fields.headline: Emerging market opens up
fields.trailText: The big money always lies in spotting the minnow who grows into a fish the size of a blue whale. In investment terms, that means going for the emerging market.
fields.body:
The big money always lies in spotting the minnow who grows into a fish the size of a blue whale. In investment terms, that means going for the emerging market.

But unless you have bought into a collective fund which buys shares in South American or South East Asian or African markets, to date it has been extremely difficult for private investors to pick up individual shares outside the EU or the US. Now Brunswick Direct, a Swedish-listed online brokerage, allows you to do just that.

Open an account with a minimum of $2,000 and you can buy or sell the stocks of 26 countries, including Vene-zuela, Estonia and Hungary - Chinese B shares are soon to come - with the average trade taking just five minutes.

Purchases can either be at the Reuters list price or at a top or bottom price decided by you. There is no maximum trade and the fee per trade is 0.75% or a minimum of $50.

But by their very nature, emerging markets are highly risky and trading in them should only be undertaken if you could afford to lose your entire investment. Financial advisers usually recommend that even the more financially sophisticated should only have 5% of their money in emerging markets.

Brunswick director Paul Luke says: "When you sign up for the site you fill in an application form which lists all the possible warnings you can imagine."

The site also carries market overviews, broker research and investment features. Luke says he currently favours Mexico and Russia, but would warn people away from Turkey and Poland. Brunswick Direct is at www.brunswickdirect.com

webTitle: US credit card giant launches three savings accounts in UK

fields.headline: US credit card giant launches three savings accounts in UK
fields.trailText: Capital One, which has more than 1m cardholders in this country, was recently granted a UK banking licence and is offering three products: an instant access-style account, a 30-day notice account and a two-year fixed rate savings bond.
fields.body:
US-based credit card giant Capital One this week entered the UK savings market with the launch of three accounts offering what it claims are "some of the most competitive rates around".

Capital One, which has more than 1m cardholders in this country, was recently granted a UK banking licence and is offering three products: an instant access-style account, a 30-day notice account and a two-year fixed rate savings bond. They are all operated by phone and post.

Its interest rate boast only partially stands up to scrutiny. The no-notice account, called Direct Saver, is paying a not-particularly-competitive 3% to 5.5% gross, with the lowest rate going to those investing between £1 and £999. To obtain the top rate of 5.5% you would need to have a whopping £50,000 stashed away.

There are better rates around than this for those seeking easy access: Nationwide's InvestDirect postal account pays from 5.55% on £1, and Alliance & Leicester's EasySaver has a rate of 5.5% from £1. Both offer instant access via a cash card. For those banking online there are even higher rates available: Halifax's Web Saver account pays 6.35% on balances of £1 plus.

However, the other two Capital One accounts offer a lot better value, particularly for those with larger sums to invest. The 30-day notice account pays 4.5% gross on balances of £1-£999, 6% on £1,000-£9,999 and an attractive 6.85% on £10,000-plus. These rates are for those opting for interest to be paid annually and include a 1% bonus for the first six months.

The two-year fixed rate bond pays 5% on balances up to £5,000, and a decent 7% for amounts above this. The latter is one of the best rates around for this type of product.

webTitle: Insurers get their dedicated policing authority

fields.headline: Insurers get their dedicated policing authority
fields.standfirst: From now on companies are to be regulated by the General Insurance Standards Council. Rupert Jones has the details
fields.trailText: From now on companies are to be regulated by the General Insurance Standards Council. Rupert Jones has the details
fields.body:
There is a new watchdog for the insurance industry on the prowl and over the coming months the public will be hearing a lot more about it.

The General Insurance Standards Council (GISC), launched two months ago, is an independent body set up to police companies selling insurance including motor, home and travel cover, plus a long list of other products from pet insurance to extended warranties offered by shops selling electrical goods.

The GISC has been set up to oversee both the insurance companies themselves and the multitude of firms that sell general insurance, ranging from insurance brokers to supermarkets to car dealerships. Its aim is to make sure people are treated fairly.

There is a code of practice containing a list of promises that all companies which sign up must follow, including pledges that all information provided will be "clear, fair and not misleading" and that complaints will be handled fairly and promptly. However, the initiative is very much focused on service and behaviour - it does not regulate the price people pay.

Since the launch around 500 companies have signed up to the scheme including most of the major insurers (Royal & Sun Alliance, Norwich Union, Direct Line, Cornhill and Churchill are among them) and a number of insurance brokers. Its profile is fairly low at present but over the next few months people will start to see television adverts from insurers that make reference to them being a member of the GISC, and the logo will start to appear in the windows of insurance brokers, travel agents and other high street outlets.

At the moment the new watchdog, set up and funded by the industry, is voluntary. However, membership is expected to become compulsory by March next year because (provided the Office of Fair Trading gives the go-ahead) from then, an insurance company that is a GISC member won't be able to deal with a broker, retailer or other seller that isn't regulated by the watchdog.

Chris Woodburn, its chief executive, hopes that one day relatively soon, just as most people wouldn't buy a package holiday unless they see the Abta symbol displayed, they won't buy an insurance policy unless they see the GISC logo.

In the meantime it is already possible to check whether a particular company has signed up to the scheme. You can log on to the website - www.gisc.co.uk - and view the list of members, which is updated all the time. Other well-known insurers which have already signed up include CGNU, Virgin Money and Egg. Mr Woodburn hopes to have 1,000 members by the end of the year, representing 80%-85% of the general insurance business done in this country.

One of Mr Woodburn's bugbears is the "unacceptable pressure" he believes people are put under to take out extended warranty cover when they buy electrical goods in particular. Britons spend more than £600m on extended warranty policies each year, an average of £121 each. These insure your ap pliances for several years after purchase but can cost up to half of the price of the item and often represent poor value for money. It is estimated that only 5% of appliances break down during the warranty years.

Aside from home, motor, travel, pet and extended warranty cover, the products covered by the scheme also include private medical and dental insurance, mortgage payment protection insurance and legal expenses cover, but do not include life insurance and pensions. There are one or two other products that could be added to the GISC's remit in the future, including long-term care insurance.

The code features a list of pledges including requirements to:

 Explain all the main features of a product including any significant restrictions or exclusions;

 Provide customers with full policy documentation;

 Handle claims "fairly and promptly";

 Give people information about what they should do if they want to make a complaint.

The GISC has a dispute resolution facility for handling complaints but doesn't have any powers to force members to compensate customers who suffer problems. However, looking to the future it is expected that members will have to belong to the new financial services ombudsman scheme (a one-stop shop for complaints against a financial services company) being launched within the next year.

Leaflets outlining people's rights under the new regime are currently being printed and will be distributed to members. It is also hoped they will be available in Citizens' Advice Bureaux and post offices.

fields.headline: Illusions of choice
fields.trailText:
My Zinc Bed
Royal Court Theatre Downstairs, London
****
fields.body:
My Zinc Bed
Royal Court Theatre Downstairs, London
****

Faith has long obsessed David Hare. After dealing in Via Dolorosa with imprisoning convictions he returns in his new play to contemporary England and to our various substitutes for political or religious belief. The result is dense, rich and engrossing, even if sometimes the social commentary is shadowed by Warner Brothers melodrama.

Addiction is one of the prime themes of the play: addiction to alcohol, love or the transient adrenalin of business. Thus we see a penurious poet and reformed alkie, Paul Peplow, hired by an ex-Marxist millionaire, Victor Quinn, as a copywriter for his burgeoning internet business.

Quinn has a young Danish wife, Elsa, who has also been rescued from an abyss of drugs-and-drink; he seems to be playing some strange Mephistophelian game, luring the poet back into alcoholic degradation to solace his solitary wife and relieve his deadlocked marriage.

On one level the play is a bizarre triangular drama with odd echoes, as when Elsa cries "I'm not a stranger to self- hatred", of Ingrid Bergman's movies. But Hare's real theme is the insecurity of modern life in which compulsions take the place of convictions: we are all hooked on something, Hare suggests; and, if business is largely a matter of creating a nebulous confidence, then so too is love.

If anything, Hare floats too many ideas. But he is very good on the acrid solitude of a staled marriage and the difficulty of conquering one's debasing compulsions. And, as always, his writing is laced with a sharp, suggestive wit. "Never underestimate the illusion of choice," cries the empire-building Quinn, neatly harpooning the paradox of capitalism. When he announces that the modern newspaper interview is a form "as rigid and contrived as the the 18th-century gavotte", journalists will flinch in recognition.

Two sides of the triangle in Hare's own production are perfectly formed: Julia Ormond as Elsa not only comes up with an exact Scandinavian accent but hauntingly creates a woman who is irreparably damaged. Steven Mackintosh also has the right hollow-cheeked intensity as the poet who cannot quite quash his faith in the liberating embrace of alcohol. Only Tom Wilkinson, while conveying Quinn's capitalist grandeur, seems at the moment to be offering an unfinished sketch rather than a complete portrait. Even so, it remains a fascinating late-Hare work analysing our modern malaise while implying that somewhere along the way we have lost any settled beliefs.

Until October 28. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: GE scraps Scottish Life bid
fields.trailText: GE Capital's £1bn bid for the insurer Scottish Life collapsed yesterday, with talks breaking down just hours before a formal takeover announcement had been expected.
fields.body:
That immediately sparked speculation that the US-based company has scrapped the deal in favour of a £4bn bid for Equitable Life.

GE Capital had been in exclusive negotiations to acquire Scottish Life but the talks, which had been going on for more than a month, are believed to have broken down over pricing issues.

A source close to the negotiations said: "The field of interested parties had been narrowed and the focus was on one, but it has since been opened up again."

In a statement Scottish Life said it was continuing discussions with a number of other companies "regarding possible strategic transactions", believed to include Royal London and Liverpool Victoria.

The company added: "Scottish Life is in in discussions to establish whether any such transaction would be in the best interests of its members and policyholders."

The £1bn takeover was expected to produce windfall payouts averaging £3,000-£4,000 for each of Scottish Life's 275,000 qualifying members.

The failure of the deal comes amid mounting speculation that an agreed takeover would have been challenged by hostile bids from other insurers locked out of the negotiations. It is understood that Scottish Life had avoided potential bids from insurers operating in the independent financial advice market, where it sells most of its products.

An agreed sale to GE Capital would have preserved the management positions and jobs of the 1,200 workers at the insurer, based in Edinburgh.

GE Capital refused to comment on the talks with Scottish Life but said it remained committed to acquiring British life insurers.

A spokesman said: "We are presently looking for a platform to grow our interests in the sector, with a close eye on demutualisations which present an opportunity to use our capital strength to support financially challenged mutuals."

Equitable Life, a mutual which is in a difficult financial position after losing a £1.5bn court case over guaranteed annuities, is now regarded as GE Capital's main target.

Equitable was put up for auction after the court case and is believed to have received expressions of interest from 15 bidders.

Until yesterday Prudential was widely tipped as the front runner, but the failure of the Scottish Life deal pitches it against GE Capital's financial firepower.

GE Capital, part of US conglomerate General Electric, has assets of more than £200bn and has made 100 acquisitions in Europe since 1995.

webTitle: Homebuying still where the heart is

fields.headline: Homebuying still where the heart is
fields.trailText: Britons are keeping the housebuying habit - for the time being at least. Despite house prices flattening out, an above average 4% plan to move over the next three months.
fields.body:
Britons are keeping the housebuying habit - for the time being at least. Despite house prices flattening out, an above average 4% plan to move over the next three months, according to the new Move and Improve index from Alliance & Leicester. And that's in line with a similar survey this time last year.

Some 6% say they intend to buy between January 2001 and next September. But unless more join them, demand could fall. The index measures sentiment rather than actual decisions.

Alliance & Leicester says most people move because they need to - 30% need more space, 16% change because of relationship breakdowns and other personal matters while 13% do so because they have a new job. Only 22% cite "change of environment" or "hating the neighbours."

But even those who need a new property are not happy with present values. Only 7% of those planning to move reckon now is a good time to invest in bricks and mortar.

On one measure, however, house prices look a bargain. The Cheltenham & Gloucester affordability index - it compares prices with incomes - predicts the average home purchaser will spend 39.5% of take-home pay on their mortgage by the end of this year, compared with 71.3% when the indicator hit an all-time high in 1990.

"The housing market has peaked but the early Bank of England action in raising interest rates has avoided the drastic action needed to regain control a decade ago. We have just had a mini-boom with a much less damaging impact on affordability," says C&G 's Roger Burden.

And Bradford & Bingley claims buy to rent is still a sound investment with yields of up to 9%.

fields.headline: Pensions minefield cleared
fields.standfirst: What is the bid/offer spread? Under the new rules ordinary investors will no longer have to scratch their heads. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: What is the bid/offer spread? Under the new rules ordinary investors will no longer have to scratch their heads. Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
A major new scheme aimed at helping people to pick their way through the pensions and investments minefield is being launched next month, finally spelling curtains for the dreaded "bid/offer spread" that has baffled investors for years.

The initiative is aimed at making it easier for people to buy products such as personal pensions, life insurance and unit trusts with confidence and there will be a new kitemark-style logo that companies can display if they meet eight "promises" on such things as clarity of information, customer satisfaction and your right to get your money back.

Investors will also be cheered by the fact that there are plans to simplify the charging structure on many products and abolish completely some of the charges that bamboozle investors.

The scheme, which is currently lumbered with the tag "the Savings and Long-Term Risk initiative" (SALTR), is aimed at boosting public confidence in pension and investment products following a wave of recent scandals, most notably the £11bn personal pensions mis-selling debacle and the current endowment mortgage crisis.

This is not a government initiative and has nothing to do with the "Cat-mark" scheme for individual savings accounts and mortgages - it's being co-ordinated by a group of leading financial services companies backed by the Association of British Insurers and membership will be voluntary.

But those behind the scheme reject any suggestions that this means it will be a toothless regime. They say the standards will be tough for firms to meet and will be policed by an independent body. The standards and logo will be officially launched on October 17 but the scheme doesn't go live until October 2001. Why such a long gap? Andrew Stoker, project co-ordinator, says they have given companies a year "to get their house in order and apply for the mark".

The scheme will cover a range of products including personal pensions, stakeholder pensions (to be launched in April 2001), life insurance, endowment policies, unit trusts and Isas, and with-profits bonds. It's very much driven by life insurers, but those behind it are also hoping to get high street banks and fund management companies on board.

One aspect of the scheme that Mr Stoker says will be quite painful for companies is the requirement to phase out some charging structures that investors find hardest to fathom. We will finally see the end of the "bid/offer spread", which has long puzzled people buying life and pension products and unit trusts.

At the moment, when you invest in these products, you'll be issued with a number of units in the fund. The bid/offer spread is the difference between the price at which you buy units (the "offer" price) and the price you get when you cash in your investments (the "bid" price). Investors are confused because the bid/offer spread will often be different to the initial charge they have been quoted. For example, the initial charge might be 5.25% and the spread 6%-7%.

In an attempt to make it simpler, those in charge of the scheme have decided that products launched by member companies after the scheme goes live cannot have a bid/offer spread. They will have until October 2004 to get rid of the bid/offer spread on all existing products, and in the meantime will have to call it an initial charge.

The eight promises include pledges to:

 Clearly set out the costs, communicate "in plain language" and inform you regularly about how your products are doing. There will be a requirement that annual statements for products such as pension plans will have to prominently display the "true value" of your plan or policy. "At the moment quite a lot of companies say the current value of your contract is X, but if the person rings up they are told there are surrender penalties or the transfer value [what you'd get if you decided to move your money to another company] is a lot less than that," says Andrew Stoker. "We are saying the true value is what the customer can get out at that point and that is what we should be seeing."

 Extend the current 14-day "cooling-off" period for people buying unit trusts, pensions and life policies to 30 days. This means that if you decide within this period you don't want the product, the company will refund the original investment.

 Meet minimum targets for customer satisfaction. Companies will get a score based on how happy customers are with such things as service provided and how complaints are handled. Those that don't make the grade can't be part of the scheme.

To win the mark of quality, a company will have to meet the standards for all its relevant products; it can't have a few products that meet them and others that don't. An independent board will be responsible for policing the regime and will have the power to strip companies of the quality mark if they fail to make the grade.

Investors will also be cheered by the fact that there are plans to simplify the charging structure on many products and abolish completely some of the charges that bamboozle investors. The scheme, which is currently lumbered with the tag "the Savings and Long-Term Risk initiative" (SALTR), is aimed at boosting public confidence in pension and investment products following a wave of recent scandals, most notably the £11bn personal pensions mis-selling debacle and the current endowment mortgage crisis. This is not a government initiative and has nothing to do with the "Cat-mark" scheme for individual savings accounts and mortgages - it's being co-ordinated by a group of leading financial services companies backed by the Association of British Insurers and membership will be voluntary. But those behind the scheme reject any suggestions that this means it will be a toothless regime. They say the standards will be tough for firms to meet and will be policed by an independent body. The standards and logo will be officially launched on October 17 but the scheme doesn't go live until October 2001. Why such a long gap? Andrew Stoker, project co-ordinator, says they have given companies a year "to get their house in order and apply for the mark". The scheme will cover a range of products including personal pensions, stakeholder pensions (to be launched in April 2001), life insurance, endowment policies, unit trusts and Isas, and with-profits bonds. It's very much driven by life insurers, but those behind it are also hoping to get high street banks and fund management companies on board. One aspect of the scheme that Mr Stoker says will be quite painful for companies is the requirement to phase out some charging structures that investors find hardest to fathom. We will finally see the end of the "bid/offer spread", which has long puzzled people buying life and pension products and unit trusts. At the moment, when you invest in these products, you'll be issued with a number of units in the fund. The bid/offer spread is the difference between the price at which you buy units (the "offer" price) and the price you get when you cash in your investments (the "bid" price). Investors are confused because the bid/offer spread will often be different to the initial charge they have been quoted. For example, the initial charge might be 5.25% and the spread 6%-7%. In an attempt to make it simpler, those in charge of the scheme have decided that products launched by member companies after the scheme goes live cannot have a bid/offer spread. They will have until October 2004 to get rid of the bid/offer spread on all existing products, and in the meantime will have to call it an initial charge. The eight promises include pledges to:  Clearly set out the costs, communicate "in plain language" and inform you regularly about how your products are doing. There will be a requirement that annual statements for products such as pension plans will have to prominently display the "true value" of your plan or policy. "At the moment quite a lot of companies say the current value of your contract is X, but if the person rings up they are told there are surrender penalties or the transfer value [what you'd get if you decided to move your money to another company] is a lot less than that," says Andrew Stoker. "We are saying the true value is what the customer can get out at that point and that is what we should be seeing."  Extend the current 14-day "cooling-off" period for people buying unit trusts, pensions and life policies to 30 days. This means that if you decide within this period you don't want the product, the company will refund the original investment.  Meet minimum targets for customer satisfaction. Companies will get a score based on how happy customers are with such things as service provided and how complaints are handled. Those that don't make the grade can't be part of the scheme. To win the mark of quality, a company will have to meet the standards for all its relevant products; it can't have a few products that meet them and others that don't. An independent board will be responsible for policing the regime and will have the power to strip companies of the quality mark if they fail to make the grade.

fields.headline:
Thousands 
 
missing out on benefits
fields.trailText: Thousands of elderly people continue to be short-changed on their state pensions because of a string of faults with the government computer system designed to calculate pension entitlements.
fields.body:
Thousands of elderly people continue to be short-changed on their state pensions because of a string of faults with the government computer system designed to calculate pension entitlements.

The experience of a Jobs & Money reader from Cambridge is typical of what charity Help the Aged describes as, "a scandal that beggars belief".

The reader deferred receiving his state pension until this January when he put in his claim at age 67. When his first payment came through, he realised he had been paid only the basic state pension of £67.50 and none of the extras due to him including an additional pension from the State Earnings-Related Pension Scheme (Serps), graduated retirement benefit and benefit for his deferred pension period.

When he asked why he was being underpaid, the agency told him that it had a "computer fault" which needed to be rectified before he could be paid the additions he was owned. This was despite the fact that the sums involved were not in doubt. He had received a letter from the Benefits Agency in December 1997 telling him that he would be entitled to a state pension of £83 a week.

Most worrying for him and for others in a similar position was that the agency was unable at the time to give him any indication of when the problem might be solved and when he would start getting the benefits to which he was entitled. "As pensioners are prone to a higher death rate than other members of the population, the non-payment of what is due to them has an even more important significance than to other people," he said.

He was also shocked to be told that compensation for "people who have suffered delay and inconvenience in receiving their full pension entitlement due to the problems with the computer system" is a paltry one-off £10.

It took a strong letter of complaint and another seven months of waiting before the agency sorted out his entitlement and eventually sent him back pay of £1,000.

Payment delay problems started in 1998 following the installation of a new computer system called NIRS2 at the Newcastle headquarters of the Contributions Agency, then a division of the DSS but now, confusingly, renamed the National Insurance Contributions Office (NICO) and part of the Inland Revenue.

Technical problems caused continuing difficulties in calculating top-up pension entitlements for people who had contracted out of Serps into personal pension schemes for the tax year 1997/98. As a result, thousands of pensioners have been receiving only the basic state pension while waiting indefinitely for their additional entitlements to be calculated and some people who retire in the near future could also be affected.

"We've heard from a number of people who have been affected and are angry at not getting the money they are entitled to," says a spokesperson for the charity Age Concern.

"It's very difficult for them to plan ahead when they don't know what their full provision will be."

Help the Aged says: "It's a scandal that thousands of pensioners are suffering from this mess, having to live on the basic state pension when many are due a substantial top-up.

"And the government still hasn't committed itself to righting the problem."

In May, the Secretary of State for Social Security Jeff Rooker said that 128,000 pensioners were still waiting for their cases to be reviewed and that the Benefits Agency would complete its review of the backlog of retirement pension claims by the end of this year.

But that may be optimistic. An Inland Revenue spokesperson said this week that the last claims should "hopefully"be sorted out by April 2001. However, slightly more encouraging news for pensioners in this predicament comes from the DSS. "Anybody affected by this can ask their local Benefits Agency to do a manual calculation of their pension entitlement.

"This may take a bit of time, perhaps a couple of weeks, but once it has been done they should start to receive their full entitlement," said a spokesperson.

On top of the one-off £10 compensation payment, peo ple who have already been waiting some time for their full pension entitlement to be worked out may also be eligible for compensation under the DSS' general special payments scheme.

To qualify, the arrears owed must be more than £100, the delay suffered must be more than eight months and any potential compensation must be worth £10 or more. Application details are available from local benefits agencies.

webTitle: Stock exchange chief quits over iX debacle

fields.headline: Stock exchange chief quits over iX debacle
fields.trailText: Gavin Casey, chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, became the first casualty of its botched merger yesterday by resigning with a £600,000 pay-off.
fields.body:
Gavin Casey, chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, became the first casualty of its botched merger yesterday by resigning with a £600,000 pay-off.

Mr Casey, whose departure was regarded as inevitable after shareholders tried to eject him at the annual meeting on Thursday, left immediately.

The exchange has begun to seek a replacement who will help fend off the hostile £800m bid by OM of Sweden. Brian Winterflood, chairman of Winterflood Securities, said the new chief executive should be a "young, aggressive, computer literate, whiz-kid".

Mr Casey's departure, after a four-year tenure, came amid speculation that Deutsche Börse, the German exchange with which London was to have merged, was rallying support for a "white knight" bid. Deutsche Börse was said to have been in discussion with exchanges in Milan and Madrid about a rescue, with support from the US Nasdaq hi-tech exchange.

During the search for Mr Casey's successor, Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London exchange, will fill his role. Mr Cruickshank, who joined the exchange only six months ago and also faced a knife-edge vote by shareholders this week, paid tribute to Mr Casey.

"Shareholders of the LSE and all our customer owe a lot to Gavin." However, Mr Cruickshank refused to say whether he had still supported his chief executive after Thursday's meeting.

Michael Marks of Merrill Lynch was also said to be under pressure to resign after shareholders expressed dissatisfaction with his non-executive role on the exchange's board.

Mr Casey, who turned the exchange from a loss-maker to profit earner, ended up taking the blame for the ill-fated plans to create iX, the Anglo-German exchange that was to have become a pan-European centre for share dealing. He was on a one-year contract and was paid £624,000 last year.

In his resignation letter Mr Casey said: "I have decided that it is absolutely right that I should resign as chief executive of the company and this I now do, to take effect today."

At the annual meeting, the exchange's first since its demutualisation, shareholders called for exchange executives to "fall on their swords".

Last night Hugh Marsden, a partner at stockbroker SP Angel & Co, said of Mr Casey. "I don't think he did too bad a job. I'm sorry its come to this."

webTitle: Oiling a slippery slope for the UK's future

fields.headline: Oiling a slippery slope for the UK's future
fields.standfirst: The blockade is adding to the woes of a British economy which should be doing better, Robin Stoddart believes
fields.trailText: While the leap in the price of oil had limited impact even on the industrial countries that are the heaviest users and importers, the stoppage on deliveries put the London market in a stew this week.
fields.body:
There is a limit to the number of shocks the economy as well as the stock market can absorb. While the leap in the price of oil had limited impact even on the industrial countries that are the heaviest users and importers, the stoppage on deliveries put the London market in a stew this week.

Severe management difficulties in many areas ranging from the Stock Exchange itself through the Dome and in the government followed a string of bad news from major companies, particularly in engineering and textiles.

"Old hat" could have been the response to the problems of manufacturers facing competition from low-wage countries. And with its own oil and gas resources the UK is not a loser when prices rise. But the contrast between the economic performance of the US and other industrial countries, particularly Britain, was underlined by the prospect of disruption caused by fuel shortages.

The US economy is expanding by a near-record 5.2% this year and 10 years of constant growth will soon be chalked up. Hopes that the UK might advance at more than half this rate could soon be blighted and there is no expectation at all that productivity will accelerate, as it has across the Atlantic.

Deal-making is still flourishing, but it is American companies which are calling the tune and taking most of the profits. They already dominate the investment banking business and much of the fund management activity which helps keep the City prosperous. American companies own a large proportion of the most dynamic UK industries and are steadily mopping up more.

Wealthy individual investors, as well as US institutions, own large stakes in the companies that remain under home ownership. By contrast, only 7% of US equities are overseas-owned. The spate of European acquisitions of US corporations testifies to their technological and marketing abilities. But outside oil and pharmaceuticals there are few British companies large enough to be more than bystanders in this activity, where they are not the actual prey.

UK managers have made such a mess of old acquisitions in the US, whether in retailing, insurance, or most areas of manufacturing, that they have often resorted to employing chief executives from overseas to maintain any expansionary ambitions in faster-growing areas and, in many cases, to plan and execute improvement policies at home.

There are signs of a new entrepreneurialism among the younger owner managers in hi-tech and service areas, but they are no more widespread than in other European countries and way behind those in the US.

It is, nevertheless, still the general view that the UK economy is doing quite well, as shown by near-full employment and negligible inflation. But when capacity in so many areas of manufacturing is being axed and there is a desperate resort to overseas recruitment - not just for those with special qualifications in information technology, but for the teaching and nursing professions where the supply of dedicated women particularly seemed assured not many years ago - prospects must be in some doubt.

The hundreds of thousands employed in call centres may or may not prefer the pay and hours on a temporary basis, but in a country that is both densely populated and gradually ageing the outlook is grey.

Perhaps the state of public finances highlights the problem as much as anything. An enormous budget surplus has accrued from taxation that, besides the main elements of sales and income tax, relies more than anywhere else on heavy drink, tobacco and fuel duties. Although they are insupportable in that they erode the activities on which they are based and encourage smuggling and overseas operators, the government is only feebly promoting more desirable outcomes for health and the environment.

It could raise many more billions through National Savings and issues of government stock. If it delays, they will become more difficult and expensive. Already gilts, at least at the longer end of the range of dates and particularly among undated issues, are well off their peaks. Although moves allowing pension and life funds to invest in top-quality corporate bonds would ease the upward pressure on the limited supply of government stocks with their guarantee of repayment on due date, the present financial situation is less satisfactory than the inflation figure before the most recent oil price rises and official protestations of prudence would have us all believe.

The fall in the pound against the dollar testifies to an impending, if old, balance of payments problem. But it has given funds invested mainly in the US a mighty boost in recent weeks. Double-figure percentage gains in unit and investment trusts were common last month, though large insurance and bank funds with mainly old economy holdings lagged.

Among Fidelity's numerous funds specialising in the home market, Special Situations jumped by over a fifth and in a year it has almost doubled. Abbey US Emerging beat this by a fifth over a year, while both Gartmore American Emerging and Small Companies funds scored growth of almost 18% last month.

Smaller company funds grew half as fast again as the average north American unit fund, but Threadneedle's large funds in the area stood out and, while the Smaller Companies units soared by 120%, the two others appreciated around three-quarters over a year. AIB Govett US Opportunities and Framlington American Growth were not far behind with growth of over two-thirds and a few points less respectively.

In this sector investment trusts were mostly too large and set in their blue-chip ways to distinguish themselves, but Fleming raised values by 40% in a year, as did a couple of the medium-sized international generalists, led by Brunner. The two giants Foreign & Colonial and Witan meantime pushed ahead by getting on for a third.

fields.headline: Plastic without the drastic
fields.standfirst: Parents may quail at the idea but children can't use this card to borrow. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Parents may quail at the idea but children can't use this card to borrow. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
The launch this week of a plastic payment card specifically aimed at teenagers will cause more than a few parents to shudder at the idea of a "credit card for kids".

The card, called Splash Plastic, is targeting youngsters who want to buy goods on the internet and is designed "to give teens the independence to spend their own money online", says the company behind it.

However, parents can breathe a sigh of relief: Splash Plastic isn't actually a credit card. It's a pre-paid card that only allows you to spend what you've got, so you can't run up huge debts.

Mums and dads have a few months to prepare for the full-scale Splash Plastic assault - it is being piloted in November and will be officially launched in late January backed by a £2.5m advertising campaign. But kids are already being enticed to sign up now by logging on to the website (www.splashplastic.com). Those under 14 are requested to ask their parents to complete the online form for them.

Teenagers are arguably the most net-savvy section of the population and more than 80% say they are keen to buy CDs, computer games and books online, but up until now most of them have effectively been locked out of the e-shopping revolution because they are not allowed to have a credit card. Splash Plastic says its card gives teenagers the freedom to shop independently on the net.

"There are 6.7m teenagers in the UK spending £20bn a year. They want to spend their own money and don't want to ask to borrow a credit card or rely on their parents to top up on online 'e-wallet'," says the company's marketing director Briand Beausoleil. It is estimated that one in three teenagers could have a pre-paid card of this type within two years.

So how do the cards work, and who are Splash Plastic anyway? The cards look just like credit cards, even down to the magnetic stripe on the back, but there is no credit facility. You have to go into a participating shop, hand over your card and the money you wish to spend online, say, £10 of pocket money.

The shop assistant will key this into a special terminal which will credit it to their Splash Plastic account. The card is now automatically loaded with £10 of cash and the teenager can spend it online immediately at internet retailers subscribing to the scheme. You don't need a bank account.

Splash Plastic says it is working with the UK's leading payment system providers on developing a network of 60,000 high street top-up terminals. It has already signed a deal with PayPoint, which operates a system for payment of bills through newsagents, convenience stores, supermarkets and petrol stations, and is busily trying to sign up online retailers selling "appropriate" items such as books, CDs, computer games and clothing.

The system is described by the company as "safe, secure and convenient". Cardholders will have a password which they will have to quote when making purchases.

Splash Plastic was set up by a group of London Business School graduates. It has secured funding from venture capitalists including GE Equity (the investment arm of GE Capital, the UK's largest store card provider), Global Retail Partners, Arts Alliance and Sussex Place Investment Management, the London Business School's investment division.

So what do others think? The National Consumer Council says that because the card is pre-paid, teenagers can spend only the amount which parents have agreed to. But it adds that less well-off mums and dads are inevitably going to come under pressure from their offspring to take out a card or top it up.

Other card news

 RBS Advanta has launched the lowest-cost credit card in the UK - an introductory annual percentage rate (APR) of 2.9 for both purchases and balance transfers until June 1 2001. But after that, the standard rate of 17.9 will apply (16.9 for the platinum version of the card).

 After years of looking down its nose at the wave of low-cost, no-frills credit cards launched in the UK, Barclaycard is quietly test-marketing one of its own. Selected Barclays customers are being invited to sign up for Barclaycard Alpha, which has no annual fee, a standard rate of 14.9 APR on purchases and a 5.9 APR balance transfer rate.

 People's Bank and Virgin Mobile have joined forces so that anyone taking out a People's Bank platinum credit card can take advantage of an introductory rate of 4.9 APR for purchases and balance transfers, plus obtain £50 off Virgin Mobile's new Siemens M35i handset, which currently sells for £119.99.

It is estimated that one in three teenagers could have a pre-paid card of this type within two years. So how do the cards work, and who are Splash Plastic anyway? The cards look just like credit cards, even down to the magnetic stripe on the back, but there is no credit facility. You have to go into a participating shop, hand over your card and the money you wish to spend online, say, £10 of pocket money. The shop assistant will key this into a special terminal which will credit it to their Splash Plastic account. The card is now automatically loaded with £10 of cash and the teenager can spend it online immediately at internet retailers subscribing to the scheme. You don't need a bank account. Splash Plastic says it is working with the UK's leading payment system providers on developing a network of 60,000 high street top-up terminals. It has already signed a deal with PayPoint, which operates a system for payment of bills through newsagents, convenience stores, supermarkets and petrol stations, and is busily trying to sign up online retailers selling "appropriate" items such as books, CDs, computer games and clothing. The system is described by the company as "safe, secure and convenient". Cardholders will have a password which they will have to quote when making purchases. Splash Plastic was set up by a group of London Business School graduates. It has secured funding from venture capitalists including GE Equity (the investment arm of GE Capital, the UK's largest store card provider), Global Retail Partners, Arts Alliance and Sussex Place Investment Management, the London Business School's investment division. So what do others think? The National Consumer Council says that because the card is pre-paid, teenagers can spend only the amount which parents have agreed to. But it adds that less well-off mums and dads are inevitably going to come under pressure from their offspring to take out a card or top it up. Other card news  RBS Advanta has launched the lowest-cost credit card in the UK - an introductory annual percentage rate (APR) of 2.9 for both purchases and balance transfers until June 1 2001. But after that, the standard rate of 17.9 will apply (16.9 for the platinum version of the card).  After years of looking down its nose at the wave of low-cost, no-frills credit cards launched in the UK, Barclaycard is quietly test-marketing one of its own. Selected Barclays customers are being invited to sign up for Barclaycard Alpha, which has no annual fee, a standard rate of 14.9 APR on purchases and a 5.9 APR balance transfer rate.  People's Bank and Virgin Mobile have joined forces so that anyone taking out a People's Bank platinum credit card can take advantage of an introductory rate of 4.9 APR for purchases and balance transfers, plus obtain £50 off Virgin Mobile's new Siemens M35i handset, which currently sells for £119.99.

webTitle: Better life cover deal may be in family way

fields.headline: Better life cover deal may be in family way
fields.standfirst: An income benefit policy may be both cheaper and easier to manage than term insurance. Jill Papworth compares them
fields.trailText: An income benefit policy may be both cheaper and easier to manage than term insurance. Jill Papworth compares them.
fields.body:
When people with young families look for essential life cover they normally buy term insurance, a no-frills protection product which pays out a lump sum if you die within the specified term and nothing if you don't.

But, where money is tight, they will generally get a better deal by buying a less well-known family income benefit (FIB) policy, according to Donna Bradshaw, a director of London-based independent financial advisers Fiona Price & Partners.

"Most people will survive until their children reach adulthood. So for most young families, the priority is to pay as little as possible for essential protection you hope you will never need to call upon," Ms Bradshaw says.

"Family income benefit, which can be arranged to pay you an index-linked annual income, gives you the level of protection you need at a lower cost than straight term insurance. And, though the savings aren't huge, managing to shave even £5 a month off the cost of your life cover means you've got a bit more to spend on other essentials."

For a male non-smoker aged 30 next birthday, FIB paying £15,000 per year increasing at the rate of inflation over a 20-year term, the cheapest premium at present is £12.29 per month from Swiss Life. For his female equivalent, the same cover would cost £10.41 per month, again from Swiss Life.

The cheapest quotes for a 20-year level term policy paying out a roughly equivalent lump sum benefit of £250,000 would be £17.71 for the same man and £12.88 for the same woman, from Legal & General.

FIB is also easier to manage than straight term insurance, which is generally arranged to pay out a fixed lump sum. It is relatively straightforward to calculate what income your dependents would need to live on if you were to die. It's trickier to work out what lump sum they'd require to invest in order to generate an adequate income over a period of years, given the unpredictable ups and downs of inflation. And, should the worst happen, the last thing your bereaved partner will feel able to cope with is deciding how to invest a lump sum to produce an income while the children are still dependent. Arranging for them to receive an inflation-linked income will relieve them of any such worries.

FIB is cheaper than level term insurance because, as time goes by, the overall payout on FIB is less and therefore the risk to the insurer is less. Take the example of the FIB policy above paying out an inflation-linked income of £15,000 per year over a 20-year term. If the insured were to die in year one, their dependents would receive £15,000 (plus inflation) each year for the next 19 years - a total of £285,000 (plus inflation). Were they to die in, say, year 10 the total payout would reduce to £150,000 (plus inflation). So the cost and risk to the insurer reduces over time.

If the insured died leaving a 20-year level term policy paying out a £250,000 lump sum, the payout would remain the same whenever during the term their demise occurred.

Barry Davys, an independent financial adviser specialising in family protection products, agrees that FIB is slightly cheaper than term insurance and that, in the event of a bereavement, it can simplify the need to manage finances.

But, he says: "Given that the difference in cost is relatively small, unless pennies are critical, I feel term insurance provides better value because you get full cover throughout the term.

"Also, though it's true that working out how to invest a lump sum can be a problem for a recently bereaved person, I've come across many who are very glad of a lump sum rather than an income, especially where the deceased has left substantial debts - which is often the case in my experience. Really you need to compare the two types of cover and make a personal judgement on which would best suit your needs."

webTitle: Naked truth about investing in shares

fields.headline: Naked truth about investing in shares
fields.standfirst: The London Stock Exchange's campaign to increase public awareness of the long-term benefits of equity investment is heading for the capital
fields.trailText: Tomorrow sees the beginning of Share Aware London, the biggest event to date in the London Stock Exchange's ongoing Share Aware campaign aimed at raising awareness of the long-term benefits of equity investment for the private investor.
fields.body:
For the first course: Jamie Oliver launched a programme of seminars and workshops

Tomorrow sees the beginning of Share Aware London, the biggest event to date in the London Stock Exchange's ongoing Share Aware campaign aimed at raising awareness of the long-term benefits of equity investment for the private investor.

Following roadshow visits to Leeds, Birmingham, Scotland, Cardiff and the North- west over the past two years which attracted more than 5,000 people, the campaign is now hitting London. Jamie Oliver, BBC2's Naked Chef, yesterday launched the week-long programme of seminars and workshops for private investors at venues across the capital culminating in the two-day Sharex exhibition at London Olympia on September 22-23.

For anyone keen to hone their share investment skills, the event should certainly provide some useful, low-cost information - most of the seminars are free and it costs just £15 for both days at Sharex if you register in advance.

According to new research by ProShare, a body which promotes share ownership, and the Stock Exchange, the number of people who have bought shares has increased by 33% over the past 18 months.

It also found that if you had invested £500 in the stock market in 1989, it could have been worth as much as £2,290 in 1999, while the same amount put into a typical building society account would have gen erated a return of just £777.

The exciting possibility of choosing a stock market winner may tempt you to make your first dive into equities by buying the shares of just one or two companies that appear promising.

Novice investors, however, might be advised to be wary of being carried away by topics such as how to pick growth stocks. While there is no disputing the basic message behind the Share Aware campaign - that over the long term the real return from shares historically outperforms all other types of investment - this does not mean that all individuals will benefit from becoming direct shareholders.

"Very few people can afford the risk that buying individual equities will expose them to when starting out as investors," says Dan Kemp of independent financial adviser Holden Meehan.

"Unless you've got substantial funds to invest - and that means £250,000-plus that you don't need in the short-term - then you should go for collective investments where each individual share will make up only a very small proportion of your holding."

Buying individual shares means betting on being able to pick top-performing stocks and avoid the losers.

The beauty of holding shares via collective investments or pooled funds like unit trusts and investment trusts is that your money is invested - and your risk is thus spread - across a wide range of shares in a fund managed by an experienced professional.

"Direct ownership is significantly higher risk than collective investments and it's all to do with diversity. The more companies you spread your money across, the more consistent your return," Mr Kemp says.

"What you need is long-term consistent returns which will come from well-diversified collective investments."

One good place to start learning the basics of successful stock market investment is via Proshare, which is an independent non-profit making body that produces a range of useful factsheets.

"We recognise that share ownership is not for everybody," says a spokesperson. "If a first-time investor contacts us about getting started we emphasise several points. First, that you should only consider share ownership once you have got your pension, insurances and rainy day savings in place. Second, that you should only invest money you can afford to leave untouched over the long term and that you can afford to lose. And third, that your first way in to shares should be through some sort of collective such as an individual savings account (Isa), unit trusts, investment trusts or via an investment club."

More detailed information on investing in unit trusts is available from Autif (the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds) and on investment trusts from AITC, the Association of Investment Trust Companies.

Share Aware London seminars that may particularly appeal to novice investors include Proshare's How to set up and run a successful investment club (tomorrow 2.15pm at The Hilton Metropole Hotel, W2 - entry £5). Visitors to the Sharex exhibition can also attend seminars by Alvin Hall, presenter of BBC2's Your Money or Your Life and Tom Winnifrith, presenter of Channel 4's Show Me The Money.

For information on Share Aware London, call 020-7797-4444 or visit the Share Aware section on www. londonstockexchange.com. To register for Sharex phone 0131-466-4242 or go to www.sharex.co.uk. Proshare factsheets are available on 0870-264-5484 or at www.proshare.org.uk. For Autif information call 0208-207-1361 or visit www.investmentfunds.org.uk. For AITC information, call 0800-707-707 or visit www.itsonline.co.uk

fields.headline: The top ten mistakes
fields.trailText: Ticking on page 2 that a specified supplementary page is attached, but then not attaching it.
fields.body:
Ticking on page 2 that a specified supplementary page is attached, but then not attaching it.

Failing to complete a separate supplementary page for each employment.

Stating that information may be found elsewhere, for example, "per P60", rather than entering the figures on the return.

Reporting the capital balance on a savings account, rather than the interest earned in the year.

Stating that a figure is provisional when it is actually an estimate. (If a figure is provisional, the Revenue will expect you to come back with a more reliable figure later, see above.)

Entering the net figure for pension contributions paid by an employee, instead of the gross amount before tax relief given at source.

Sending information in a covering letter or attached accounts, rather than on the form itself. (A covering letter or accounts may helpfully expand on what is on the form, but cannot substitute for a completed tax return.)

Failing to tick 'yes' at question 19, asking the Revenue to refund any overpayment of tax. (In such cases, the Revenue will hold any repayment against future tax liabilities.)

Failing to sign and date the form on page 8.

Failing to take a photocopy of the return (in case the original is mislaid by the Revenue).

webTitle: A form guide to filling in

fields.headline: A form guide to filling in
fields.standfirst: As a tax return deadline looms, David Brodie tackles the most frequently asked questions and helps to explode some myths
fields.trailText: As a tax return deadline looms, David Brodie tackles the most frequently asked questions and helps to explode some myths.
fields.body:
Four and a half years after the last government heralded the introduction of self-assessment as "a simpler and fairer system", calls to TaxAid's helpline reveal that a high level of confusion persists among ordinary taxpayers. As we approach the September 30 filing date, it may help to explode a few myths.

I will be charged a penalty if I do not file my return by September 30.

False. The legal deadline for filing is January 31. There is a £100 penalty if you miss that time limit, but no penalty for filing after September 30.

But I must file by September 30 if I want the Revenue to work out my tax.

False. The Revenue will work out your tax whenever you file the return. However, if you do so after this month, the taxman cannot guarantee to let you have his calculation before January 31, 2001, the date any remaining tax for 1999-2000 falls due. Without his figures, you may underpay and so face interest and surcharges.

There is no other reason for filing by September 30.

False. If you are an employee, another benefit of early filing is that the Revenue will collect any underpayment below £1,000 through your PAYE code for 2001-02 and you will not have to pay it next January.

If I have not been sent a tax return form, I do not need to worry about tax.

False. If in 1999/2000 you had income or capital gains which were not fully taxed, you must notify the Revenue in writing no later than October 5. If you do not, you could face a penalty of up to the amount of tax due.

I cannot complete my return as I have lost my P60 (or P45) and my boss says she cannot provide a duplicate.

Half true. Your employer may not produce duplicate forms, but she could give you a letter or note showing the salary you were paid and the tax deducted, which is all you need. If she won't help, you may get the figures from the Revenue; as your employer should have filed them with the tax office by now.

I cannot complete the return as I am still awaiting some information from a third party.

False. You need not delay filing just because you do not have all the information you need. For example, if you are still awaiting details of income you received from a bank or building society, or benefits-in-kind from your employment, you may enter a 'provisional figure' on the form, tick box 22.3, and then supply the correct figure after filing, when you obtain it (see page 27 of the tax return guide).

I cannot complete the form as I have lost details of some of my income.

False. The taxman accepts that it is sometimes necessary to make an estimate - for example, if records have been lost or destroyed. This is explained under 'Other estimates' on page 27 of the guide. Where a significant figure is estimated, it is best to explain this in the white box on page 8 of the form, so that it is clear what you have done.

I went to my tax office for help in completing the form but was told that this is my responsibility and they were not allowed to assist.

False. While tax office staff will not normally write information on the form itself, they should always be willing to explain the entries that you should make. Such sup port is promised under the Revenue's Service Commitment reproduced on page 31 of the guide, and you may complain if it is refused.

As a pensioner on a low income, I do not understand why I was sent a tax return. However, once a form is issued, it must be completed.

False. Last year the Revenue announced that it would be taking 200,000 low income pensioners out of self-assessment. It seems you may have been overlooked, but if you telephone your tax office to explain your situation they may agree to dispense with the form.

I am frightened to file in case my form contains a mistake, and then there is nothing I can do.

False. After filing, you can "amend" your return by a letter to your tax office pointing out the error and giving the correct figure. This can be done at any time up until 12 months after the filing deadline - that is, by January 31, 2002.

 David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity that offers free advice on tax matters to people who cannot afford professional fees. Tel: 020-7624-3768 Mondays to Thursdays, 10am-noon.

The top ten mistakes

 Ticking on page 2 that a specified supplementary page is attached, but then not attaching it.

 Failing to complete a separate supplementary page for each employment.

 Stating that information may be found elsewhere, for example, "per P60", rather than entering the figures on the return.

 Reporting the capital balance on a savings account, rather than the interest earned in the year.

 Stating that a figure is provisional when it is actually an estimate. (If a figure is provisional, the Revenue will expect you to come back with a more reliable figure later, see above.)

 Entering the net figure for pension contributions paid by an employee, instead of the gross amount before tax relief given at source.

 Sending information in a covering letter or attached accounts, rather than on the form itself. (A covering letter or accounts may helpfully expand on what is on the form, but cannot substitute for a completed tax return.)

 Failing to tick 'yes' at question 19, asking the Revenue to refund any overpayment of tax. (In such cases, the Revenue will hold any repayment against future tax liabilities.)

 Failing to sign and date the form on page 8.

 Failing to take a photocopy of the return (in case the original is mislaid by the Revenue).

fields.headline: It's party time again
fields.trailText: There's bad news for day-time television viewers. The party political conference season is about to begin, promising three weeks of afternoon viewing which combines the anarchic spontaneity of Songs of Praise with the wit and warmth of the Shopping Channel.
fields.body:
There's bad news for day-time television viewers. The party political conference season is about to begin, promising three weeks of afternoon viewing which combines the anarchic spontaneity of Songs of Praise with the wit and warmth of the Shopping Channel.

If you're irresistibly attracted by the sound of people patting themselves on the back you might be tempted to sign up and join one of these parties. But what are the costs of becoming politically active? And never mind what they're offering the country, what have they got for their own members?

For £17.50 (£6 unwaged and pensioners) you could join Labour. This entitles you to membership of the Labour party travel club (currently offering trips to Las Vegas and the Dominican Republic) and a special rate on home, motor and travel insurance, arranged through CGU.

There is also a legal service for members, offering free advice for car crash injuries and discounts on wills and conveyancing. Also, the "Labour Savings Club" promises to shop around for you and find savings on big household purchases. Another perk is that you can buy into a wide catalogue of merchandising, along the lines of the Greet the Dawn tea towel, priced at £5.99.

But the People's Party credit card - a Co-operative Visa card - doesn't do any favours with a 19.8APR (and a donation to the party of 0.25% of whatever you spend on the card).

If this doesn't feel like a party that swings, the Conservatives charge £15 membership for an opposition that can offer a discount wine club and cheap televisions. William Hague might have drawn a few sniggers with his claim to have drunk 14 pints a day as a youth, but it's his party that is rocking enough to offer a reduction on a case of wine from £72.93 to £58.99.

If that isn't enough to get you looking right, the party sound system has never been cheaper than through the membership deal with Home Electrical Direct, an online dealer in discount televisions, washing machines, hi-fis and microwaves with a politician-style offer of "buy now and pay nine months later".

And forget all those snide claims that the Conservatives are Little Englanders afraid of anything with a hint of overseas - because it's the Tories that offer a travel club with trips to Rome and cruises aboard the Ocean Majesty.

But a political party needs values, and what better value than the Liberal Democrats, who will let you join their party for a bargain basement £5. Never mind the Tories banging on about save the pound: if you sign up with the Lib Dems you'll have saved a tenner.

The party also benefits if you buy books through the online Amazon bookshop, but if you make your purchases using the Liberal Democrat credit card it could be expensive, because the arrangement with the Co-operative Bank is the same as Labour's, which means you'll be paying an illiberal 19.8APR on your purchases - again with a 0.25% of purchases donated to party funds.

And don't expect any poundstretcher deals from the Greens, who charge £19 for membership (£8 unwaged). There's also the intriguing offer of life membership for £247, which if you weren't working would mean you'd have to be a member for 31 years to show a profit. But once you're on the inside with the Greens, you have the pick of party merchandising - polo shirts, sweat shirts, T-shirts (priced £8.50 to £12.75), any colour you like, as long as it's green.

The cheekiest political sales pitch must be the Natural Law Party, which promises: "Donate £100 or more and receive the book, A Reason to Vote, by Robert Roth completely free as a special thank-you." Completely free membership is also available for £15 and a four-hour long "inspiring" party video is yours - completely free - for £17. And if you want to make an unmistakable visual statement about yourself, you could sign up with the UK Independence Party and buy a grey polyester tie, priced £9.99, with a "shadow stripe effect which subtly repeats the words UK Independence Party".

But the real price you have to pay could be much higher. No one likes to admit it, but all political parties have far more than their fair share of misfits and obsessives who find a safe haven in organisations that specialise in dull meetings in community centres and in rooms above pubs around a tray of cement-flavoured sandwiches. So don't expect a bundle of laughs as part of the membership deal.

Altogether now, a spontaneous standing ovation on the count of three...

Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: More potent than petrol
fields.trailText: The vast majority of British people spent the week wondering if their petrol tanks would run dry. But actuaries - the people who find accountancy too exciting - were focused on one thing only; the government's review of occupational pension schemes.
fields.body:
The vast majority of British people spent the week wondering if their petrol tanks would run dry. But actuaries - the people who find accountancy too exciting - were focused on one thing only; the government's review of occupational pension schemes.

Their excitement was not misplaced. The outcome of the review will affect everybody who has a company pension scheme - that's 12.5m people - and will have a critical impact on financial markets, for big and small investors alike. It spells higher costs for employers - they will have to shovel more money into pension schemes because we are all living longer.

It spells a possible sell-off in the gilts market, so if you hold government stock it may fall in value. It suggests a shift to pension funds buying corporate bonds, so if you have invested in a corporate bond Pep or Isa, it's probably good news. And if you are retiring soon and are aghast at the lousy annuity rates on offer, it may mean slightly better returns.

At issue is a complex device called the minimum funding requirement (MFR), which was introduced in the aftermath of Robert Maxwell's £400m raid on the Mirror pension schemes. Well-meaning experts devised the MFR as a way of ensuring that the cash in a pension fund more or less matched its future liabilities to pay out incomes to a company's retired workers.

But as the chairman of the National Association of Pension Funds, Alan Pickering, said this week: "The cure has turned out to be worse than the disease."

The problem with the MFR is that it has effectively forced pension funds into buying ultra-safe government stock - known as gilts - to ensure that their liabilities are fully covered.

At the same time the government, whose coffers have been swelling with the tax receipts of a booming economy, has not been inclined to issue gilts. The result of lots of buyers chasing very little supply is that the price of gilts has been forced up and the yield has been forced down.

The pension funds have been left with a preponderance of low-yielding gilts which offer their investors poor long-term returns compared to investing in shares, or even bonds. They have therefore been clamouring for a new MFR measure that will allow them to value their future liabilities using higher-yielding corporate bonds rather than gilts.

The actuarial profession produced a report, published this week, which says there is no loss of pension security if the funds invest in a basket of corporate bonds rather than gilts. The DSS, which authorises the MFR, is inclined to accept the proposals, but this week said it wants more time for consultation. So what are the implications for your pension and your investments?

Your pension

Watch out for employers who use the new MFR to dump costly final salary pension schemes. Hidden towards the back of the MFR proposals was also an interim recommendation that employers pay higher contributions to cover the fact that people are living longer. The MFR was devised in 1995, but since then new mortality figures suggest that pensioners will on average live two years longer than initially thought.

The DSS and the Institute of Actuaries are therefore proposing that employers increase their contributions by 6.5%, which translates into an extra £700m a year for the next two years and £400m a year thereafter. Employers are already fighting against the increased burden.

The CBI says: "We are concerned about the interim changes proposed by the Institute of Actuaries. Government figures suggest that the price tag will be £2.5bn over the next five years. Companies would strongly oppose implementing the interim changes ahead of a long-overdue review."

One big firm of actuaries which advises companies on their schemes, Punter Southall, warned that companies' resistance to the extra cost will encourage them to switch out of final salary schemes into money purchase schemes, which are widely considered as a second-class deal for pensioners. "It's going to continue to accelerate the switch to money purchase schemes. We support the concept of final salary schemes, but this adds to the cost of what are already expensive schemes."

Your annuity

Many holders of personal pension schemes have been shocked to discover that even if they have saved up a large sum, all it buys at retirement is a small annual income, called an annuity. Ten years ago £100,000 bought an annual income of £11,000 for a 65-year-old. Today it buys around £5,800 a year. Part of the reason for the collapse has been the MFR, because annuity rates are based on the yield on long-dated gilts.

Many are hoping that a revised MFR will boost annuities, as the yield on gilts rises. Earlier this week the yield on 15-year gilts rose from 5.1% to 5.2% in anticipation of the MFR review and analysts believe this move has further to go.

But no analysts are predicting a sudden sharp increase in gilt yields, with some saying that the MFR proposals will not have the impact on yields that many anticipated. So annuities may improve, but only marginally.

Your investments

Corporate bond holders - through funds such as corporate bond Peps and Isas - should be happy. Whereas the City was expecting the MFR review to see a widening of the valuation measure to include triple or double-A grade bonds as well as gilts, the Institute of Actuaries' proposals went further. It recommends that the basket of bonds should include anything that is investment grade, which means bonds rated BBB and above, which make up the majority of bonds held in Peps and Isas.

As pension funds begin to buy more corporate bonds, their prices rise, which means that the capital value of the investment in a corporate bond fund rises. "It's positive for the corporate bond market from a growth perspective, and ultimately from a performance perspective. No one will be selling corporate bonds today," said Barclays Capital after the announcement.

However, there's never a one-way ride in the City. If you hold a long-dated gilt, which can be bought over the counter at Post Offices, or if you inherited War Loan stock or Consols, a switch from gilts to bonds could see their capital value fall marginally.

Finally, there is some speculation that equities will be long-term losers. City analysts were this week suggesting that some pension funds will not only shift out of gilts to bonds, but also out of equities to bonds.

"The market believes that the review seems to be more positive for fixed-income markets at the expense of equities. However, while agreeing with this sentiment, we are not convinced that this will be the final outcome. The government wants people to invest in venture capital, so why would you encourage them away from equities?" said Barclays Capital.

fields.headline: New head for troubled Bhs
fields.standfirst:
Move to brighten up store chain image in lead up to market flotation
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Entrepreneur Philip Green yesterday bolstered the top management of his Bhs retail chain in a move regarded as a precursor to a stock market flotation of the troubled high street group.
fields.body:
Entrepreneur Philip Green yesterday bolstered the top management of his Bhs retail chain in a move regarded as a precursor to a stock market flotation of the troubled high street group.

The appointment of Terry Green to Bhs is expected to mark a radical change in image for the middle-market chain. He left Debenhams as chief executive earlier this week.

City sources said they expect Terry Green to use his experience in the retail industry to take Bhs - once known as British Home Stores - more up market and compete with ailing retailer Marks & Spencer on the high street.

Such a move was regarded yesterday as a way for Philip Green to keep his bid ambitions for M&S alive. The industry remains sceptical about Philip Green's ability to raise the funding, perhaps as much as £10bn, to launch a full scale bid for M&S.

The new but long-rumoured appointment is also regarded by industry experts as evidence of the difficulties Bhs has been facing on the high street since Philip Green bought it from Storehouse for £200m six months ago.

One senior source said: "We expect them to float Bhs on the stock market and turn the company against M&S by using Terry Green's experience to put in designer brands."

After months of speculation that the two men would soon be working together, Philip Green said he was "delighted" to have lured Terry Green, to whom he is not related, to Bhs.

Philip Green acknowledged that Bhs needed a new direction to make more profits. He said the group was making £1bn of sales but that a quarter of its potential retail space was not being used.

In the year to April 1, the period before Philip Green took control, Bhs made an underlying profit of £13.1m. "This appointment shows our serious intent for Bhs to be a leading catalyst in the retail industry," Philip Green said. "Bhs has been suffering from a lack of direction. It's not short of customers. We've got plenty of footfall." He played down any plans to try to raise the financing to bid for M&S, saying "My concentration is on Bhs."

Philip Green, who is based in Monaco, admitted however that a stock market flotation of Bhs might be considered, once the retailer was back on track.

"(The flotation) won't be in the coming months. We do not have a plan today other than to get it back on track. We'll review our position. It's an option. Not the only option."

Amid speculation that Philip Green would eventually take on M&S , he said that he regarded all retailers as competitors. But, he said: "We are going to develop a quality, value proposition. We believe that customers want choice, variety and great value."

Terry Green, who left Debenhams after 12 years this week, said: "I am excited by the Bhs brand and the strength of its customer loyalty, timing is everything thing. Bhs has been snoozing and represents one of the most rewarding challenges in retail today." Terry Green, who had also been cited as a potential candidate to run M&S, is said to have been lured from Debenhams to Bhs on a lucrative incentive package. He led Debenhams through its demerger from the Burtons group.
