fields.headline: A razor in every apple
fields.trailText:
The White Devil
Lyric Hammersmith, London
**
fields.body:
The White Devil
Lyric Hammersmith, London
**

John Webster's brilliant, bloody 1612 revenge tragedy is a poisonous brew of sex, intrigue and moral ambiguity. In Vittoria Corombona there is an exceptionally modern anti-heroine who is condemned not for her crimes but for her sexual appetites. Her brother Flamineo, who pimps her to his boss, the Duke of Brachiano, is a wideboy on the make in a world of dicey employment prospects. In the world of the play, there is a razor blade in every apple. Violence and cruelty are the norm and there are no longer any certainties, except that death will come, sooner rather than later.

Philip Franks's production is mostly intelligent, always clear and accessible, but it only succeeds in being modish, never modern. Part of the problem is the specificity of the setting: the play is transposed from the 16th century to the Rome of Fellini's 1960 film La Dolce Vita. At her trial Vittoria turns up looking like Anita Ekberg; the soon to be unhappy couple celebrate their wedding in a sleazy nightclub. This is all reasonable enough, if not particularly illuminating. But even allowing for the fact that the 20th-century history of the Catholic church is not an honourable one, it stretches credulity to accept the level of church and papal corruption that the text demands.

Other touches are just gimmicky: the dumb show is replaced by home movies of the murders of Vittoria and Brachiano's husband and wife, which put you in mind of those brainless burglars who snap each other with a stolen camera while doing over a house.

Too much of the evening is over-emphatic, particularly Rae Smith's design which strips back the stage to the back wall, has a central image of a crucifix overlaid with a sword and an old rubbish tip in one corner with a bird cage perched on top. The lighting is terrific, and there is much to commend in Sebastian Harcombe's nervy Flamineo and Zoe Waites's Vittoria, an intelligent woman trying to be herself in a world that sees her only as a commodity. But in the end, although Franks offers us the pain of the play, he seldom gets to the heart of its passion or our contemporary passion for it.

Until October 28. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

Other touches are just gimmicky: the dumb show is replaced by home movies of the murders of Vittoria and Brachiano's husband and wife, which put you in mind of those brainless burglars who snap each other with a stolen camera while doing over a house. Too much of the evening is over-emphatic, particularly Rae Smith's design which strips back the stage to the back wall, has a central image of a crucifix overlaid with a sword and an old rubbish tip in one corner with a bird cage perched on top. The lighting is terrific, and there is much to commend in Sebastian Harcombe's nervy Flamineo and Zoe Waites's Vittoria, an intelligent woman trying to be herself in a world that sees her only as a commodity. But in the end, although Franks offers us the pain of the play, he seldom gets to the heart of its passion or our contemporary passion for it. Until October 28. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

fields.headline: Sorry, you don't exist
fields.trailText: Jobs & Money highlights the six major areas where problems repeatedly crop up and how you can challenge the agencies and ensure that your file is corrected.

Are you billed as a villain in the X-files?

Are you a Mr Smith, Jones or Patel? Are you a citizen of a country other than Britain? Is your father, ex-wife or brother a financial wrongdoer? Did the people who lived in your house before you not pay their bills on time? Answer yes to any of these questions and you might be one of the many people who uncover - often too late - that their credit file is seriously blotted.

Last month Jobs & Money highlighted the secretive world of credit scoring - how lenders including banks, department stores and mobile phone companies, score you before deciding to offer you credit. It prompted a large postbag to Jobs & Money, with much of the anger directed at the two credit reference agencies, Experian and Equifax, which dominate the business in the UK.

This week Jobs & Money highlights the six major areas where problems repeatedly crop up and how you can challenge the agencies and ensure that your file is corrected.

Anyone can apply to the agencies for a copy of their file - it costs £2 - but recent surveys have shown that up to one in 10 files contain errors. The errors may not seem X-rated, but they can lead to an embarrassing credit rejection in a store or, at worst, refusal to give you a mortgage.

Your file contains four major types of information. The crucial piece of data is your entry on the electoral roll, as the lack of a ID card system in the UK means the roll is the only way that lenders, especially new telephone and internet-based "remote" companies, can identify whether you are who you say you are.

Secondly, the file details your repay ment history, warning lenders if you have been in arrears or have defaulted on a credit agreement. Thirdly, it holds the details on any county court judgments recorded against you and, fourthly, it tells lenders about the credit history of related parties, such as your family and other credit applicants at the same address.

But it is not Experian or Equifax that accepts or rejects you - it is the lenders which interpret the data and take the decision whether to lend. The good news is that the 1998 Data Protection Act, which comes into force in October next year, will give you more rights to challenge anything held about you - by asking for a "notice of dispute" - and will restrict the automatic right of the agencies to use third-party information.

American? That won't do nicely

You may have lived and worked in Britain for decades, you may even have a wife or husband who is British, but if you don't hold British citizenship you can largely forget about applying for credit.

Several angry Americans and Australians wrote to us about how they are constantly refused credit, even though their financial position is perfectly sound. The problem is the electoral roll; non-British citizens are not on the roll, and therefore almost don't exist as far as the credit reference agencies are concerned. Madonna may live in Britain and go out with Guy Ritchie, but she better not apply for a British credit card.

Lianne Kordan came to Britain in the 60s from the US with her parents, and is constantly discriminated against. Ashley McEwen married an Englishman and works as a senior PA in the film business in London.

Yet her building society rejected her application for a Visa card. She was one of the luckier ones - at least she was told it was because she's not on the electoral roll.

"I pointed out that I was joint-owner of a mortgage and had a long-standing bank account in the UK. Their only attempt at a compromise was to ask me to send two years' worth of bank statements to prove my credit-worthiness. At this point I had had enough and so dropped the enquiry, but the incident still riles me," she says.

Both Experian and Equifax insist that all a non-British citizen has to do is to provide them with proof of identity, which will be added to the file so that lenders will not automatically refuse credit; if they do refuse on this basis alone, it is breaking industry guidelines. But the experience of Jobs & Money readers is that these guidelines are indeed regularly broken.

At Rackhams department store during the January sales the shop assistant convinced Lianne Kordan that she should apply for a storecard to obtain a further 10% discount. But minutes later the assistant returned and gingerly told her: "I'm afraid Madam, we have a slight problem... "

Being rejected for credit is a problem that Ms Kordan has lived with all her life. Her parents, American academics, came to Britain from the US in the 60s in protest at the Vietnam war. But because she has never given up her US citizenship, she is all but invisible to the credit reference agencies which use the electoral roll to confirm anybody's identity. Her problem is not unique; it affects all non-British citizens who live in the UK.

Ms Kordan works in information development for public and higher education authorities, so is no stranger to how databases work. She contacted Experian, which told her to supply evidence of her identity and proof of residency. Experian says: "The existence of such a statement prevents an automatic credit scoring decision being made and means the statement is seen by anybody searching the file in the future. We also notify anyone who has searched the file within the past six months."

Ms Kordan says: "They say this, but it's not what actually happens. You get an operative on the other end of the line who rejects you. They say they do not have the authority to go to that level in my credit file. I tell them they have my permission, but it doesn't make any difference."

Experian says it is "mystified" by Ms Kordan's continued problems. "This consumer's application would, by law, be referred out of any automatic scoring system and referred for a 'manual' decision. She should be dealt with by someone more senior and should definitely appeal against these decisions."

However, Ms Kordan draws little comfort from Experian's assurances. "The problem is that you can't even make it to first base. They're just using a system, the electoral roll, that was never designed to be used as a credit mechanism."

Alias Smith, Jones and Patel

Mr Smith moved into a flat in London five years ago, unaware that another Mr Smith lived in a flat in the same building. Last March he applied for a temporary overdraft from First Direct and was refused, but was recommended to check his file at Experian. Even though he had moved out of the flats 10 months earlier, Experian linked his file to the other Mr Smith, and he suspects this may be why he was refused the overdraft.

"The need for the overdraft has now thankfully passed, but I am pursuing the matter in an effort to find out who is making the decision where. Experian links us to another Smith at our old address although we have requested that they 'disconnect' us. Smithism anyone?" he says.

Experian says that same surnames do cause mix-ups, but plays down how significant the problem is. "Previous occupants with the same surname do occassionally appear to be concurrent because of the vagaries of updating the electoral roll. It is not fair to say this problem is 'quite common' but it can happen, and, if it does and we are advised that no financial connection exists, we will ensure that the connection is severed," says Experian.

Equifax admits that if you have lived in a block with other same surname residents, there is a problem. "If you live in flats with lots of dwellings, it can be a particular problem," says an Equifax spokes-man. His advice? "If you have a common name and have moved recently, get a copy of your file, see who you are associated with, and then ask for a notice of disassociation."

The problem is, most people won't apply for a file until after they have been rejected. In the US, where the credit reference agencies are even more powerful, consumers can pay $20 a year to have their file sent to them every quarter, so they can easily pick up mistakes. But there are no plans to introduce such a system here.

The sins of the fathers

Mark Jenkins (not his real name) was turned down for a Halifax mortgage in January this year, prompting him to check the information held on him at Experian and Equifax. He discovered that there was no way for lenders to distinguish between him and his father, who had run into financial difficulties after an industrial accident.

Mr Jenkins had the same first name, middle initial and surname as his father, plus they had lived at the same address about six years earlier. The obvious way to differentiate between them is by using date of birth - but, surprisingly, neither Experian or Equifax put this on their systems.

"Dates of birth do not form part of the file, so we would not be able to distinguish between two people with exactly the same name at the same address. We would usually ask the consumer to identify which entries belonged to whom," says Experian.

Mr Jenkins did so, and said Experian replied promptly. However, although it deleted his association with his father, Experian then listed his address incorrectly, which caused further delays.

Equifax refused to drop his father from his file unless he submitted both birth certificates. Mr Jenkins did so. A month later, when a copy of his new Equifax file arrived, he found that the agency had deleted not just his father's details, but nearly all of his as well. "My credit reference now consisted of my name and address, hardly conducive to inspiring confidence in mortgage lenders," he says. "The whole ridiculous performance has been extremely frustrating, particularly since house prices have leapt over the past year. I still have no idea whether I will be able to get a mortgage. I would appreciate anything that could be done to force the credit agencies to keep more accurate records."

The agencies say they do their best to keep accurate records, and are forced to do so by Data Protection and Consumer Credit legislation. Mr Jenkins, it appears, may have a strong case for compensation. "We consider requests for compensation on a case by case basis," say the agencies.

Mr Jenkins' case highlights how family connections -known as third party data -can cause significant problems, particulary among estranged partners. Experian says parents, children and ex-wifes or ex-husbands are not forever entwined in a credit file. "We will create disassociations if no financial connections exist. Just ask us."

Denied credit by a false default

One of the more worrying problems encountered by a Jobs & Money reader began after he bought a sofa at Courts Furnishings on a three-month interest free loan. The reader, who wants to remain anonymous, describes himself as a public sector accountant of "boring financial rectitude". He only discovered that Courts had incorrectly registered him as defaulting on the loan when he was turned down for a Nationwide Flex Account.

"I discovered that Courts had registered an eight-rating against the loan, even though it had been settled in full. The payment was by direct debit, but the month after it was cleared a further payment was taken. I contacted them and it was put back into my account. Over the next two years I had repeated demands for the money which, of course, I did not owe, including a notification of proceedings. Each time I phoned and was assured the matter was settled and Courts sent letters of apology. It ceased in 1995. But in 1996 there was a posting to Experian with the eight-rating, indicating that the account was only settled after legal action."

Naturally, he demanded that Experian remove the rating. It refused. "Their response was that they could only act on the instruction of Courts, which I found astonishing."

Experian says: "We would not have 'refused' to remove it. We would have explained that we need first to query the matter with the lender which provided and owned the information. We will and do remove incorrect information. While we do this we mark the data as 'in dispute'. If we fail to satisfy a customer, he or she can complain to the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner who will investigate."

Courts has subsequently apologised and paid the complainant £500 in compensation, and Nationwide has accepted his application. But his alarming experience is a warning about the dangers of using direct debits, and the need to keep meticulous records - and defaults can be registered against you without you ever knowing.

Victims marked as 'fraudsters'

Imagine the shock of another Jobs & Money reader (understandably, he also wishes to remain anonymous) when he saw that his credit file accused him of being a fraudster.

"A warning from credit industry fraud busters 'Cifas' warning appeared on my records alleging that when applying for a Capital One credit card saying I had provided a 'genuine name and address' but had included 'material falsehoods and/or omissions in personal details or other relevant information', " says our reader.

Letters to Cifas and Capital One failed to explain what was wrong with my application in the first place. Capital One's initial tactic was to ignore me, it then moved on to say that it could not 'enter into the specifics of my application.'"

Equifax says Cifas alerts on a file do not indicate that they think you are a fraudster. It may be that a credit card has been stolen and used fraudulently, with the lender posting this information on the system. "It's there to protect lenders and consumers," says an Equifax spokesman.

He says a Cifas alert should not lead to an automatic rejection. Instead, it produces an automatic referral, where the lender is obliged to speak to the organisation that posted the alert.

But the system is far from foolproof. For example, Cifas alerts are attached to addresses rather than individuals, because lenders believe certain addresses are used time and again for making fraudulent applications.

Individuals cannot request to have the alert removed. Experian says that if the Cifas alert is incorrect ("people dealing with fraud prevention tend to be wary of revealing their methodology"), then the consumer should ask Cifas to investigate and make an amendment if necessary.

Where to get help

For a copy of your credit reference agency file, write to Experian, Customer Help Service, PO Box 8000, Nottingham NG1 5GX or Equifax, Dept 1E, PO Box 3001, Glasgow G81 2DT. Enclose a cheque or postal order for £2. The Office of the Data Protection Commissioner can be contacted at 01625 545745 or online at www.dataprotection.gov.uk - its leaflet on credit agencies, No Credit, is available by calling 0870 4421211.

webTitle: End of savings trap in sight for elderly

fields.headline: End of savings trap in sight for elderly
fields.standfirst: The proposed credit regime promises to reward pensioners who save rather than penalising them. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: The government this week pledged to boost the income of pensioners who save for their retirement. Social security secretary Alistair Darling said pensioners on low incomes would be rewarded rather than punished for saving following the introduction of a pension credit.
fields.body:
The government this week pledged to boost the income of pensioners who save for their retirement. Social security secretary Alistair Darling said pensioners on low incomes would be rewarded rather than punished for saving following the introduction of a pension credit.

"Until now, people on low incomes who have some sort of second pension have always lost out. They've been stuck in the savings trap. The Pension Credit won't just remove the penalty for saving: it will create a reward for saving," he said.

The move follows stinging criticism of the government's decision earlier this year to increase the basic pension by just 75p. The rise, linked to inflation, was widely condemned as derisory in a period of strong growth in earnings. At the TUC conference this week union leaders added to the government's woes with attacks on its treatment of pensioners.

But the announcement of a pensions credit failed to dampen the feeling among unions or pensioners' groups that the government has neglected the elderly. They gave the credit only a lukewarm welcome, saying the govern ment had failed to say how much it would be worth. They also said the credit would complicate a benefits system already weighed down by complex rules.

At the moment the government calculates that a pensioner's savings provide an income - whether they do or not - and applies an interest rate to the sum. The interest income, along with any payments from an occupational pension, are taken out of the benefits a pensioner receives as part of the government's minimum income guarantee.

The guarantee pays income support to top up a single pensioner's income from £67.50 to £78.45 per week and from £108.10 to £121.95 for a married couple.

Pensioners who miss out on the top up after other income is taken into account will benefit from the credit, though by how much will not be known until consultation papers appear later this year.

Mr Darling made it clear that richer pensioners hoping to cash in would be disappointed. Pensioners like Victor Meldrew of One Foot in the Grave fame are more the target audience than the elderly gentlemen featured in the current hit film Space Cowboys, featuring the geriatric yet extremely wealthy Clint Eastwood and Donald Sutherland.

Only pensioners with incomes hovering around the level of the guarantee are likely to be affected. The guarantee is expected to rise to £100 at the next budget, limiting the credit to incomes of about £120.

Mervyn Kohler, head of public affairs at Help the Aged, said the government had addressed an important issue but left people guessing about the effect of its policy. "The state pension will still be paid to everyone, but will not add up to much and most pensioners on low to middle incomes will rely on a trade-off between the guarantee and savings incomes and they don't know yet how that trade-off will work. What it does tell middle England is that they can save for their retirement without a means test taking it all away."

But Mr Kohler believes the proposals contain some contradictions. "The government says [the credit] will make life easier for people. Yet it means that anyone with any savings will need fill in more forms to tell the government how much they have, which will only increase bureaucracy."

One source of pension income in the future will be the government's stakeholder pension. Stakeholder pensions limit the charges imposed by investment companies and introduce greater flexibility into the pension regime. They are targeted at people on low to middle incomes who want to save anything from £10 a month upwards.

Ministers were concerned that only a few people would take up the scheme if the small but significant sums saved through stakeholder were deducted from benefits. A stakeholder pension that pays £50 a week could be less than the benefits that make up the minimum guarantee in the future. The pension credit is designed to make saving even small sums of money in a stakeholder pension worthwhile.

The Association of British Insurers said its members were pleased that the government wanted to reduce the disincentive to save for those around the threshold for means-tested benefits."People who faced the prospect of of losing state benefits if they contributed to a stakeholder pension, for example, will now have every incentive to save."

The TUC has matched the government's pension credit plan with the launch of its own stakeholder pension at its annual conference in Glasgow. The union body said it had joined forces with the Prudential and Standard Life to offer the pension next April to 6m union members.

It plans to target the half a million members without access to an occupational pension scheme and the 5.5m members with incomes under £30,000 who could use a stakeholder pension as a top up to their existing pension, though all members and non-members alike will be able to sign up.

Under the stakeholder scheme charges are limited to 1%, but the TUC said the huge potential membership had allowed it to keep the management fee to 0.85%.

John Monks, TUC general secretary, said: "Our comprehensive range of benefits, with the competitive price, makes it one of the best value packages around."

webTitle: Instead of grandeur we get Little England

fields.headline: Instead of grandeur we get Little England
fields.standfirst: In the first of a weekly series, the head of a leading stock exchange shareholder laments lost opportunity
fields.trailText: In the first of a weekly series, the head of a leading stock exchange shareholder laments lost opportunity
fields.body:
In a matter of months Britain might no longer have a stock exchange to call its own. In a financial world without borders this may be of little consequence. But try telling that to the gaggle of Little Englanders who postured to oust the London Stock Exchange's management this week.

The recent history of the exchange is a sorry tale of insularity and inertia. The combination of the most blue chip brand name and the technology revolution presented the opportunity to corner the market in European equity trading. As it is, the exchange now finds itself in a corner, crowded by a hostile bid and an even more hostile shareholder base.

Thursday's annual meeting provided a forum for shareholders to air the best part of 20 years worth of accumulated frustrations. The exchange's chief executive, Gavin Casey, was invited to fall on his sword (and yesterday did so). Its recently appointed chairman, Don Cruikshank, was reminded that he is on probation. The curriculum vitae of both were held up to scornful scrutiny.

Kept their own counsel

Little, if anything, was ever going to be achieved in this forum. The exchange already had a very clear idea of the views of its shareholders and customers - it had called off its proposed merger with Deutsche Börse as a result. The exchange's biggest users - the global investment banks - unsurprisingly kept their own counsel while in public.

This is the moment of maximum leverage for Britain's smallest broking houses, particularly those specialising in private client business.

A sale of the London exchange, or a merger, requires a 75% voting majority, and votes are distributed much more widely than the concentration of business transacted on the market from day to day.

In 1999, British private clients accounted for more than 50% of UK equity bargains transacted on the London exchange. However, in aggregate these represented only 10% of the total value of UK equity business. British institutions, on the other hand, accounted for a third of bargains but two-thirds of total transaction value.

Power typically resides with those handling the institutional business. Look at the composition of the committees of users the London exchange relies on for feedback and you will instantly understand the frustrations of smaller brokers. They bear all the worst hallmarks of a gentlemen's club.

The LSE would be wrong to lean too far towards its smaller shareholders, however tempting this must be during this time of siege. The Little Englanders offer few solutions to the strategic problem facing all European exchanges: how to harness new technology to fight off the challenge posed by alternative "virtual" exchanges.

The major investment banks are, in principle, proponents of mergers between stock markets. Even small reductions in transaction costs as a result of merger synergies would have enormous benefits for their bottom line profitability. If only the LSE's plan to merge with Frankfurt had not been so half-baked. Perhaps it was a consequence of relying on the gentlemen's club, Schroders and Merrill Lynch providing the advice. Whatever the reasons, the exchange has jeopardised its support from its biggest customers.

Were it under strong management, the exchange would be in a position to drive the consolidation of European stock markets. After all, it is the largest, most liquid, and has the greatest reputation for probity. Under crippled management, though, it has become a (valuable) pawn in a game controlled by other players.

Light on cash

The one bid on the table for the exchange is from Sweden's OM Gruppen, which already operates 10 markets around the world and provides the technology for many others. OM has been welcomed for busting apart the London-Frankfurt merger but is given little chance of ultimate success.

It would be foolish, however, to dismiss OM's chances out of hand. Its bid is admittedly light on cash and heavy on OM shares, whose valuation appears unsustainably high. But few hostile takeovers are ever settled on the first bid.

Earlier this week I had the opportunity to hear OM's case first hand. Its management presented an argument clearly tailored to allay the fears of the rank and file of Britain's broking community: commercial management of a technology-rich, London-centric European exchange. In essence, an alliance of London's brand and OM's expertise.

It was difficult to fault OM's logic, but for me something was missing - a sense of grandeur befitting London's history. This may sound pompous. It may sound very 19th century. But it reflects the scale of opportunity now available to those who dare to dream.

For OM to succeed it needs to convince the global investment banks - not be cause they control the London exchange's share register but because their financial muscle behind a revised OM bid could "buy" the approval of the smaller brokers.

To corral the global players, OM must, of course, convince that it has the management and the expertise to execute its plans.

But, over and above that, it must demonstrate that a takeover of the LSE is but the first step towards a much, much bigger network of exchanges.

There is unlikely to be room in Europe for more than two big networks. London dare not be left out in the cold but then neither can Frankfurt, Paris, Milan - or indeed Stockholm in the shape of OM Gruppen itself. No player can be underestimated, for each lives in fear of the abyss beneath its feet. Most of the Europeans will concede national control in order to secure a seat at the table.

Artificial division

It is no surprise, however, that nationalistic issues loom large in Britain, Germany and France. The iX proposal was a political compromise reflecting these sensitivities - an artificial division of labour between London and Frankfurt with no room for the French.

London's reputation as a financial centre is such that it should sell itself dearly. But it should also trust its ability to win through regardless of the LSE's ultimate fate.

Those left out in the cold will be those with least to offer or those blinded by their own parochialism. London is not the former, but risks becoming the latter.

For the London exchange's current management it is probably too late. But they could attempt a small first step on the long road to rehabilitation by initiating an open-minded dialogue with all possible partners, OM included.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: Hold the back pages
fields.trailText:
Bob Dylan
Vicar St, Dublin
*****
fields.body:
Bob Dylan
Vicar St, Dublin
*****

The 800 tickets for this suddenly announced "intimate" show supposedly sold out in 15 seconds. For the select multitude, then, this was a night of almost impossibly high expectation, but Bob Dylan, for a long time now the most erratic of live performers, did not disappoint. Shuffling on stage in natty black suit and the coolest cowboy boots this side of a Sam Shephard play - white snakeskin with black toes and heels - he looked stick-thin and frail, slightly lost. Up close, you could catch every nervous fidget, every Chaplinesque shuffle and bemused shrug. He looked like a broken marionette, and, when the lights dimmed, like a ghostly silhouette of his iconic mid-60s self.

Flanked by four sidemen who looked as though they had stumbled out of a high-class Tijuana brothel, he ranged through his back pages for nigh-on two hours, by turns baffling and transfixing. To Ramona and Tomorrow Is a Long Time were taken at a shuffle, his voice sounding rusted but powerful. Tangled Up in Blue became a defiant howl of survival; Maggie's Farm a clattering, ragged thing of beauty as Charlie Sexton traded bluesy guitar licks with a suddenly focused Dylan.

A characteristically perverse reading of Just Like a Woman, the melody bent out of shape, soon derailed the crowd's attempt at singing along. Then he rearranged Girl from the North Country into an achingly regretful Spanish waltz, holding the entire crowd spellbound. When you thought it couldn't get any better, the group tore into a majestic Like a Rolling Stone, the song that most of the faithful had been secretly praying for all night. With the audience howling the chorus back at the stage, the song caught fire, sounding as close to the "wild mercury sound" of the original as it has in years.

Somewhere, during a prolonged encore, he revisited Highway 61 at breakneck speed and turned Blowing in the Wind into a stoical, world weary conversation with himself. And there, in essence, was the transformative power of Bob Dylan's art in motion: his ability to tease new meanings, nuances, possibilities from songs that have long since lodged in our collective consciousness. At close range, that alchemy was tangible, mesmerising, reaffirmative. It was Bob Dylan, reborn yet again.

Tonight at Conference Centre, Aberdeen (01224 824824), then on tour.

fields.headline: Barmby sucks the wind from Rapid sails
fields.standfirst:
Barmby 29
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Nick Barmby's first senior goal for Liverpool capped the sort of untroubled stroll so beloved of past, more illustrious, Liverpool teams on an evening when the third best team in Bucharest was no real match for the fourth best team in the Premiership.
fields.byline: Ian Ross at the Giulesti Stadium
fields.body:
Nick Barmby's first senior goal for Liverpool capped the sort of untroubled stroll so beloved of past, more illustrious, Liverpool teams on an evening when the third best team in Bucharest was no real match for the fourth best team in the Premiership.

From a romantic perspective the Giulesti stadium could, at a push, be described as quaint, a rather shabby reminder of those not too far distant days when the lumpen proletariat of a suppressed nation had little option but to compliantly embrace mediocrity.

Liverpool remain as popular as ever behind the now parted Iron Curtain but not popular enough to draw out a full house into the steaming tail end of a savagely hot day. An impoverished club's decision to quadruple the normal admission price was, predictably, an act of foolish avarice.

The Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier resisted, comfortably he was to later insist, the temptation to use just one forward; the objective was to win and win they did.

En route to dampening Rapid's ardour, there was much to concern Houllier but he was understandably pleased with the outcome: "It was not easy but this was a most satisfying nights work. We produced a highly professional performance when we needed one. I took a risk by playing an offensive side but everything worked out for us in the end."

Initially at least, the Liverpool defence creaked like a barn door - an open one. The main cause for concern was Christian Ziege's wanderlust on his first start since his arrival from Middlesbrough.

Seemingly only prepared to play at left back when his team was in possession, the German's lack of discipline was constantly exploited - if not fully punished - by Marius Maldarasanu.

Barmby had already struck the face of a post before in the 29th minute he benefited handsomely from the speed, skill and awareness of Michael Owen. He was not the first to so do and he will not be the last.

Owen laid waste to the entire Rapid defence by sprinting clear down the left and cutting inside the penalty area. Fleetingly, he shaped as if to shoot but instead dipped a shoulder before rolling the ball into the path of Barmby, who marked his first ever appearance in a European tie with the sweetest of rising shots.

The goal sucked the wind from Romanian sails and with Didier Hamann and Bernard Diomede dominant in midfield, Liverpool began to punch holes in a tiring defence. Westerveld's perceived weakness in the air was never truly examined and only in a brief period midway through a pedestrian second half did they hint at a recovery.

Even then the better of the openings continued to fall to the feet of Houllier's men and Owen will have been disappointed to strike only the body of goalkeeper Razvan Lucescu after nice work by Barmby.

The substitute Danny Murphy and Owen, again, went close to underscoring Liverpool's superiority but the gulf between the sides was so evident that their profligacy was annoying rather than crucial.

Rapid Bucharest (3-5-2): Lucescu; Mutica, Stanciu, Iencsi; Buta (Schumacher, 45min), Maldarasanu, Isaila, Iftodi (Buga, 73), Frasineanu; Pancu, Constantin (Radu, 60).

Liverpool (4-4-2): Westerveld; Song, Babbel, Henchoz, Ziege (Traore, 85); Barmby, Carragher, Hamann, Diomede; Heskey (Murphy, 35), Owen (Fowler, 80).

Referee: N Volquartz (Denmark).

webTitle: Ron Atkinson on the sacking of Vialli

fields.headline: The sacrifice of Vialli is a sign of increasing player-power
fields.trailText: Alienated from the players? I'd have thought Ken Bates would have been pleased to know his manager wasn't one of the boys any more and was turning a bit nasty. Chelsea should have stood by him.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli has good reason to feel he got a very raw deal. For a start he was sacked by Chelsea after winning as many trophies in 2 seasons as Sir Alex Ferguson collected in his first six at Old Trafford. On top of that he seems to be another victim of player power.

Internal rumblings apparently had a big role in bringing down Egil Olsen at Wimbledon, John Barnes at Celtic and Ruud Gullit first at Stamford Bridge and then at Newcastle. Now we are led to understand that Chelsea's squad have got rid of their second manager in three years.

Vialli is said to have lost the backing of some players and there have been comments to undermine him. But I thought his remark that he was disappointed in Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson for lacking "confidence in his conduct" said a lot.

Clubs have been complaining that players have too much power and Chelsea had a great opportunity to make a stand. It was a chance for strong management to come into play from their hierarchy, supporting Vialli to the hilt.

Instead the sacking helps to increase players' sway and sense of strength. There will be things we don't know; there always are. But if Vialli had a problem and the board felt the players were getting a bit uppity I think they should say: "Hang on, he's our manager and we'll back him."

The fact is that Vialli is the most successful manager in Chelsea's history and could easily have gone on to win a championship there.

Every manager has dressing-room problems of one sort or another. When I was in a rough patch at Manchester United there was a big punch-up between Jesper Olsen and Remi Moses, and players will often talk. They'll look for any cop-out when they should be looking at themselves and will magnify things to suit their agenda.

When Frank Leboeuf made his comments about Vialli having problems with everyone, maybe Vialli should have got hold of him and said: "If you don't want to play for us I'll stick you in the screaming room." But it was remarks by Didier Deschamps which really amused me.

He said Vialli wasn't the man he had known as a player. Well of course he wasn't. And I'd have thought Ken Bates would have been pleased to know his manager wasn't one of the boys any more and was turning a bit nasty.

It's been suggested Vialli's treatment of Gianfranco Zola helped to unseat him but as a manager you make decisions for everyone and inevitably sometimes they're unpopular with individuals.

The players should realise that their responsibility is to give their utmost on the field and stop wittering. There will be some at United who aren't happy about what's happened to Mark Bosnich but they have to get on with it.

Strong leadership from the manager and the board can deal with problems, so I don't believe players have complete power. But the fact that they are paid enormous wages makes it far harder to discipline them.

At one time if someone stepped out of line a club could hit him hard in the pocket and the impact would be felt. Now, with people on £30,000 a week, docking two weeks' wages is not a matter of life and death.

I think what Chelsea need is a manager in Ferguson's mould, with a no-nonsense approach. A few of the foreign players in particular have used the press to air their grievances, and a bit of discipline seems to be lacking.

But what the club must guarantee is that their new man has extensive experience and good English. I would rule out two candidates: Frank Rijkaard needs to learn his trade at club level in the Netherlands, and Dino Zoff speaks little English.

Neither has Jose Camacho impressed me with Spain. Terry Venables looks a good choice, as does Sven Goran Eriksson, but would Eriksson really want to leave Lazio?

Whoever gets the job will be taking over from a good man. Let's not forget that Vialli won more trophies - five - at Chelsea than Arsène Wenger has with Arsenal and went further in the Champions League.

People say Vialli failed in the Premiership, but bigger clubs than Chelsea have failed as well. All it needed was a couple of wins to turn his season. If Gérard Houllier does as well in even his next 2 years at Liverpool, I somehow don't think he'll be sacked.

webTitle: Champions League: De Boer slates 'mean' Smith

fields.headline: De Boer slates 'mean' Smith
fields.trailText: Leeds United's best efforts to paint an image of Alan Smith as a reformed character were dealt a significant blow yesterday when the striker was castigated by Barcelona's Frank de Boer for his "mean and unacceptable" behaviour.
fields.body:
Leeds United's best efforts to paint an image of Alan Smith as a reformed character were dealt a significant blow yesterday when the striker was castigated by Barcelona's Frank de Boer for his "mean and unacceptable" behaviour.

Smith's talent for courting controversy resurfaced during Wednesday's 4-0 Champions League defeat at the Nou Camp when he infuriated the Catalan club with some reckless challenges.

One lunge forced the Dutch international Philip Cocu out of the game and the talented but temperamental teenager could not have complained had he received a red card.

"Smith was far too aggressive. He was mean and I don't like that," said De Boer. "You can play hard but what he did was totally unacceptable.

"Whenever the ball was gone Smith went on to hit the opponent's legs. He should have been sent off for the foul on Cocu and there were others too. If he's going to become a top player he has to calm down and grow up. That is not the way to play."

The Leeds captain Lucas Radebe is doubtful for tomorrow's match against Ipswich at Elland Road even though x-rays revealed that the neck injury he sustained against Barcelona is nothing more serious than bruising.

 Football north and south of the border appears to have beaten the fuel crisis, with both the English and Scottish Premier Leagues giving the green light to this weekend's fixtures.

Early concerns that Newcastle would be unable to play their match with Southampton at the Dell appear to have been unfounded and the decision of the protesters to abandon their blockades should ease the problem further.

 Roberto Baggio, now 33 and out of contract at Internazionale, has signed a two-year contract with the newly promoted Serie A club Brescia.

fields.headline: Panucci eases Blues backlash
fields.standfirst: Panucci 22
fields.trailText: Chelsea looked like a team with other things on their mind last night as they struggled to beat the champions of Switzerland. But the recriminations were few. As soon as the final whistle sounded the club's thoughts returned to the rest of Europe where they hope to find a manager to lead them to greater glories than competing in the Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
Chelsea looked like a team with other things on their mind last night as they struggled to beat the champions of Switzerland. But the recriminations were few. As soon as the final whistle sounded the club's thoughts returned to the rest of Europe where they hope to find a manager to lead them to greater glories than competing in the Uefa Cup.

By a process of elimination and the injection of common-sense into the proceedings - the presence of George Graham, Terry Venables and John Gregory in the succession speculation had threatened to turn it into a joke - the leading contender now appears to be Frank Rijkaard.

When asked yesterday if he was interested in replacing Gianluca Vialli or had been in touch with Chelsea, the normally forthcoming Rijkaard was unusually diplomatic - "I don't comment on my connections with a club until the deal is done."

It was interpreted by those who know him as signifying that something is afoot.

Rijkaard is very highly thought of. Although he resigned as Holland coach after they failed to win Euro 2000 on home soil, 92 per cent in a Dutch poll shortly afterwards thought he should not have fallen on his sword, while 87 per cent rated him the best coach in the championship.

Even the media were impressed with the way he dealt with them and, though Rijkaard has coached only at international level, a host of top European clubs have filed his name for future use.

Last night Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates was giving no clues, apart from definitely ruling out Venables and Graham, and reiterating the view that "we will not be hurried into a decision" on a new manager.

As for his decision to sack Vialli, Bates acknowledged he was the most successful manager in Chelsea history, that he was "a true gentleman" and that sacking him "was the most difficult and distressing action I have ever had to take".

For their part the Chelsea fans in last night's far-from-capacity crowd blamed Vialli's sacking on Frank Leboeuf, booing the Frenchman's first touch of the ball, presumably because of his recent revelation that "everybody has problems with Vialli".

The task of picking up the pieces fell to the caretaker manager Graham Rix. Trying to pull the players' thoughts away from the managerial hubbub on to a game against a small-town side must have been difficult. But Rix took the bull by the horns, fielding three strikers and giving the midfielder Sam dalla Bona his first start.

St Gallen, Swiss champions for the first time since 1904, may be a backwater club playing in Europe for the first time since 1985, but they only narrowly lost to Galatasaray, the defending Uefa Cup holders, in the qualifying round.

The fact that Chelsea were playing in the Uefa Cup for the first time rather than duelling in the lucrative Champions League, as they did last season, was a factor in Vialli's downfall. But the players began the game eagerly. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, twice, and Tore Andre Flo went close before Christian Panucci put Chelsea ahead after 22 minutes.

A great ball from Dennis Wise found him in the area and the Italian defender saw his shot cannon off the keeper and loop over the line. It was his first Chelsea goal.

However, St Gallen had done enough to warn Chelsea against complacency. Pereirs Guido forced a diving save from Carlo Cudicini on nine minutes and Jerren Nixon shot just wide on 34.

Swiss hopes were raised further at the start of the second half as Chelsea started giving the ball away with alarming regularity. St Gallen could not capitalise and the first chance fell to the home side when the defender Daniel Imhof nearly headed past his own goal keeper.

But Chelsea wore an increasingly subdued look. The events of the week semed to be taking their toll and shouts of "Vialli, Vialli" ringing around the ground did not help. On this showing, Chelsea need a new manager as soon as possible.

Chelsea (4-3-3): Cudicini; Panucci, Leboeuf, Desailly, Le Saux; Di Matteo, Wise, Dalla Bona; Flo, Hasselbaink, Zola.

St Gallen (4-4-2): Astiel; Zellweger, Imhof, Zwyssig, Dal Santo; Winkler, Mueller, Guido, Nixon; Jairo, Amoah.

Referee: V Torres (Spain).

fields.headline: Larsson locks on to target but Helsinki keep their hair on
fields.standfirst: Larsson 14, 25
fields.trailText: After a bright start, Celtic made heavy weather of beating a Finnish team who from the outset had looked inferior but were soon allowed to appear quite accomplished. On a night when a minor throng of 40,000 should have been allowed to bay with delight, they ended up growling with disdain.
fields.body:
After a bright start, Celtic made heavy weather of beating a Finnish team who from the outset had looked inferior but were soon allowed to appear quite accomplished. On a night when a minor throng of 40,000 should have been allowed to bay with delight, they ended up growling with disdain.

It was another occasion when Eyal Berkovic had a mere walk-on role for Celtic, the Israeli getting 15 minutes as a substitute for Lubomir Moravcik, once more fuelling rumours that he will shortly leave the club.

Celtic's start under Martin O'Neill this season has resem bled no other in living memory, though the new manager still faces a tall order, and it is 20 years since Celtic last survived in Europe beyond Christmas.

At present there is no lovelier sight at Parkhead than the hair-band, a remark no one would have got away with in the hard days under Jock Stein.

The piece of equipment used by Henrik Larsson to control his flying locks had never been a Glasgow favourite before, but big men today who follow Celtic are almost tempted to wear it in the street, so symbolic is it of goals.

Larsson, his foliage firmly strapped down, hit two first-half goals, and kept poking away at the Finns with menace. Larsson's first, a sweet header from Jackie McNamara's cross after 14 minutes, left the Helsinki goalkeeper Jani Viander without hope. The Swede's second 10 minutes later was an adept chip over Viander following Chris Sutton's clever pass.

Having started so well, Celtic allowed complacency to set in, and the Finns found spaces in which to express their wiles. They were not devoid of tricks.

Rafael, their trumpeted Brazilian, had already caused Jonathan Gould to parry a shot, and only McNamara's blunt challenge on Janne Saarinen prevented Helsinki from snatching a goal.

Celtic, indeed, became rather flustered in the second half. None of it did O'Neill's calm demeanour any good.

 Hearts rode their luck in Stuttgart at times but produced a gritty defensive display and the Germans - fresh from beating Bayern Munich at the weekend - could manage only a 1-0 first-leg win. Stuttgart's 35th-minute goal came via a clever floated free-kick by their Bulgarian international Krassimir Balakov.

Celtic (3-5-2): Gould; Mjallby, Boyd, Valgaeren; McNamara, Lambert, Moravcik (Berkovic, 75min), Petrov, Mahe (Healy, 51); Sutton, Larsson.

HJK Helsinki: (3-5-2): Viander; Turpeinen, Kuivasto, Heikkinen; Yeremenko, Hakanpaa, Nylund, Yla-Jussila (Paulus, 60), Saarinen; Kaliio, Rafael.

Referee: D Drabek (Austria).

fields.headline: Red faces and silver medal for red rose
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 324
Surrey 297-9
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText: This should have been a good day for Lancashire as they clinched second place in the championship for the third year running, their best spell since 1928-30. However, it ended in an embarrassing farce as play was twice stopped by the glare of the sun off the roof of the new media centre at the Stretford end.
fields.body:
This should have been a good day for Lancashire as they clinched second place in the championship for the third year running, their best spell since 1928-30. However, it ended in an embarrassing farce as play was twice stopped by the glare of the sun off the roof of the new media centre at the Stretford end.

It is not the first time the low September sun has caused problems here, where the square is east-west. But when a game against Kent almost exactly a year ago was similarly affected, Lancashire promised to cover the roof. They bought some big black sheets, but yesterday afternoon there was no one on the ground to put them up.

Fortunately there were clouds about, limiting the stoppages to a total of 25 minutes, allowing Martin Bicknell and Saqlain Mushtaq to extend their last-wicket stand to 54 and bring Surrey within 27 of Lancashire's first-innings total. That was quite a recovery after the newly crowned champions slipped to 111 for five at lunch, still 64 short of the follow-on.

Adam Hollioake started like a train with 49 from 39 balls but was left with his meagre season's tally of three championship half-centuries when he was bowled driving at Mike Smethurst. Ian Ward then edged Glen Chapple to Warren Hegg, and Ally Brown drove Chris Schofield to cover in the last over before lunch.

Schofield picked up the next three wickets too. He had Jon Batty caught at slip off a leg-spinner which turned and bounced - this wicket gave Lancashire a second bowling point and the £50,000 runners-up cheque - then Ian Salisbury, the leggie preferred for the winter tours of Pakistan and Sri Lanka, caught behind, and Alex Tudor lbw to a long hop.

But Gary Butcher justified his selection ahead of Ben Hollioake with an impressively patient 66, including 10 boundaries, and a share in two partnerships of 50.

Butcher had been missed in single figures, one of two slip chances that went down before lunch while Mike Atherton spent the day grazing stiffly in the outfield. On a pitch which has already offered considerable turn and variable bounce, those drops may cost Lancashire the win they covet over the champions.

 Hampshire's left-arm seamer Alan Mullally has ruled himself out of England's plans for the ICC Trophy in Kenya next month after again breaking a rib in a sneezing fit. He has been plagued by rib problems after suffering the same injury on last winter's tour of South Africa.

fields.headline: Umpires put Wagh on action stations
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 400-8 dec
Essex 208-5
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 400-8 dec Essex 208-5
fields.body:
Warwickshire 400-8 dec Essex 208-5

Mark Wagh's bowling action will be put under the microscope by the England and Wales Cricket Board after he was "warned off" by the umpires John Hampshire and Barry Dudleston.

After completing one over of off-spin costing four runs, Wagh was withdrawn from the attack after the umpires conferred and called the captain Neil Smith into the discussion. The umpires expressed doubts about the legality of Wagh's action and Smith voluntarily took him off. Lord's was contacted during the tea interval and it is now up to the ECB to make a judgment.

Wagh was no doubt left reflecting how much fortunes can change in 24 hours. A day earlier he had scored a career-best 137 which culminated in the award of his county cap.

Yesterday, in this promotion battle, it was the turn of Darren Robinson to impose himself with the bat. With some justification it can be truly said that he has had an "in and out" career since making his Essex debut eight seasons ago.

It was believed that the retirement in 1997 of Graham Gooch, in whose shadow he tried to make progress in the early years, would see him grasp the opportunity to make more use of his talent. But centuries have been rare and yesterday he was denied one when he turned Smith's off-spin into the hands of backward short-leg.

Nevertheless he can console himself that his 92 was full of character and value. He arrived after Paul Prichard, half forward, was removed lbw by Charles Dagnall without a run on the board, and then watched Paul Grayson and Stuart Law fall cheaply, the latter to a magnificent one-handed catch by Trevor Penney at cover.

That left Essex in some disarray at 63 for three and Warwickshire's 400 for eight declared must have seemed on the distant horizon. Robinson, however, was to restore sanity to the Essex innings against an attack lacking Allan Donald, Ed Giddins and Ashley Giles.

The skipper Ronnie Irani was the other major contributor. He passed 50 for the ninth time this season in a championship match and is due to resume this morning on 72 when Essex's immediate aim will be to gather the additional 43 runs required to avoid being asked to follow on.

webTitle: Two Halves of a Zodiac Coin at the BBC

fields.headline: Two Halves of a Zodiac Coin at the BBC
fields.trailText: Peter Salmon and Lorraine Heggessey. A compelling symmetry emerges as the mantle of BBC1 controller passes from Taurus Peter Salmon (May 15 1956) to Scorpio Lorraine Heggessey (November 16 1956).
fields.body:
Peter Salmon and Lorraine Heggessey. A compelling symmetry emerges as the mantle of BBC1 controller passes from Taurus Peter Salmon (May 15 1956) to Scorpio Lorraine Heggessey (November 16 1956).

Born six months from each other, their suns are in exact opposition, 180 degrees apart. The job change is marked by Saturn triggering this opposition from June until next spring, yoking together their destinies at the BBC.

Peter Salmon seems fated to do the hard bits, with his money-conscious Taurus sun opposed by Saturn at birth, a symbol of limitation. He has been a safe pair of hands during a cash-starved era, and it is ironic that just as Greg Dyke, another Taurean, finally delivers more booty, Salmon won't get to spend it.

Now he is off to Sports, where the BBC is chronically unable to compete with cash-rich commercial channels. Even so, he should be happier because his unexpressed Jupiterian creativity can loosen up and play games with the BBC's sporty Sagittarian planets.

Heggessey has strong links with two of the principal horoscopes for the BBC. Its Capricorn Royal Charter (January 1 1927) has Saturn conjunct the Moon. Heggessey, born on its first 29-year Saturn cycle, is fittingly symbolised as the first woman (Moon) controller (Saturn).

The horoscope for BBC television, timed for the first public broadcast (3pm, November 2 1936), shows it as a Scorpio. Heggessey has immediate affinity here, with all the tough, determined and transformative energy of the Scorpion, more daring than her Taurus opposite number.

Mark Thompson, director of television, describes her "tremendous energy and fierce commitment", and Heggessey's aggressive Mars is placed exactly on the Ascendant of this BBC TV horoscope.

The rationale of her appointment is for her to go in like the SAS in the ratings war. Little wonder she likes Warriors. When she combines her sex, death and secrets Scorpio instincts with the clinical Virgo in her horoscope, we see Animal Hospital, The Human Body and Biteback. Scorpio may also tempt her into controversy. Her stint as producer of The Underworld, interviewing Mad Frankie Fraser, shows the Plutonic side of her Scorpio colours, but this type of programming may prove too near-the-edge for primetime television. Mars often brings trouble in its train, and although things may be rosy between her and Dyke at present, the contacts in their charts are oppositions, suggesting divergences of opinion when the honeymoon is over.

Because this job comes under humourless Saturn, despite all her talent and energy, Heggessey should be prepared for the same flattening influence felt by Peter Salmon. She carries the BBC's burden of being a public service broadcaster in competition with commercial genre channels. Apart from slugging it out in the ratings war, with Heggessey leading from the front, the unanswered question remains: what is the BBC for?

webTitle: Breast screening success falls well below target

fields.headline: Breast screening success falls well below target
fields.standfirst: Controversy over screening programme will continue
fields.trailText: The national breast cancer screening programme has saved lives but nowhere near the target number set down by the Department of Health in 1992, according to the first major assessment of its performance.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The national breast cancer screening programme has saved lives but nowhere near the target number set down by the Department of Health in 1992, according to the first major assessment of its performance.

The study, in the British Medical Journal, will not put an end to the controversy that has periodically surfaced over the cost-effectiveness of breast screening. It found that death rates dropped by 21.3% between 1990 and 1998 but that screening was responsible for only a 6.4% reduction, against a target for 2000 of 25%.

Better treatment - epecially the drug tamoxifen - and women's greater awareness of breast irregularities, causing them to seek treatment earlier, accounted for the remaining 14.9% decline in deaths.

The research was greeted by the co-ordinator of the national screening programme, Julietta Patnick, as a resounding endorsement of the programme. It "proves that the breast screening programme saves women's lives" and "confirms that we are on the way to a 25% reduction in mortality from breast cancer. We are confident that we will reach our target."

But critics of the programme will say that the money would be better spent on treatment than on detection of cancer.

Roger Blanks, an epidemiologist at the Institute of Cancer Research, and colleagues, who carried out the study, said the full benefits of screening had not yet been felt. Only from 1995 were all women aged 55-69 invited to come for screening, and some who died would have been diagnosed with cancer before they were ever invited to be screened.

"We don't think it is a final answer," said one of the authors, Sue Moss, associate director of the cancer screening evaluation unit at the institute. "We would expect to see a further effect in the next five years or so. We know cancer detection has improved, particularly as a result of introducing double viewing."

Double-view mammography, where the breast is seen from two angles, was originally restricted to a first visit but is to be extended to every examination.

Ms Patnick said better screening was allowing more cancers to be detected earlier, before they could be felt by hand. "This makes less drastic treatment possible, and gives women a greater chance of survival."

She believed the full effect of the programme would be discernible by 2010, when she expected a halving of the death rate in women aged 55-69 from that of 1990, thanks to screening and better treatment.

In 1997-98 the programme detected 7,932 cancers, an increase of 11% on 1996-97.

But screening has not lived up to the huge expectations at its introduction in 1988. The Forrest committee, which proposed it, based its recommendations on the results of randomised controlled trials in Sweden. These showed that screening could reduce death rates in women aged 50 and over by 25-30% over 10 years.

The BMJ report argued that the Swedish trial and the programme in England and Wales were not strictly comparable. In Sweden women diagnosed with breast cancer before they were enrolled in the screening trial were excluded from the results. There was also a big learning curve involved for medical staff when a national programme was rolled out.

The authors concluded: "Our research indicates that for 1990-98 improvements in treatment and screening both probably have major roles in the reduction in mortality."

Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, was confident that the number of lives saved by screening would continue to rise sharply, due to action to ensure the programme's quality, the increased uptake of screening, the use of higher film densities and the ever-increasing experience of radiologists.

The government was committed to developing the programme, including the routine invitation to women aged 65-70 to be screened. At present they have to request it.

webTitle: Kennedy tells party to tap 'anti-political sentiments'

fields.headline: Kennedy tells party to tap 'anti-political sentiments'
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy will tell next week's Liberal Democrat conference that the current upsurge of popular protest gives them the chance to become "the anti-politics party" because they share the voters' anger and disappointment.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy will tell next week's Liberal Democrat conference that the current upsurge of popular protest gives them the chance to become "the anti-politics party" because they share the voters' anger and disappointment.

Facing his second party conference as Paddy Ashdown's successor, Mr Kennedy will urge activists to be bolder in "tapping into anti-politics political sentiment, and make our number with an awful lot of people".

They could do so because their policy message chimes with the wider mood of public protest, he said: the need for better-funded public services and more openness about taxation; and the need to create a more direct link between how taxes are raised and what they are spent on - including roads, schools and hospitals.

In a pre-conference interview with the Guardian as the petrol crisis eased yesterday, the Lib Dem leader was careful not to align himself with rightwing populist campaigns on issues as different as asylum and immigration, law and order, petrol prices and child abusers.

"I am not saying we should become champions of direct action, of course not; because I lead a parliamentary party and believe in something called parliamentary democracy. But parliamentary democracy must be more responsive to sentiment in the country, though not populist sentiment.

"We did not buy the populist line in the Martin case [the farmer who killed a burglar], on asylum and immigration, or a number of other issues," insisted Mr Kennedy."You have to stick to your core principles, but say you want better engagement with the public than any of us are yet managing."

He cited his outspoken but unpopular support for Europe - he now wants sterling to join the euro in September 2004 after a 25% devaluation - and hs call for for higher public spending that Tony Blair repeatedly condemned before he did a u-turn on the NHS.

The uproar at last year's world trade conference in Seattle was at least as significant a protest, he believed, and (like the fuel pickets) was also a product of informal organisations using new technologies (the internet and mobile phones) that meant such "social revolutions" could emerge very rapidly.

"It shows how the power structure is potentially moving away from the established world of politics much more in the direction of the grassroot, people's world of politics - which has a very different vocabulary," he explained.

Watching TV phone-ins, he had been startled by the vehemence of the hostility directed at Mr Blair and his colleagues for allegedly being out of touch: "It is extraordinary for an administration that prides itself on being the apotheosis of that sort of thing."

It all showed how people with a heartfelt cause could get a long way with public opinion and media access, Mr Kennedy argued, though he rejected Tory claims that this week's dispute had been a taxpayer's revolt. What the situation needed was a government willing to explain the link between taxes and spending.

"It's a classic case of 'if this is where we take money from, then this is what we are going to spend it on'," he said. Coincidentally the earmarking of specific taxes for specific purposes, the technical term is hypothecation, is a theme of his new book, The Future of Politics (HarperCollins £17.99).

Environmental taxes that helped build better public transport were a crucial ingredient, though the Highland-born MP (first elected for the old SDP at the age of 23) was enough of a country dweller to realise that many rural voters needed cars.

Aides were yesterday instructed to raise the profile of next week's scheduled environment debate in Bournemouth. In his book, Mr Kennedy is frank enough to admit that not taking green issues seriously enough when he was first elected in 1983 is one of his four big mistakes.

The others are his failure to protest enough when London police quashed demonstrations against the Chinese premier Jiang Zemin in 1999, his failure to vote against the disastrous child support agency, and his advice to Mr Ashdown that the Lib Dems should not publicise their controversial policy decision to call for a royal commission into the possible decriminalisation of drugs.

The book is organised around the MP for Ross, Skye and Inverness West's core belief in liberty, with each chapter bearing titles like Freedom from Poverty or Freedom to Breathe: the Green Future. But it concludes on the need to restore idealism to the political system.

"It will not be possible to categorise the voter of 2020 as a socialist or a conservative. He or she a variety of things; internationalist, green, committed to properly-funded public services, and technologically aware."

Green issues and IT were crucial to engaging the young in politics, he believed. Though admitting he was no Ashdown with computers, he did use a laptop and a Psion personal organiser. "To people now going through school and university, it is all like riding a bike was to my generation, that's the difference. I don't know how electricity works, but I couldn't imagine existence without it. That's how they feel about IT."

Mr Kennedy, 40, is thinner than he was a year ago; there is a Diet Coke can on his desk. Sitting in Paddy Ashdown's office, where he has changed all the paintings (there is one of the Palace of Westminster burning down in 1837), he shrugged off criticisms that he is less active than "Action Man" or that he had less influence with Mr Blair - whom he saw for a chat last week.

His book contains not a single reference to the word "project" - shorthand for Lib-Lab cooperation beloved of Messrs Blair and Ashdown. "The second half of any parliament is more competitive than the first half, instinctively so." And there was not much progress to be made on the shared Lib-Lab agenda for constitutional reform this side of polling day.

"I think there's a clear, settled mood in the Liberal Democrats. The atmosphere in the party is relaxed, the party is relaxed with me and I am relaxed with the party. They know we are carrying on with the joint consultative committee [with Labour] in perfectly responsible constructive cooperation. But they also know there is no question of fighting the next election other than as an independent political party."

Could he one day serve in a Lib-Lab coalition as Ashdown might have done? He did not rule it out. "I think it will be arithmetic-driven," dependent on the next election result. But he did not think it likely "because the first-past-the-post [voting] system usually delivers a clearcut majority. That is what it is designed to do."

Did it annoy him that Mr Blair had kicked into touch the two promised referendums Mr Kennedy and his party activists so badly wanted, on the euro and on electoral reform for Westminster? It must have done, but the genial Mr Kennedy did not admit it. "It's better for me to concentrate on what is attainable at this stage rather than what is unattainable."

webTitle: Petrol Crisis - Labour must learn from escape

fields.headline: Petrol Crisis - Labour must learn from escape
fields.body:
Tony Blair looked the most relieved man in Britain yesterday as the petrol crisis eased after the wheels had been close to falling off his government.

A senior Downing Street official, asked if the government would be adopting a "triumphalist" tone, wryly conceded: "I cannot imagine this has helped the government's standing."

The tone of the prime minister's third No 10 press conference in as many days was distinctly contrite after such a narrow escape. Mr Blair insisted his policies were right, but admitted he had been caught on the hop. Lessons will be learned about crisis management - and about monitoring disputes before they become crises.

The more fundamental question is whether it has done long-term harm to new Labour's hard won reputation for competent economic management, or whether the crisis headlines will evaporate almost as quickly as the crisis itself developed last weekend.

The short-term damage to Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and John Prescott - and lesser ministers in the crossfire - is obvious. As Mr Blair admitted, they were caught unaware by the speed of the blockades' impact on a "just in time" society whose petrol stations and supermarkets hold just enough stock to get by for a day or so.

In the first misjudgment, Downing Street and other Whitehall departments thought the protests would fade away rather than spread when they started at the end of last week.

Mr Blair realised there was a serious problem only on Monday night when demonstrators blocked his way to a Chinese restaurant in Hull for dinner with Mr Prescott. The following day he pulled out of a regional tour and trip to the TUC in Glasgow to return to the Downing Street bunker.

Britain was running out of fuel and heading for a shutdown potentially more disastrous than the winter of discontent or the three-day week during Edward Heath's era.

Only on Wednesday did it finally appear as if the government was getting to grips with the crisis as Mr Blair summoned oil industry executives to read the riot act to the global corporations accused of colluding with the demonstrators.

It has been a bad week for government dignity in a year when it has been battered by events as disparate as asylum seekers, NHS cash, leaked Blair memos, cashpoint fines and Euan Blair's GCSE celebrations. The only upside of the fuel crisis is that it has distracted public attention from the tottering Greenwich dome.

Potentially worse for the PM is the accusation, levelled by yesterday's Daily Telegraph, that the crisis was final proof that Mr Blair's is an arrogant government that does not listen to the kind of unBlairite small businessmen who manned the picket lines, to ordinary voters, or even to its own MPs.

"We've been warning Gordon about petrol prices for months now," one minister muttered this week. Despite Mr Blair's repeated refusal to bow to intimidation by small unrepresentative groups, many Labour MPs are certain that concessions will have to be made inside the 60-day deadline imposed by truckers.

That will be a crucial test for the chancellor. As with the single parent benefit revolt in 1997 and this year's 75p increase in the basic pension, plenty of MPs will be whispering that Mr Brown is too powerful and too inflexible for the government's own good. "Tony should rein him in," they will say again.

The arrogance charge - rejected yesterday by Mr Blair - is more dangerous when tied to William Hague's "stealth tax" jibe. The prime minister, chancellor and their colleagues have done their best to explain that world prices are the main culprit and that the extra petrol taxes they imposed in 1997-99 were of Tory origin, caused by the Tory debts they had to clear.

Last March's decision to scrap the fuel escalator inherited from the Tories, and used during Labour's early years, has been cited as evidence that the government is listening. The argument has convinced few voters.

The Downing Street machine has sought scapegoats: the pickets, the police, and the Opec oil producers. It has also resorted to shroud waving, getting the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to put the NHS into the firing line. The tabloids will attack him for playing politics with the sick. But it worked. Along with the prospect that the army would be sent in the risk of pickets being blamed for deaths helped tip them - and the tabloids - away from further confrontation.

Yet ministers persistently refused to go to war, at least in public, with the major oil companies, the one obvious scapegoat whose foot dragging, self-interested tactics could have united pickets, public and ministers against them. Yesterday's own goal by Esso in raising prices before performing a swift U-turn showed what scope was there.

Downing Street optimists hope that once voters have reflected on the dispute they will turn against small groups of politically motivated pickets with a vocally anti-Labour agenda.

There is even some hope that the crisis will help make voters less car dependent as they discover the joys of fast-moving buses, bikes and unpolluted pavements. But they are almost certainly being over-optimistic.

Demonstrators tapped into public resentment against the highest petrol prices in Europe when Britain has North Sea oil.

By backing down yesterday before causing the widespread disruption just round the corner, they deprived Mr Blair of the great victory some in No 10 hoped he could achieve.
