fields.headline: Most wanted:  Lady Penelope boots
fields.trailText: The film may have been godawful but we don't hold it against them. No, everyone will always love Thunderbirds and it's about time Lady Penelope was recognised as the style goddess she is. She's the only TV doll anyone would ever want to be (excepting Miss Piggy, of course) and, at long long last, our dreams can come true. For Breakthrough Breast Cancer awareness month, style-tastic trainer company Acupuncture has launched the Lady Penelope boot (£100 from www.breakthrough.co.uk org.uk from October 1), set to cause pangs of desire in shoe addicts and devotees of children's TV alike. Even better, each pair is autographed (oh my God) by the show's creator, Gerry Anderson.

webTitle: E-comsport hires Miller for marketing position

fields.headline: Miller takes marketing role at e-comsport
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Steve Miller, the self-styled domain names guru, has resurfaced as marketing manager of e-comsport.
fields.body:
Steve Miller, the self-styled domain names guru, has resurfaced in a whole new incarnation - as marketing manager at a sports new media company.

Miller, who left his post as head of marketing at Virtual Internet at the start of the summer, has joined fledgling firm e-comsport, a company which provides sports data and information to both professional and consumer sports audiences.

e-comsport clients include Manchester United, Arsenal, Liverpool, Chelsea, Aston Villa, West Ham, Leicester City and Southampton.

Before joining VI in September 1999, Miller was marketing director at rival domain name firm NetNames since 1997.

Asked what made him move out of domain names, Miller replied: "The hosting and domain name market only remains exciting for so long - so it's good to get involved in a subject area that is expanding, has massive potential and that I really love - i.e. sport and football." e-comsport was floated on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) in May this year, raising £7.8m to fund product development and expansion.

The management team at e-comsport comprises Sir Richard Greenbury, former chairman and chief executive of Marks & Spencer, as non-executive chairman; and Alan Montgomery, former ceo of Glasgow Rangers and finance director of Scottish Television, as ceo.

webTitle: ITouch forges alliance with Vodafone for Olympics

fields.headline: ITouch signs exclusive Olympic deal with Vodafone
fields.trailText: 10.15am: ITouch has signed an exclusive deal with Vodafone to supply Olympic results on mobile phones. By Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
ITouch, the recently listed AIM company, has signed an exclusive deal with Vodafone to supply Olympic results on mobile phones.

Instant alert services will be sent out as SMS messages to ordinary phones, although users can personalise so they are not bombarded with too many messages.

Content for the service is provided by Independent News & Media, Associated Press and 365.

Avi Azulai, iTouch's joint managing director, stressed that you don't have to be in Sydney to receive these Olympic text messages which can be read, "in the Olympic stadium in Sydney, on the street in London or Dublin or even at the beach in Cape Town".

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.trailText: News from PR industry trade title PR Week on appointments, account and agency reviews, and pitches. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sandy Henney, the former royal press secretary who left St James's Palace in disgrace after failing to secure the copyright for Prince William's 18th birthday photographs, has resurfaced as corporate affairs director at Thames Water. Henney will face an uphill struggle at Thames, which has recently dropped out of the FTSE 100 and suffered an exodus from its PR department.

The Pepsi and Tango accounts are up for grabs after Britvic Softdrinks called a review of its entire UK consumer PR. Freud Communications, which handles Pepsi, and Henry's House, Tango's agency, are both repitching.

Unilever needs a new London corporate relations manager after Stephen Milton left for New York. Milton has left London after four and-a-half years to be Unilever's PR director in the US.

Bank of Scotland this week slashed its PR agency roster from 12 to three. Only one incumbent agency, Brunswick, survived after the 13-way pitch.

The London Chamber of Commerce & Industry has appointed a new head of transport and sustainability campaigns as the capital seeks to address its transport problems. Dirk Paterson joins from Christian Solidarity Worldwide.

And the PR nightmare of the week is the Firestone tyre disaster. PR Week's verdict: "Growing mortality rates, falling share value, a brand reputation for safety and reliability in tatters, official government investigations and the prospect of a wave of litigation. It could be from the text book of worst PR nightmares, but it is the current reality for both Ford's Jacques Nasser and Firestone's Masatoshi Ono."

fields.headline: AltaVista to lay off staff
fields.trailText: 9.30am: AltaVista is believed to be laying off around 15% of its workforce today, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AltaVista is believed to be laying off around 15% of its workforce today in a bid to move into profitability by next quarter and go ahead with its long-awaited initial public offering.

AltaVista chief executive Rod Schrock this week informed employees of the move, but he would not reveal the exact number of redundancies. It is understood that most of the cuts will be made in the divisional headquarters in order to centralise operations. Employees in offices outside San Francisco are expected to be hardest hit.

A number of US websites, including Cnet.com and Business 2.0, ran details of the speculation, but AltaVista has yet to confirm the move.

AltaVista's UK press office said it was expecting an announcement this afternoon from the US head office, but had no further details at this stage.

Earlier this year, AltaVista cut about 40 jobs at its US offices, and it has twice delayed a planned European and US IPO.

AltaVista holding company CMGI last week announced it was going through a major restructure and would focus increasing on growth revenue rather than market share.

fields.headline: Durlacher announces three-fold profits surge
fields.trailText: 10am: The Durlacher Corporation has posted a three-fold rise in pre-tax profits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Specialist internet investment firm the Durlacher Corporation has overcome a see-saw first half of the year to post a three-fold rise in profits.

The company said pre-tax profits for the year rose from £2.7m to £12.2m, and announced a link-up with German venture capitalist BMP to set up a UK life sciences research project.

Durlacher shares rose 7.5p to 119p in early trading, far below the year high of 455.5p in February. The company was an obvious target during the April slump in technology stocks when New York's Nasdaq index plummeted, sending the shares to below 100p for several months.

Geoffrey Chamberlain, chairman of Durlacher, said: "A year ago I stated that we had laid the foundations for an international expansion and expression of our strategy over the next few years.

"One year later the foundations are stronger and our branding and reputation increasingly recognised and valued globally."

webTitle: Regional press garners strong ABC results

fields.headline: ABC figures show regional press is thriving
fields.trailText: Regional newspapers have emerged triumphant in ABC six-monthly figures out today, reports Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
Regional newspapers have emerged triumphant in ABC six-monthly figures released today, as 52% of all regional papers have increased their circulation for the third year running.

In the face of competition from the internet, TV and national newspapers, the figures show that 61% of regional weeklies are thriving. This growth has continued despite the presence of an extra 4m free newspapers on the market each week.

Chris Stanley, Newspaper Society marketing director, said: "The result is phenomenal when you consider that we just don't have the time to consume media as we did in the past. As media choice continues to grow and audiences fragment, it is heartening to see how over half of local newspapers continue to add sales."

The newspapers showing the greatest rises are the Malton & Pickering Mercury with 89.9% growth, followed by the Islington Gazette (up 19.7%) and Hunts Post Series (up 16.2%).

The ABC figures reveal an aggregate decrease in regional circulation of 2.1% - a figure that includes large regional titles such as the Scotsman and London's Evening Standard - compared with a decline of 3.7% for daily national newspapers.

Stanley insisted that sales-boosting initiatives such as price-cutting were imposed in extreme cases of marketing or competition such as the Scotsman's rivalry with the Times in Scotland, and would not impact on aggregate results.

He added: "All mainstream media are struggling to maintain audience share, with individual titles, stations or channels inevitably delivering to smaller audiences. Meanwhile, regional publisher online activities are attracting around 100m page impressions each month.

"We are still the prime news and information source in the UK but people are accessing us through a growing range of channels. Life is local and this performance underlines that fact."

webTitle: Lowe Lintas pays damages to Che Guevara photographer

fields.headline: Che Guevara photographer wins damages from Lowe Lintas
fields.trailText: A photographer whose shot of Che Guevara was used in an ad has won substantial damages from Lowe Lintas. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A photographer whose world-famous shot of Che Guevara was used in an advert for Smirnoff vodka has won substantial damages after the advertising agency Lowe Lintas and the Rex picture agency agreed to an out-of-court settlement.

Alberto Diaz Gutierrez took the two companies to the High Court to sue for breach of copyright. His decision came as a surprise because the image has been used the world over with no response from the little-known photographer.

But the 72-year-old Gutierrez objected to the use of the photograph to promote alcohol. He said he was standing up for the principle that work should not be used in a way that might damage the integrity of the artist or subject. He was quoted as saying, "alcohol and Che Guevara have nothing in common". Gutierrez said he would give the money to a children's charity.

The poster ad featured Guevara with a hammer and sickle motif, in which the sickle was represented by a chilli pepper. Lowe Lintas has since lost the Smirnoff account.

webTitle: Newspapers win priority status for fuel supplies

fields.headline: Newspapers win priority status for fuel supplies
fields.standfirst: More on the fuel crisis
fields.trailText: The newspaper distribution crisis appeared to be easing this morning, following the Department of Trade & Industry's decision to give priority treatment to national titles in the UK petrol drought.
fields.body:
The newspaper distribution crisis appeared to be easing this morning, following the Department of Trade & Industry's decision to give priority treatment to national titles in the UK petrol drought.

The DTI has placed newspaper production and distribution on its list of 29 essential services that can receive fuel from 298 special petrol stations across the country. The decision is a success for the Newspaper Publishers' Association, which has been lobbying throughout the week for government assistance.

Steve Oram, director of the NPA, said the association was yesterday asked by the DTI to provide telephone numbers and addresses of distribution depots and hauliers.

The DTI could not be reached for comment, but the government said at the beginning of the shortages that only emergency services would be given priority for fuel supplies.

"It seems to infer that newspapers may get some assistance, and the DTI would not have asked for these details for no reason. But they would not tell us if that means they will help us out," said Mr Oram.

Steve Gordon, divisional director of TNT Newsfast, which delivers titles for 70% of the national newspaper market, said the government had already given priority to the newspaper delivery network.

"We have definitely been given some kind of priority in getting our products out, and we have just had our first diesel delivery in a week. There will be deliveries over the weekend and through to Tuesday," said Mr Gordon.

However, there are concerns over the next stage in the delivery process, when the haulier deliveries to wholesalers are then picked up by small retailers and distributors.

Terry Perry, managing director of the Association of Newspaper & Magazine Wholesalers, said that a number of distributors and retailers relied on garage forecourts for their petrol. The major oil suppliers say it could be two weeks before supplies return to normal.

fields.headline: Ogilvy & Mather picks up £268m Motorola account
fields.trailText: Motorola has handed its $400m global advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather following a six-month review, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Motorola has handed its $400m (£268m) global advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather following a six-month review.

The move sees McCann-Erickson, which also pitched for the global account, lose its Motorola business in the UK. Leo Burnett also pitched for the account.

The three agencies had previously shared the Motorola business, with O&M having the smallest share. O&M chief executive Shelly Lazarus led the pitch.

webTitle: Broadcasters say ad ban ' will wipe out children's TV'

fields.headline: Broadcasters say ad ban ' will wipe out children's TV'
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest broadcasters and advertisers yesterday issued a stark warning that Swedish plans to ban TV advertising for children across the European Union would wipe out indigenous programme-making and result in a flood of trashy American imports.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest broadcasters and advertisers yesterday issued a stark warning that Swedish plans to ban TV advertising for children across the European Union would wipe out indigenous programme-making and result in a flood of trashy American imports.

In a pre-emptive strike ahead of January next year when Sweden will assume the EU's rotating presidency, leading television industry officials said that a ban would cut into their revenues and could lead to job losses.

Sweden has its own national ban on TV ads targeted at children under the age of 12 because it believes that they are too young to distinguish between ads and programmes. It wants such a ban extended across the 15-nation EU and the upcoming presidency will give it a unique opportunity to influence decision making.

Britain's commercial TV stations, such as ITV and Sky, are vehemently opposed.

"Investment in children's programmes in Europe would decline overnight. There are warehouses full of American cartoons which could be bought outright," said Ross Biggam, who represents some of the UK's biggest commercial broadcasters.

The lion's share of children's advertising revenue was ploughed straight back into programme making, he said, and if that source of funding dried up children's TV would simply disappear.

"If it can't be financed then the owners won't make it," he added. Some companies would go bankrupt.

Dan Maddicott, head of children's programmes at United Productions, which supplies ITV, predicted a wave of "cheap and cheerful" American imports if a ban was implemented.

"We have a high level of expertise in the UK and if the money to make programmes disappears we'll have to buy in,"he said.

ITV spent around £45m a year of which £38m was used to commission "quality children's drama".

Sweden is likely to find allies in Denmark, Ireland, Greece and Italy, according to Ian Twinn of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, and will work furiously behind the scenes in readiness for the next review of the so-called "TV without frontiers" directive in 2002.

"Our members rely strongly on TV advertising for marketing and, without that, maintaining strong brands is going to be more difficult. They wouldn't sell so many products and that would lead to job losses," said Mr Twinn.

Swedish diplomats yesterday denied they will push for an immediate ban in January but admitted that they would like to see one in the long run and would work towards this goal.

webTitle: BBC1's new chief stands up for populism

fields.headline: BBC1's new chief stands up for populism
fields.standfirst:
My job is to arrest ratings decline, says controller, as she declares readiness to go head to head with ITV

Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Like alcoholics in denial, BBC executives are usually reluctant to admit their craving for high ratings. But hours after her appointment as BBC1 controller was confirmed, Lorraine Heggessey came out as an unashamed populist.
fields.body:
Like alcoholics in denial, BBC executives are usually reluctant to admit their craving for high ratings. But hours after her appointment as BBC1 controller was confirmed, Lorraine Heggessey came out as an unashamed populist.

Declaring her intention to take on ITV and revealing her favourite programmes to be EastEnders, Big Brother and Who Wants to be a Millionaire, she said: "I want to make BBC1 the best channel on television." Did that mean making it more popular than ITV? "Of course."

It is a high-risk aim. To succeed, Ms Heggessey must confront head-on the dilemma that has been the downfall of her predecessors. Without high audience figures for BBC1, a licence fee levied on every TV viewer becomes almost impossible to justify; yet ratings-chasing risks accusations of trivialisation.

Ms Heggessey was in no doubt of the scale of her task. "My job will clearly be to arrest the ratings decline, if not reverse it," she said. An indication of her strategy came in her identification of ITV's popular drama stalwarts Inspector Morse and A Touch of Frost as examples of good television. Both series gained huge audiences for the commercial network, yet neither could remotely be classed as trash TV. The BBC would kill for such regular success with high-quality programmes.

Competition from multi-channel television is intensifying. Sky One, in particular, is scoring well with clutch of original British programmes this autumn, while ITV plans to screen Who Wants to be a Millionaire? several times a week until the new year.

Ms Heggessey is likely to respond by sanctioning an extra weekly episode of EastEnders. ITV expects her to schedule it on Sunday night, where the BBC is weak, in order to deliver a high audience to later-night drama series.

Another priority is to fill the gap opened by the plan to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm from next year - and that means more drama.

Yet Ms Heggessey has almost no experience in popular adult drama - she is at present the joint director of factual and learning programmes, and was previously head of the children's department. She will depend upon a strong team and the advice of an experienced figure responsible for commissioning drama programmes - expected to be the BBC programme-maker, Jane Tranter.

The BBC has already launched a recruitment drive to strengthen its drama department. Granada's head of drama, Simon Lewis, and his deputy, Sue Hogg, have already defected. One of the producers of the successful ITV series Cold Feet, Christine Langan, is considering a lucrative offer from the BBC. Laura Mackie, LWT's deputy controller of drama, who has presided over London's Burning, is expected to announce her departure for the BBC soon.

ITV is clearly concerned: Granada has made a counter-offer to Ms Langan.

But to avoid accusations of dumbing down, Ms Heggessey cannot abandon the serious factual and educational programmes for which BBC1 is known. ITV showed this week that good-quality current affairs can deliver the ratings: the first in a new series of Tonight With Trevor McDonald, focusing on the petrol crisis, beat Big Brother with a record 6.7m viewers, 37% of the available audience.

Ms Heggessey said that the drive for ratings would not mean the BBC would play it safe. On the contrary, she expects to be bold and imaginative in her programming decisions. "I'd rather be ambitious and fail, than not take risks and succeed."

Burning ambition and a lively record

Most viewers who know of Lorraine Heggessey know her as the mumsy figure who solemnly declared to Blue Peter viewers that one of its presenters had been sacked for drug-taking.

But her buttoned-up blouse concealed a burning ambition. For the best part of the past decade, Ms Heggessey has been working towards the job that, while being the most difficult in television, is also one of the most coveted.

She started her career in journalism, at the Westminster Press local newspaper group, before joining the BBC's Panorama programme and ITV's now defunct This Week current affairs show.

It was as deputy editor on Hard News, the Channel 4 media series, that she came to the public's attention. In a memorable on-screen appearance she doorstepped the doorstepper-in-chief, Roger Cook, for a Dispatches film. The sight of her 5ft 3in frame bouncing down a Manchester street after the lumbering Cook, weighed down by a large breakfast, made for a bizarre but hugely entertaining sequence.

She moved to the BBC to launch its right-to-reply programme Biteback, quickly moving up the ranks. She became editor of the now axed science programme QED, and created Animal Hospital. Against the wishes of senior executives such as Alan Yentob, she insisted that it was presented by Rolf Harris. It demonstrated a populist touch for which she has become revered - but the factual credentials gained early in her career were strengthened when she was executive producer of The Human Body in 1996.

At BBC1, Ms Heggessey has an extra £100m to play with. She declared yesterday her intention to "surprise and delight" the audience, and revive BBC1.

She has two daughters, aged seven and 10, and is the first female controller of BBC1. But she did not see gender as an issue. "The most important thing is what kind of life you have: do you have a rounded life, are you in touch with the viewers?"

With an air of mischief and a sideways glance at the director of television, Mark Thompson, she added: "I think women are better than most men."

webTitle: Trinity Mirror loses two senior executives

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror loses two senior executives
fields.standfirst:
National newspapers chief goes

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Two senior executives of Trinity Mirror - including Roger Eastoe, who was in charge of the group's national newspaper titles - are leaving as part of a reshuffle engineered by chief executive Philip Graf.
fields.body:
Two senior executives of Trinity Mirror - including Roger Eastoe, who was in charge of the group's national newspaper titles - are leaving as part of a reshuffle engineered by chief executive Philip Graf.

The restructuring has created a new senior post overseeing the group's national and regional titles.

The company said the new executive would free Mr Graf to supervise the development of Trinity Mirror's new media business, and to look for further acquisitions.

The job has been offered to an as yet unnamed executive with a background in consumer product marketing, Mr Graf said. Mr Eastoe, 49, was a Mirror Group stalwart. He is due to leave at the end of the month, and a group statement said he was pursuing "a number of business opportunities".

He denied there had been any acrimony: "I've been at the crease for 25 years and run the nationals for four or five years, and I've had a great time. I was here at the low point for the Mirror Group when we weren't sure there was a business anymore. I am moving on now, but the business is in good shape."

Mike Masters, the other executive on his way out, was group managing director publishing and will retire at the end of the year.

Mr Graf said Trinity Mirror's immediate focus would be to pursue further acquisitions in the regional press, although he conceded the group was reluctant to engage in a bidding war for Regional Independent Media. The group has, however, sought permission from the DTI to acquire certain RIM titles in Lancashire should they become available.

Much of his focus will be on the internet business - including the evaluation of the group's role as an internet service provider.

Trinity Mirror reported a 14.7% increase in half-year, pre-tax profits to £104.5m before a £15m cost of investing in new activities. Revenues were 7.4% higher at £560m, and shares climbed 15.5p to 540p.

The Mirror, Sunday Mirror and Sunday People achieved 7.4% revenue growth to £210m and operating profit of £43m for the first half. Regionals grew revenues 6.1% to £245.3m and profits by 10% to £66.8m.

The job has been offered to an as yet unnamed executive with a background in consumer product marketing, Mr Graf said. Mr Eastoe, 49, was a Mirror Group stalwart. He is due to leave at the end of the month, and a group statement said he was pursuing "a number of business opportunities". He denied there had been any acrimony: "I've been at the crease for 25 years and run the nationals for four or five years, and I've had a great time. I was here at the low point for the Mirror Group when we weren't sure there was a business anymore. I am moving on now, but the business is in good shape." Mike Masters, the other executive on his way out, was group managing director publishing and will retire at the end of the year. Mr Graf said Trinity Mirror's immediate focus would be to pursue further acquisitions in the regional press, although he conceded the group was reluctant to engage in a bidding war for Regional Independent Media. The group has, however, sought permission from the DTI to acquire certain RIM titles in Lancashire should they become available. Much of his focus will be on the internet business - including the evaluation of the group's role as an internet service provider. Trinity Mirror reported a 14.7% increase in half-year, pre-tax profits to £104.5m before a £15m cost of investing in new activities. Revenues were 7.4% higher at £560m, and shares climbed 15.5p to 540p. The Mirror, Sunday Mirror and Sunday People achieved 7.4% revenue growth to £210m and operating profit of £43m for the first half. Regionals grew revenues 6.1% to £245.3m and profits by 10% to £66.8m.

fields.headline: Oasis launches dot.com start-up service
fields.trailText: Oasis Communications has set up a service just for dot.com start-ups, Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Oasis Communications has gone against the marketing agencies tide by setting up a service just for dot.com start-ups.

WebHatching has been formed with the sole purpose of offering a fully-integrated marketing and business service to help start-ups to launch and develop their brand.

It is a decisive move for the agency at a time when the bulk of marketing agencies are increasingly loathe to work with dot.coms.

However, Oasis operates rigorous due diligence before taking on new business. It will only work with people who have at least £100,000 seed capital and, above all, it looks for a unique business concept and strong management team.

With start-ups, Oasis protects itself by asking for 50% of the fee and all third-party costs up front. And although the agency sometimes takes a stake in the business in return, it usually works on a fee basis.

"Fortunately, we haven't had our WebHatching wings clipped to date," said interactive director Mark Cripps.

The service was initially targeted at dot.com start-ups, but Oasis is opening it up to traditional businesses.

Oasis recently picked up a number of new clients including MoonFruit, Deckchair.com, Securicor and a number of undisclosed dot.com start-ups.

The wins have increased Oasis's billings from £8m to £27m.

webTitle: Going bananas as Brussels sprouts myths

fields.headline: Going bananas as Brussels sprouts myths
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Leading pro-Europeans yesterday launched a withering attack on Eurosceptic "myths" and scare stories about supposed EU plans to ban curved bananas, cheddar cheese and mushy peas.
fields.body:
Leading pro-Europeans yesterday launched a withering attack on Eurosceptic "myths" and scare stories about supposed EU plans to ban curved bananas, cheddar cheese and mushy peas.

The former Tory chancellor Kenneth Clarke and the union leader Sir Ken Jackson criticised anti-euro groups for "twisting the facts" about Brussels as Britain in Europe published a pamphlet challenging recent reports about law-making in the European Union.

The pamphlet, Straight Bananas? - 150 anti-European myths exploded, is part of a drive to debunk anti-European myths, which the all-party pro-euro group claimed were to blame for the low level of support which exists in the UK for joining the single currency.

The stories exposed as false in the pamphlet include supposed plans by European commissioners to ban the traditional British loaf, overly curved cucumbers, shandy and soya milk, and to rename brandy butter as "brandy spreadable fat".

Mr Clarke, a patron of Britain in Europe, said: "We are all tired of the way some of the anti-European campaigns have twisted the facts about our place in Europe."

He added: "This pamphlet is one answer to millions of pounds worth of misleading propaganda."

At the TUC conference in Glasgow, Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU, said: "The No camp is built on myths and misconceptions. The polls show people want the hard facts."

Andrew Haldenby of Business for Sterling, a leading group in the No campaign, dismissed the pamphlet as "pathetic".

webTitle: Money or influence - a toss-up for the Gulf states

fields.headline: Money or influence - a toss-up for the Gulf states
fields.standfirst: The Gulf's vast reserves mean it will always have hefty clout in the world's oil markets, but no one can say where its long-term future leads for sure, explains Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The Gulf's vast reserves mean it will always have hefty clout in the world's oil markets, but no one can say where its long-term future leads for sure, explains Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Experts usually sound convincing until you put two of them together and find that they disagree. Sometimes it's amusing, but when the argument is about our future oil supplies it's troubling.

A few days ago I attended a seminar on "the strategic importance of Gulf oil", where I was surprised to find that two bodies who ought to know for certain - the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the US Department of Energy - have very different views of the Gulf's prospects.

The Gulf has about two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves and, if the IEA is correct, we are going to become ever more dependent on it. By 2010 our dependence will be so great that the Gulf states will be called upon to produce 41m barrels a day - more than double what they produce now.

Given the political uncertainties in the area (where Iraq, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are the main producers) the risks inherent in that are obvious.

The Department of Energy, on the other hand, predicts that 10 years from now the Gulf will be producing 28m barrels a day. This too means the Gulf will become more important, but the change is much more modest.

Both forecasts can't be right and, quite possibly, both are wrong - there are too many unknown quantities to consider.

The main difficulty is predicting future worldwide demand for oil. Prices are a key factor, because higher prices force people to use less oil or switch to alternatives. Wild price swings, of the kind we have seen over the last two years, make forecasting extremely difficult. Various experts have recently put forward plausible-sounding arguments for prices ranging from $5 (£3.50) a barrel to levels even higher than those of the last few weeks.

One factor affecting future demand (and, in turn, prices) is the revolution in information technology. Because of it, we may have moved into a period where economic growth will not necessarily increase our need for oil. IT uses electricity which, on the whole, is not oil-generated. Also, IT may eventually reduce our use of transport, which in the US accounts for about half of all oil consumption.

A further imponderable is the effect of environmental concerns about oil. Anti-pollution measures in the form of deterrent taxes and moves towards cleaner fuel will probably reduce our use of oil. Nobody knows by how much, but four years from now the US motor industry will begin introducing vehicles powered by fuel cells rather than gasoline, and it is estimated that by 2010 around 10% of new cars will have them.

A few years ago, there were many who predicted that the world would eventually run out of oil. Now, an increasing number can be heard suggesting the opposite: we might not even need it.

Dr Fadhil Chalabi, of the London-based Centre for Global Energy Studies, believes that world energy is in transition. He recalls how, in 1911, Winston Churchill told the British navy it was time to stop burning coal in their ships and convert to oil. Today, there is still plenty of coal in the ground but nobody wants it. The same could happen to oil, Dr Chalabi says, and we may look back on the 20th century as "The Century of Oil".

The politically interesting question is what this might mean for the Gulf as a region where oil has given some states (Iran and Iraq) freedom to resist Western influence and has obliged others (Saudi Arabia and Kuwait) to seek Western protection.

If the price of oil remains high, the relative importance of the Gulf is likely to decline. This is because high prices give the oil companies more cash to invest in exploration elsewhere, making them less dependent on Gulf oil.

On the other hand, if demand falls and prices go down, we are likely to become more dependent on the Gulf. This is partly because there will be less exploration elsewhere, but also because Gulf oil is produced more cheaply than in many other parts of the world.

The extraction cost of Iraqi oil is only $1 (70p) a barrel, but for oil from the new fields in the Caspian sea it is $14-16 (£10-11) a barrel. While the selling price of oil remains above $30 (£21) a barrel, Caspian sea oil is well worth producing, but it rapidly becomes less attractive as prices fall.

To some extent, this also applies to the United States. When the selling price fell to $10 (£7) a barrel a couple of years ago, American oil production became uneconomic - which is why the US then pleaded with the Gulf states to cut production and drive up prices to at least $20 (£14) a barrel.

So the future of the Gulf looks like a trade-off between money and influence: to be rich but less important if prices are high, or to be more important but less well-off if prices are low.

The government's full list of priority users for petrol.
Petrol special report

27. Veterinary services.

fields.headline: Life in the middle lane
fields.standfirst: With petrol hard to come by, Northern editor Martin Wainwright engages in a reverse version of Speed - keeping the dial below 56mph - and grapples with those tricky in-car LCDs he never had time for before
fields.trailText: With petrol hard to come by, Northern editor Martin Wainwright engages in a reverse version of Speed - keeping the dial below 56mph - and grapples with those tricky in-car LCDs he never had time for before.
fields.body:
I doubt if I'm the only person who has discovered a fascinating new form of reading during the petrol crisis - a winking patch of liquid crystal display on the car dashboard which I've previously found too confusing to use.

It's part of something called the "Driver Information System" which always goes wrong, particularly when my children press its two control buttons too keenly, and it starts unfathomable tasks like assessing your maximum speed and optimum temperature between two randomly chosen points (or something).

It also flashes up an enormous exclamation mark from time to time, which the instruction book classifies as a Serious Problem but which clearly isn't, and therefore has the eventual effect of the shepherd boy crying "Wolf!" But enough of the downside; during the petrol drought, it has been a wonderful aid to my efforts to squeeze hundreds of miles out of a 50-litre Ford Escort tank.

We have to drive, those of us reporting for the Guardian outside London, and I regret to say that often we have to drive very fast, to follow the newsdesk's whims from Immingham to Clitheroe via, shall we say, Blyth. ("Well," says the voice in London, "They're only an inch apart on my map"). To retain our ability to drive at all though experts reckon we should cruise at 56mph, no more, and a fascinating exercise it is.

Pulling out of Leeds, uphill towards Harrogate, the winking red LCD shows horrendous levels of fuel consumption: 19.1 miles per gallon, 17.3, then up to a proportionately generous 27.5 as we ease into top gear. A plateau by the entrance to Esholt reservoir (happy memories of the Great Yorkshire Drought - this is where they built a whole new road for those other emergency tankers) and the figure soars to 38.6, then up through the 50s, 80s and, amazingly, as the run swoops down to Harewood and the Wharfe Valley beyond, a cracking 177 miles for every gallon. No! 220? I can drive to Morocco at this rate.

For a novice, LCD-watching is terribly dangerous, a constant threat to the much lower accident statistics which are certain to come from the current period of a national attempt not to drive too fast. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents is sure about that. I just rang them on the carphone (hands-free but yes, I admit I was jeopardising the statistics even more) and they said though it was too early for figures, last time (the 1970s oil crisis), there had been a terrific drop.

Three days of driving at 56mph or less tells you, uncontrovertibly, that they must be right. You don't get there as quickly (though in towns or trafficky runs like the M62, there isn't a huge difference), but you know that you are being much more safe. You are also being fabulously effective at saving petrol. I almost swore, on a stately trip to York and back last Tuesday, that the fuel gauge was lower when I started than when I got back.

I shall try to keep this up, although I write that with the sinking heart of someone who knows that - like not having another bag of crisps or bar of chocolate - the resolution won't be kept. But there may be some converts; my journeys have involved lots of friendly grins at Audis and BMWs which would normally flash past, but are clearly following the same 56-max regime.

The only dangerous moment, ironically, was when an enormous lorry thundered up behind on the motorway, flashing and roaring because I was in its way (overtaking another wagon in the lane to my immediate left). It seemed a bit mean, especially when the danger of hauliers' "rolling blockades" was playing havoc with Yorkshire motorways. But as Tony Blair has discovered, it's best to avoid confrontations with 32-tonners.

fields.headline: Rationing keeps NHS afloat
fields.standfirst:
The economy: Key staff given priority but other services struggle

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Health
fields.body:
Health

Only desperate measures kept Britain's ambulance teams on the road yesterday, and the end of most blockades gave no immediate relief to patients and relatives marooned with empty tanks.

One Pontefract garage owner made the 90-mile round trip to Immingham refinery to fill portable tanks with petrol to supply local doctors and nurses, while scores of other medical staff - including ambulance drivers - organised car pools, lifts and even bicycles to get to work.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, warned that cancelled operations would cause a backlog for weeks and that there was no question of lifting the NHS emergency alert. Touring the Royal Sussex County hospital in Brighton to thank staff, he said: "The situation remains serious and there are very real concerns about the next few days.

"We are not going to be able to get the health service back to normal with the flick of a switch."

The country saw hundreds of piecemeal local rationing schemes, with garages limiting supplies to medical staff, frequently supervised by police. Officers turned away a dozen people trying to fill home-brewing barrels and other illegal containers at the BP garage in Leeds where customers were allowed £20 fill-ups after emergency services had been restocked.

Birmingham city council gave part of its supply to hospitals after warnings that nurses and doctors were stuck at home.

Hidden costs of the blockade continued to bite elsewhere, however, particularly in cutting visits by relatives to sick and dying relatives. West Yorkshire hospice chaplain Rev Daphne Green said: "The grief caused hasn't perhaps been fully realised. We had a funeral where relatives couldn't attend because they had no petrol and it was very upsetting."

In Eastbourne, two hospital administrative staff rode horses to work. Sonia Capelli, 38, said that she and Hayley Wilkinson, 19, took 45 minutes to commute - "not a lot slower than it normally takes".

Martin Wainwright

Food

Shoppers have been told to stop panic buying fresh food as widespread rationing was introduced to try to curb people stockpiling basic foodstuffs. Demand for bread and milk has increased by 50% in recent days, according to the British Retail Consortium.

The Federation of Bakers said that excessive demand for bread would result in shortages. John White, director of the federation, said the supply chain was still fragile and bakers have had to reduce the number of deliveries.

American superstore Wal-Mart in Bristol was limiting customers to two loaves of bread each and at Somerfield in Malmesbury, Wiltshire, a limit of three fresh items and six non-fresh items was imposed by the store manager.

Asda has doubled its fresh food order across the country to cope with demand.

Abattoirs have warned that meat supplies could dwindle and livestock may have to be destroyed because of the difficulties distributing animal feed. John Davies, agricultural director of Webbs Country Foods in Kent, which processes poultry, said six million chicks would starve today unless feed is delivered. Staff at Malton Bacon factory in north Yorkshire have stopped slaughtering pigs.

Welsh transport secretary Sue Essex urged people to use food in their cupboards and freezers rather than stockpiling food from shops and supermarkets.

"Any problems with food distribution will be overcome if those of us with food in their cupboard, the fridge and the freezer draw on these stocks over the weekend, rather than using scarce fuel to make food scarce too," she said.

Sainsbury said its food deliveries had continued as normal throughout the fuel crisis. "We have been working as normal," said a spokeswoman. "But the problem is that demand has been very high rather than supplies being low.

Helen Carter

Post office and banks

The Post Office is reducing its services to a bare minimum, halting second deliveries and stopping Sunday collections because of the depletion of its fuel supplies.

Banks, however, believe they will not have to resort to any drastic action after securing a place on the government's priority fuel list for the armoured vehicles which transport money around Britain.

Even though tankers were starting to reappear on the roads yesterday, just 10 tanker loads reached the Post Office, which has a high priority status for fuel. It needs 30 tanker deliveries a day to maintain its 36,000-strong fleet of vans.

To stretch the little fuel that is has left, the Post Office said its aim was to continue to provide as near to normal service as possible. But it would make just one postal delivery and collection a day and completely suspend Sunday's collection.

The Post Office's main priority was to ensure cash reached its 18,000 network of post offices to allow social security benefits to be continued to paid. It will also aim to keep its rural Postbus service running.

Jill Treanor

Business

Senior executives last night were keeping their fingers crossed that the fuel blockade would be lifted completely as industry leaders warned that the crisis would cost business more than £1bn.

The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said it would take weeks for companies to resume pre-crisis levels of operation while the London Chamber of Commerce believed things were likely to get worse before they got better.

A Chamber spokesman added: "At least £1bn will have gone in lost output but it is still going to be a long process getting businesses back to where they were."

The CBI said it was difficult to quantify the exact scale of the problem but believed "hundreds of millions of pounds" would have been lost. A spokeswoman for the CBI said members reported sales down, manufacturing processes stopping and a threat over jobs. Much depended now whether tankers could supply businesses as well as emergency services.

The UK Steel Association said there was guarded optimism causing some members to postpone plans for winding down production lines. But some shifts had already been cut and output scaled back according to David Rae, the organisation's secretary general.

Terry Macalister

Schools and local services

Hundreds of schools that have managed to keep going during this week's fuel crisis may be forced to shut next week unless teachers are among those given priority access to the petrol now being delivered to designated petrol stations.

As thousands of schoolchildren were told to stay away from classes yesterday education officials warned that teaching staff in some rural areas were finding it increasingly difficult to get to work.

Somerset county council, which has kept all its school open, said heads would make a decision today on whether to reopen on Monday. A spokesman said the authority was concerned that unless teachers were able to get petrol schools across the county would be hit next week.

In Rhondda Cynon Taff only one of the county's 19 secondary schools was able to open yesterday forcing 19,000 children to miss lessons. The schools will remain closed today. The council has warned that the problem could spill over beyond the weekend, possibly affecting primary school children as well.

Devon said none of its schools had had to close. But 47 of the 950 school bus services have already ground to a halt. More are expected to be hit today.

In Birmingham more than 370 children were affected after two schools closed because of the fuel shortages, while in Bolton up to 100 special needs pupils were unable to get to classes after buses on five routes were cancelled.

In County Durham, where schools remained open yesterday, the council said it did not anticipate any problems before the end of the week.

Geoffrey Gibbs

Public transport

Fuel deliveries reached selected train and bus depots yesterday after some London services ground to a halt, but operators warned that buses would not be back to normal for a week and London cabs were coming off the road.

A spokesman for the mayor's fuel emergency team in London, which yesterday appealed directly to fuel suppliers, said Brentford and Dagenham bus depots received fuel last night after drying up. But 60% of First Capital's east London services had been cut and three London bus companies cancelled services because drivers could not get to work.

Stagecoach spokesman Barry Gardner said that although fuel tankers had reached critical depots in Oxford, Gloucestershire and Lancashire and fuel was expected in Wales, services would suffer cancellations after 7pm. These measures could stay in place until next week.

In the north-west, the bus operator Arriva said it had enough fuel to run normal services until tonight. Sunday services were still operating in Blackpool, and in Nottingham and Bristol evening services remained reduced.

A Transport for London spokeswoman said the capital's taxi situation was getting "progressively worse" as independent drivers came off the road and fleets with diesel reserves prioritised getting London underground staff to work.

The Association of Train Operating Companies was optimistic that train companies had enough fuel to run normally for the next six days. Anglia resumed cancelled services yesterday but selected South West services from Exeter and Brighton South West remained cancelled until fuel arrived.

Angelique Chrisafis

webTitle: Anger over 'fat cat' oil bosses' pay rises

fields.headline: Anger over 'fat cat' oil bosses' pay rises
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the petrol war
 Tensions boil over at pump queues  Government not prepared, says home secretary
 Fuel supplies rationed
 BA raises prices
 Protesters in court
fields.trailText:
 Tensions boil over at pump queues
 Government not prepared, says home secretary
 NHS stays on red alert
Special report: the petrol war
fields.body:
Pay rises given to executives of oil companies were deemed a "scandal" today after research for a union showed bosses had enjoyed increases of up to 65%.

The general union GMB said the figures, showing that nine executives at BP Amoco and Shell received rises of at least 35% last year, exposed new levels of "greed".

Its general secretary, John Edmonds, said: "It is a scandal that these directors are making huge profits by milking the country dry."

The top pay rise at BP Amoco was 65%, while at Shell it was 58%, according to the research.

It also showed the pay of the highest earning director at Elf Petroleum increased from £415,000 to £640,000 last year, while at Esso it rose from £474,000 to £495,000, at Totalfina it went from £192,000 to £268,000 and from £461,000 to £474,000 at Texaco.

Mr Edmonds said: "This exposes the insatiable greed of the oil guzzling gluttons.

"Taxpayers should ask themselves whether they really want to see tax revenues pumped into the coffers of the fattest cats in the corporate jungle or whether they would rather see money invested in vital public services."

The fuel crisis will have cost businesses £1bn - the equivalent of £40 per household - by the time it has ended, the Institute of Directors (IoD) warned separately today.

The overall loss of output would be about £1bn on the assumption that it would take two to three weeks for the crisis to be fully resolved, and that disruption to the economy would be about 5% of activity in the first week and rapidly declined after that, the IoD said.

The hotel and tourism industries, retail and manufacturing are all particularly vulnerable, while agriculture and businesses in rural areas are also likely to be disrupted, it warned.

And, almost as a direct response to that warning, British Airways announced today it had raised fares by three percent as a result of high fuel prices.

A spokeswoman for Europe's largest airline said the rise had taken place with effect from today and covered all published tariffs except current promotional fares.

It came after KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, which is in merger talks with British Airways, had also announced a four percent fare rise.

The IoD said the fuel crisis could also be the final straw for small businesses. Its policy unit head, Ruth Lea, said: "Limited as the economic damage is, some marginal businesses will inevitably be finished by the fuel crisis.

"The protesters are right to complain about the extortionately high fuel duties and we look to the chancellor to cut them in his next Budget."

The IoD warning came as two protesters, arrested during the recent fuel crisis, appeared in court in Sunderland.

Farmer Andrew Spence, 33, of Medomsley, County Durham, was one of the main organisers of the fuel pickets at Jarrow and Sunderland in the north-east of England. He and fellow picketer, farmer Rob Muir, 34, of Consett, County Durham, were both accused of obstructing the highway after attempting to block the path of a tanker at the fuel terminal at Sunderland docks on Wednesday.

Both men admitted the charge and agreed to be bound over to keep the peace for six months in the sum of £50. Meanwhile, the home secretary, Jack Straw, today acknowledged that the government had not anticipated the scale and speed of the fuel price protests.

But he defended the government's action and said the boundaries of democratic protest had been crossed. "We either went the French way or we did what people expected of a serious and responsible British government ... on the issue of protests which had passed an acceptable democratic line," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "There is an issue about the boundaries of protest in a democratic society."

When asked if those boundaries were crossed, Mr Straw agreed, adding: "As a consequence of these protests, essential services, the basic fabric of our society and national life, were brought to the brink. I was surprised."

The Conservative leader, William Hague, meanwhile, used a speech to the CBI at Newport in Gwent, to poke fun at the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

He told delegates: "I suppose we should be congratulating him. He once said he promised to reduce the number of cars on the road - and that's precisely what he's done. Well done!"

Britain spent today struggling to get back to normal as petrol stations began restocking with fuel after protesters lifted the week-long pickets and demonstrations which had stopped supplies leaving refineries.

Many garages and service stations across the country were still only supplying the emergency services, while others with petrol available were being forced to ration motorists to £10 of fuel each.

Tensions boiled over at many petrol stations as long queues meant motorists had to wait, in some cases for up to two hours for their £10 worth.

But as the end of the crisis neared, traffic was gradually getting heavier in many parts of the country.

An AA Roadwatch spokesman said: "Many of the garages are still empty or closed, but people are starting to queue at stations despite their 'no fuel' signs because they are believing what they hear - that things are getting back to normal.

"Things are getting better and there are efforts to get back to normal, but there are stations still having to prioritise and ration."

Motorway services were expecting deliveries this morning, including the London Gateway on the M25 and the M1 Toddington services.

The M1 Watford Gap services reopened this morning with both unleaded and diesel supplies, but there were long queues for diesel.

Meanwhile, a handful of protesters remained at BP's Grangemouth refinery in central Scotland.

But the prime minister, Tony Blair, warned the crisis was not over yet, as protesters vowed to take action again if the tax on fuel is not cut in 60 days.

The NHS remained on red alert today, and supermarkets appealed for an end to panic buying after nervous shoppers cleared shelves of essentials such as bread and milk.

Postal services have been slashed by the Post Office as stocks of fuel for its 36,000 vehicles came close to running out, and more than 70 schools were closed.

It later emerged that more than 100 fuel protesters spent the night at the showground outside Carmarthen. They are due to discuss whether to take further action later today as they said they still felt the need to take some action.

webTitle: How long to fill up the pumps?

fields.headline: How long to fill up the pumps?
fields.standfirst:
Supplies: It may take three weeks to replenish tanks

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The fuel may be on its way but getting Britain back on the road will be a complicated and lengthy task, made worse by renewed panic buying. Oil companies, petrol retailers and motoring organisations say it could take three weeks to return to normal and have appealed to the public to act sensibly.
fields.body:
The fuel may be on its way but getting Britain back on the road will be a complicated and lengthy task, made worse by renewed panic buying. Oil companies, petrol retailers and motoring organisations say it could take three weeks to return to normal and have appealed to the public to act sensibly.

Early yesterday it was estimated that 90% of the 13,000 filling stations across the UK were empty of fuel. Oil industry officials said 300 designated petrol stations would have fuel by last night and 20% of the national network would be back on tap within 48 hours.

However, Ray Holloway of the Petrol Retail Association said initial deliveries to filling stations were not going to resolve the problem. "It's going to take us two to three weeks to get back to normal levels," he said. "The public will need to be patient and people must only take what they need."

There were few signs of patience yesterday as first deliveries reached some garages. At the Deerpark service station in Livingston news of a consignment of fuel from nearby Grangemouth brought a mile-long queue of drivers to the forecourt. More than 30,000 litres, a normal full day's supply, sold out in just three hours.

"If it goes on like this it's going to take a long, long time before we're back on track," said manager Alan Gray.

Sue Nicolson of the RAC Foundation said although it was crucial that motorists acted rationally, it was unlikely that they would. "We would say put only £10 or £20 in just to keep you going so that the petrol is enough to go round. I suspect, however, knowing human nature and the British psyche, that is not going to happen."

All eyes are now on the oil companies to see if they can rise to the challenge and get the fuel out quickly and in sufficient quantities.

The Shell UK chairman, Malcolm Brinded, yesterday assured the prime minister that the industry was responding. "We are focusing immediately on 300 sites for essential supplies and over the next two days we should see many more," he said.

Shell's fleet of 175 tankers normally make 600-700 deliveries a day to 1,100 filling stations nationwide. Only 30 of them had petrol by yesterday morning.

Esso normally delivers 700 tanker loads a day to 1,620 garages, the vast majority of which now have no fuel. "We are working as hard as we can to get all our tankers back out and the supply back to normal," said a spokesman.

BP said: "We are still talking about more than 1,200 of our 1,500 stations completely out of fuel. We think it will be two to three weeks before we can get back to a normal service. The situation would not be as dire as it has become if it wasn't for the panic buying. We can't really predict how the public is going to react now."

webTitle: No fuel tax concession says Brown

fields.headline: No fuel tax concession says Brown
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor rejects early move on prices as pickets lift blockades

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText:
As petrol station across Britain struggled
                                                                  to get back to normal today, chancellor
                                                                  Gordon Brown, dug in his heels against
                                                                  any early tax concessions on fuel prices
                                                                  before next March, despite a 60 day
                                                                  deadline for action imposed by pickets
                                                                  when they lifted their crippling blockades.
fields.body:
As petrol station across Britain struggled to get back to normal today, chancellor Gordon Brown, dug in his heels against any early tax concessions on fuel prices before next March, despite a 60 day deadline for action imposed by pickets when they lifted their crippling blockades.

With Tony Blair's full support, Mr Brown let it be known that he will not be deflected by what ministers insist are "illegal blockades and intimidation" in reaching his budget judgment as usual in March. Downing Street believes its firm stance will win round public opinion as tempers cool.

A senior No 10 official said: "These people have got to take on board the facts of the budget process. You cannot make budget decisions as a response to protests. There is a budget process and a parallel democratic process. They can make representations if they wish."

However, the government's strategy is high risk given the scale of action and strength of feeling shown this week. Protesters - who include farmers, hauliers and fishermen, already aggrieved at what they see as unfair treatment by the government - have threatened to reimpose blockades of oil refineries and depots if there is no move to cut fuel taxes.

During another day of drama which saw Esso, impose a provocative 2p-4p a litre increase - only to withdraw it within four hours after a meeting with Mr Blair - ministers breathed a collective sign of relief as the worst crisis of their government began to wind down.

It is expected that by 3pm tomorrow, many garages will be restocked, though a £10 limit of petrol per motorist may be implemented. Some motorway service stations are already re-stocked, though there are queues of up to two miles long for the fuel.

Meanwhile, the NHS remained on red alert today, and supermarkets appealed for an end to panic buying after nervous shoppers cleared shelves of essentials such as bread and milk.

Postal services have been reduced to just one collection and delivery a day by the Post Office as stocks of fuel for its 36,000 vehicles came close to running out, and more than 70 schools across Britain were closed.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, will head a joint team with the industry to ensure there is no repetition of this week's rapid crisis, though Blair aides are confident the threat to restore pickets if no concessions are made by mid-November will not materialise.

Angry pickets voted throughout yesterday to end the crisis and claimed a "a great moral victory", though pockets of resistance continued. When Esso announced its increase to protect profit margins some pickets threatened to restore their blockades and motoring organisations called the increase "insensitive".

Though Mr Blair rejected calls for an Office of Fair Trading investigation of the oil firms Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, may yet decide to instigate one. Most of the companies - making record global profits, it emerged yesterday - promised to absorb any losses from the blockades.

The prime minister's anger over yesterday's short-lived fuel price rise was evident at the press conference. "I cannot really understand that Esso decision. The world oil price, as far as I'm aware, has actually come down in the last few days." He repeated the message in private to industry leaders. Despite speculation that he will cut vehicle excise duty for lorries or reduce taxes on petrol Mr Brown, whose annual pre-budget report is due in mid-November, is adamant that he will not be bounced. Mr Blair told reporters the government is willing to listen, and to meet groups with "genuine and sincerely held grievances".

But "to lurch into some short-term fix with emergency budgets and the like would not just be irresponsible, but the effect on the country's financial standing and credibility would be immediate and catastrophic", he insisted.

In a downbeat assessment Mr Blair warned that "lives have been and are still at risk". He admitted that mistakes had been made and appealed to voters to "carefully reflect on recent events. However much people may dislike paying petrol duty there's no way that any government of this country could or should yield to this form of protest".

After regaining control of their worst spontaneous crisis yet, ministers are gambling on rallying public opinion and on western efforts to persuade Opec, the oil producers cartel, to increase production and cut prices - a move which may damage the government's green credentials. Despite savage attacks by William Hague and his allies in the Conservative press - the government had itself provoked this "taxpayers' revolt" the Tory leader said - Mr Blair has been comforted by the "extraordinary unity" among Labour supporters and unions.

Government sources said the crisis was turned round at a crucial stage by senior Transport and General Workers union officials persuading members in the Grangemouth refinery in Scotland to break the blockade in a convoy.

The deal, relayed to protesters around 2am yesterday, persuaded pickets ouside the refinery that it would be better to retreat in an orderly way while still claiming the high moral ground. At the same time, protesters at the Stanlow refinery in Cheshire - where the action started more than a week ago - also decided to abandon their blockade while they still had public support.

Privately ministers believe they can persuade voters that tough decisions on public spending - including petrol taxes - are crucial to a buoyant economy which in turn funds improved health and education.

Mr Hague gave notice that Alan Milburn's declaration of an NHS red alert will be investigated.

"The most disgraceful spinning of the crisis came from the health secretary - and we will be examining very carefully what he said and did this week," he said last night.

Tactical retreat aimed at keeping public support

fields.trailText: They were in there for hours. As the flares on the stacks of the oil refinery chimneys burned red against the night sky, two men and one woman who held the power to decide whether the fuel blockade should be stopped or continue were talking.
fields.body:
They were in there for hours. As the flares on the stacks of the oil refinery chimneys burned red against the night sky, two men and one woman who held the power to decide whether the fuel blockade should be stopped or continue were talking.

From 8.45pm on Wednesday night they sat in a little office inside the main terminal of the Shell Stanlow oil terminal at Ellesmere Port, along with officers from Cheshire police. All night, they phoned round protest sites across the country talking to various leaders about calling the whole thing off. Those protesters who couldn't be roused from their sleep in the cabs of their trucks were woken by police officers.

The key players - Paul Ashley, Tom Houghton and Hilary Whittaker, all from Farmers for Action, the direct action group who began the protest - were trying to gauge the consensus. They wanted to see if other groups had come to the same conclusion - that they should end the protest while the public were still on their side.

It was just less than a week ago that the very same people - along with Brynle Williams, another militant farmer - led a convoy of 150 farmers and hauliers from a cattle market in St Asaph near Rhyl to Stanlow, targeting it because it is Britain's largest oil refinery. The action was a spur of the moment decision, a whim that ground Britain to a halt. The blockade began at Stanlow last Thursday night and the protesters decided that that is where it should end.

After concerns were raised about the health service being put on red alert and an awareness that food stocks would be badly affected by today, leaders decided enough was enough. They had made their point. Each of the men standing on the picket line outside had been consulted in little groups by key members of what they had come to call "the people's cabinet". "It was spread like a Chinese whisper," said one. Many weren't happy with the idea of stopping the action but began to realise that they couldn't go on forever.

It was around 3am that those inside the office decided to announce they had ended it. For hours they had tried to contact Brynle Williams, but he could not be woken. The police were sent to get him and he was soon back at Stanlow.

By 5.23am, Mr Williams had called the crowd to the middle of the road to tell them the news. Till now, his method had been to announce they would be having a "board meeting" before standing on the back of his red pick-up truck and telling them the latest news. Yesterday morning, his statement was more low key.

He said: "After a discussion with all those concerned, we have decided to end this protest as of 5am. We have put the public through enough. I hope we have demonstrated that we are not just simple protesters. We have a just cause."

Standing in the smirry rain, Clive Swan, a farmer and key player, said they could have gone "on and on". "I am gutted. Everybody's gutted and saddened," he said. "We were saying that the protest at this gate had to be brought to a close. We felt we did not want it to turn ugly over the weekend by the wrong people for the wrong reasons and we averted that. It was just a perception that we had that extremists would turn up, that they would infiltrate and steer it to their way of thinking. This campaign is now handed over to the British public."

Mr Houghton, who said the talks within the office went on without a break, said: "We were getting the feeling that people were starting to get real hardship. We are family men and women and we have just got to draw the line at the end of the day. If people start really suffering - which I feel would have happened by Friday - then that public feeling and support would have gone.

"We knew we were not going to satisfy everybody. Our day is not finished, it is only just beginning. It will be a case of watch this space. I think it has shown everybody what we are capable of. When we pitched up here on Thursday, I think Mr Blair thought we were a bunch of rag bag country yokels and a few hauliers. What he didn't realise is that these are educated businessmen and shrewd."

Although it was finished, some protesters hung around, angry that it had all collapsed. But most drifted away, for breakfast, a good wash and a sleep. As one people's cabinet member, Tudor Williams, a haulier, turned on the ignition of his truck, the men who were left shouted: "See you on the road somewhere." He laughed and said: "I hope it won't be this one."

Ten questions: the oil companies confronted

The oil companies have been reluctant to speak about the blockades of the past week, so the Guardian yesterday posed 10 questions which BP and Texaco answered.

Did companies instruct drivers to take out their tankers?

Drivers appear to have been requested rather than instructed to go on their rounds, effectively giving many the option of not driving past the demonstrators. BP said drivers were consulted about the risks: "We were not prepared to expose drivers or their cargoes to being cut up on the road, driven off the road or being faced with hostile interference." Texaco said Wincanton, its fleet operator, was told to fulfill contracts.

If the drivers declined, what action did companies take?

Very little until Tony Blair read the riot act to senior executives on Wednesday. Companies are then believed to have threatened disciplinary action to get drivers back into their cabs.

BP said: "If the police or the drivers, or both, thought it unsafe for a cargo to leave the terminal, we would have considered it irresponsible to order the tankers out regardless. Since we did not issue point-blank orders, we did not meet point-blank refusal from our drivers." Texaco said it would not have been "justified" in ignoring "reasonable" concerns.

What, if any, intimidation did drivers face?

There are few reports of dri vers being attacked but some evidence of threats. A news crew caught a demonstrator telling a driver they had his picture and would put it on the internet.

BP said a tanker window was shattered at Stanlow. "We also have reports of missiles thrown at vehicles, drivers being told that protesters had their names and addresses and photos, and tankers being followed," it added. Texaco said drivers leaving Bristol and Poole had been forced to turn back.

Did companies ask the demonstrators to leave?

Apparently not. Some demonstrators were allowed to use buildings within refineries for meetings.

BP said: "Demonstrators [in] almost all cases confined themselves to public areas, so we had no right to ask them to leave." Texaco had "an ongoing dialogue".

Did companies threaten, or take, legal action against the demonstrators?

No. BP said the police were present and no roads blocked. "It may have been possible in some instances, if they were on private property, to consider suing for trespass, but we would first have had to identify individuals by name to obtain and serve writs - not an easy task in the face of heated demonstrations."

Texaco said: "Our lawyers advised that no effective legal action could have been taken to resolve the situation."

Did companies ask the police to provide escorts for tankers?

Texaco said yes. BP "spent a significant amount of time in discussion with the police at each terminal about how we might ensure the safe and uninterrupted conduct of our tanker crews leaving and re-entering the terminals".

Did companies accept any police offers of escorts?

Yes, said both Texaco and BP, but few tankers left refineries and Downing Street claimed companies needed "prodding" to take up the offers.

Did companies ask Tony Blair during Wednesday's Downing Street meeting for assistance?

No. Ministers maintain they were told why deliveries could not be made rather than how they would be made. BP said it had been in "regular contact" with ministers. Texaco would not comment.

Do companies support a reduction in fuel duty?

Yes. If taxes are high, it reduces their ability to put up prices to boost their own profits.

BP said yesterday: "We do not take a position on this issue. We simply act as a collector of tax." Texaco effectively repeated that line.

Did companies collude with the demonstrators?

BP denied a conspiracy. "There was no 'collusion' with anyone whatsoever," said the company. "Our only concern throughout this episode has been to carry out our business."

Texaco said: "We categorically deny this suggestion."

fields.headline: The choices facing the chancellor
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair rejected demands yesterday for a 1p cut in petrol duty, declaring that he was determined to avoid the humiliation of an "emergency budget".
fields.body:
Tony Blair rejected demands yesterday for a 1p cut in petrol duty, declaring that he was determined to avoid the humiliation of an "emergency budget".

But behind the scenes the prime minister may be tempted to put pressure on Gordon Brown to reduce the £36bn a year motorists pay to the exchequer. For every pound spent on petrol, the Treasury takes 71p.

There are two main ways in which the chancellor could cut fuel taxes in his next budget in March:

 He could lower the excise duty which was increased in line with inflation at the last budget, to 48.8p per litre of diesel and petrol. He may be reluctant to do this because he scrapped the fuel duty escalator in March which used to add 6% on top of the inflation rise;

 He could cut VAT on fuel, which is levied at the standard rate of 17.5%. This is virtually impossible because the chancellor would have to win the support of all members of the EU to levy VAT at a lower rate. Any cuts in the standard rate would have to apply across the board and would blow a huge hole in public finances.

Economists were divided yesterday on whether Mr Brown has the scope to cut fuel taxes. The rightwing Institute of Directors said he could cut the duty on unleaded petrol by 5p a litre. The exchequer would lose £2.7bn, but this would be made up by a windfall from North sea oil which has brought in a similar sum through the petroleum revenue tax and royalties.

Other economists say it would be foolish to cut the duty in the wake of Mr Brown's spending spree in July's comprehensive spending review. Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies said the North sea oil windfall would come to around £900m this year, far lower than the IoD estimate. He added that Britain's budget surplus of £6bn was due to turn into an £11bn deficit by 2003-04.

fields.headline: 'Come and see our plight, Mr Blair'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Brynle Williams never expected to be one of those people you see with a megaphone stuck to their mouths - he never liked those types much. But this week the farmer from north Wales found himself at the forefront of a populist direct action movement that brought the country to its knees.
fields.body:
Brynle Williams never expected to be one of those people you see with a megaphone stuck to their mouths - he never liked those types much. But this week the farmer from north Wales found himself at the forefront of a populist direct action movement that brought the country to its knees.

Mr Williams was pulled from his bed at 4am yesterday by a police officer after he slept through the numerous attempts made by his fellow protesters to get him by phone. He admits he was "well away with the fairies" when the decision was made to stand down the protest outside the Stanlow terminal.

But such was his ability to lead the collection of disaffected who had joined the protest that it was felt he was needed at the site before any announcement could be made. He is now so personally associated with the campaign that a postman delivered a letter to him care of the refinery.

An affable big fellow, Mr Williams finds it hard to stop talking or to refuse interviews. He stumbled into this role and now seems to enjoy it - though he says he is desperate to get back to farming.

Yesterday, after the last trucks and wagon trundled away from the smoke-belching stacks of the refinery, Mr Williams said he was going home to worm some sheep and bale some straw. He invited Tony Blair to visit him at his farm, saying: "He would see the reality of the situation, the relative humbleness as we live. We are just trying to scratch a living."

Mr Williams half owns/half leases a mixed, 200-acre farm with 200 cattle and 350 ewes, nestling below the Moel Famau hills near Mold, in Flintshire.

Yesterday he was being welcomed home as a hero. In the local post office in the village of Cilcain, two women were discussing the news that the protest was over. "They did a good thing but I think they stopped at the right time," said one as she picked up her morning paper. "Shall we have another protest - Brynle for prime minister?"

Last night, Mr Williams warned that the action would be reintroduced if the government failed to act to lower the price of fuel within 60 days.

"Today was not a defeat," he said. "The only time it's a defeat is when we are driven from here. We are not skulking in the corner and we have not been beaten. We are not going to lick our wounds."
