fields.headline: In brief
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: 91% in favour of protests
fields.body:
91% in favour of protests

The fuel crisis brought the biggest response yet for a BBC phone poll, on Jimmy Young's Radio 2 show. 157,489 listeners called in with 91% saying they supported the direct action.

Teachers may lose wages

Teachers who do not make every effort to get to work during the fuel crisis face being docked money from their salaries, a council warned yesterday.

Dudley council sent the warning to staff at all schools in the borough. Chief education officer Dick Colligan described the memo as standard issue in times of emergencies.

£102 for two gallons

Ferry operator P&O Stena Line has given employees free crossings to fill up with French petrol. The company introduced the offer as shortages threatened to keep staff at home.

London Underground was yesterday accepting bus tickets as a crisis measure. A spokesman said there was overcrowding with passengers up 5% on the 3m daily norm.

webTitle: The tankermen left in the cold

fields.headline: The tankermen left in the cold
fields.standfirst:
Back to work: Their bosses' u-turn and union pressure gave drivers no choice

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: It was a sudden u-turn by the oil companies in favour of pressing their tanker drivers to defy the protesters at the gates and get back on the road which helped to end the five-day fuel crisis, according to several hauliers outside the huge distribution depot in Avonmouth used by several oil companies.
fields.body:
It was a sudden u-turn by the oil companies in favour of pressing their tanker drivers to defy the protesters at the gates and get back on the road which helped to end the five-day fuel crisis, according to several hauliers outside the huge distribution depot in Avonmouth used by several oil companies.

"We wanted to give our support to the drivers. The employers were telling them they would face serious disciplinary action if they did not start work again," said Garry Bath yesterday as he stood with the last remaining members of what had been a massive protest.

To prove his point, he flagged down the next tanker in what had already become a flow of vehicles leaving the yard by midday. "The employers have been coming down hard on us," said the driver. "Our transport manager didn't threaten us with the sack in so many words this morning, but the message was clear."

The oil companies had been arguing that the drivers were being held back from the roads for their own safety, because of alleged intimidation by protesters, so their change of line put the tankermen at Avonmouth in a quandary. Although many sympathised with the fuel tax campaign, the national leadership of their union, the Transport and General Workers' Union, had condemned the protests in strong terms.

With employers now putting on the screws, the tankermen were in the cold - although the driver of the tanker flagged down by Mr Bath was quick to say local union officials had promised to protect them.

"They told us they would fight for anyone victimised or sacked for refusing to take their tanker out today," said the man as he looked down from the cab. He was unwilling to give his name.

The protesters at Avonmouth were also swayed by the word they were getting on their mobile phones that other groups around the country were calling off their demonstrations. "It never was a blockade," said Mr Bath, who owns two lorries. "We don't want to lose public support. We don't want to inconvenience the public or harm the NHS."

He acknowledged that the government had made no concession on fuel tax. "As yet," interrupted Pascal Hope, a driver in a Parcel Force uniform. "We've given the government 60 days to do something, hopefully in the autumn budget. If Blair doesn't do anything, this protest will happen again. It will definitely escalate."

Another lorry came out of the depot, this time not a tanker. Along the full length of its side it carried a banner saying, "If you support us, slow down." The protesters exchanged thumbs-up signs. But there was no sense of jubilation, more a feeling of anticlimax after the five days of protest and media attention.

Between 40 and 50 men assembled at around 10am to take the decision to end the protest. It was unanimous, Mr Bath said. A handful of protesters and two lorries would remain outside the depot for a few more hours "as a token gesture".

At Milford Haven in Wales, hauliers called off their protest outside the Elf/ Murco refinery in the mid-morning. Philip Knight, their spokesman, said he did not know of any pressure on tanker drivers to resume deliveries from the refinery.

"We decided to stop the protest in the interests of the safety of the public at large, of the tanker drivers and ourselves and our families," he said.

He sounded a little crestfallen. At midnight he and his mates had been cockahoop at the turnout of some 40 lorries and their owners and drivers who had braved a heavy drizzle to wait by the terminal's access road. Local people were coming out to chat and give them support.

Suddenly it was all over. As they drove home, Mr Knight said later by phone, there was a hitch when they heard on the radio that some of the oil companies were putting up the price of diesel by 4p, a proposal later withdrawn.

"It adds salt to the wounds," he said.

webTitle: Contrite Labour must learn from escape

fields.headline: Contrite Labour must learn from escape
fields.standfirst:
Ministers Chancellor faces crucial tax test

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair looked the most relieved man in Britain yesterday as the petrol crisis eased after the wheels had been close to falling off his government.
fields.body:
Tony Blair looked the most relieved man in Britain yesterday as the petrol crisis eased after the wheels had been close to falling off his government.

A senior Downing Street official, asked if the government would be adopting a "triumphalist" tone, wryly conceded: "I cannot imagine this has helped the government's standing."

The tone of the prime minister's third No 10 press conference in as many days was distinctly contrite after such a narrow escape. Mr Blair insisted his policies were right, but admitted he had been caught on the hop. Lessons will be learned about crisis management - and about monitoring disputes before they become crises.

The more fundamental question is whether it has done long-term harm to new Labour's hard won reputation for competent economic management, or whether the crisis headlines will evaporate almost as quickly as the crisis itself developed last weekend.

The short-term damage to Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and John Prescott - and lesser ministers in the crossfire - is obvious. As Mr Blair admitted, they were caught unaware by the speed of the blockades' impact on a "just in time" society whose petrol stations and supermarkets hold just enough stock to get by for a day or so.

In the first misjudgment, Downing Street and other Whitehall departments thought the protests would fade away rather than spread when they started at the end of last week.

Mr Blair realised there was a serious problem only on Monday night when demonstrators blocked his way to a Chinese restaurant in Hull for dinner with Mr Prescott. The following day he pulled out of a regional tour and trip to the TUC in Glasgow to return to the Downing Street bunker.

Britain was running out of fuel and heading for a shutdown potentially more disastrous than the winter of discontent or the three-day week during Edward Heath's era.

Only on Wednesday did it finally appear as if the government was getting to grips with the crisis as Mr Blair summoned oil industry executives to read the riot act to the global corporations accused of colluding with the demonstrators.

It has been a bad week for government dignity in a year when it has been battered by events as disparate as asylum seekers, NHS cash, leaked Blair memos, cashpoint fines and Euan Blair's GCSE celebrations. The only upside of the fuel crisis is that it has distracted public attention from the tottering Greenwich dome.

Potentially worse for the PM is the accusation, levelled by yesterday's Daily Telegraph, that the crisis was final proof that Mr Blair's is an arrogant government that does not listen to the kind of unBlairite small businessmen who manned the picket lines, to ordinary voters, or even to its own MPs.

"We've been warning Gordon about petrol prices for months now," one minister muttered this week. Despite Mr Blair's repeated refusal to bow to intimidation by small unrepresentative groups, many Labour MPs are certain that concessions will have to be made inside the 60-day deadline imposed by truckers.

That will be a crucial test for the chancellor. As with the single parent benefit revolt in 1997 and this year's 75p increase in the basic pension, plenty of MPs will be whispering that Mr Brown is too powerful and too inflexible for the government's own good. "Tony should rein him in," they will say again.

The arrogance charge - rejected yesterday by Mr Blair - is more dangerous when tied to William Hague's "stealth tax" jibe. The prime minister, chancellor and their colleagues have done their best to explain that world prices are the main culprit and that the extra petrol taxes they imposed in 1997-99 were of Tory origin, caused by the Tory debts they had to clear.

Last March's decision to scrap the fuel escalator inherited from the Tories, and used during Labour's early years, has been cited as evidence that the government is listening. The argument has convinced few voters.

The Downing Street machine has sought scapegoats: the pickets, the police, and the Opec oil producers. It has also resorted to shroud waving, getting the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to put the NHS into the firing line. The tabloids will attack him for playing politics with the sick. But it worked. Along with the prospect that the army would be sent in the risk of pickets being blamed for deaths helped tip them - and the tabloids - away from further confrontation.

Yet ministers persistently refused to go to war, at least in public, with the major oil companies, the one obvious scapegoat whose foot dragging, self-interested tactics could have united pickets, public and ministers against them. Yesterday's own goal by Esso in raising prices before performing a swift U-turn showed what scope was there.

Downing Street optimists hope that once voters have reflected on the dispute they will turn against small groups of politically motivated pickets with a vocally anti-Labour agenda.

There is even some hope that the crisis will help make voters less car dependent as they discover the joys of fast-moving buses, bikes and unpolluted pavements. But they are almost certainly being over-optimistic.

Demonstrators tapped into public resentment against the highest petrol prices in Europe when Britain has North Sea oil.

By backing down yesterday before causing the widespread disruption just round the corner, they deprived Mr Blair of the great victory some in No 10 hoped he could achieve.

webTitle: Lesson for Blair in blow to Jospin

fields.headline: Lesson for Blair in blow to Jospin
fields.standfirst:
France: PM's popularity dives despite 'positive' handling of crisis

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair beware: despite winding up France's fuel price protest to the satisfaction of most of those involved, the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has just seen his popularity take the biggest month-on-month knock ever recorded for a French prime minister.
fields.body:
Tony Blair beware: despite winding up France's fuel price protest to the satisfaction of most of those involved, the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has just seen his popularity take the biggest month-on-month knock ever recorded for a French prime minister.

Two different opinion polls, taken at the height of the protest towards the end of last week, show the socialist prime minister's approval rating has plummeted by between 18 and 20 percentage points from the record average of around 60% he has enjoyed since taking office three years ago.

"We're not used to blows like this," said a Socialist party source. "When you've got the impression you've handled a crisis positively, not let the situation go seriously bad on you, shown you can negotiate, avoided the use of force, you might not expect congratulations but you don't expect this kind of slapdown."

By French standards, it was indeed a crisis well handled: although taken by surprise by the scale of the protest, and appearing uncertain at first, the French government listened to the hauliers, farmers, taxi drivers and others, offered each group some - but not too much - relief, and then sat out a brief storm when they asked for more.

Whether British public opinion will feel Mr Blair has been as receptive remains to be seen. If not, he may be even more severely judged.

But equally worryingly for the British prime minister, French pollsters say the dramatic collapse in Mr Jospin's popularity was due not so much to the way he handled the crisis as to the fact that it happened at all.

According to Stephane Rozès of the polling agency CSA Opinion, which carried out a separate survey suggesting some 88% of the French population backed the protesters, the extraordinary popularity of the blockade - and the negative verdict against Mr Jospin - were a protest by proxy.

"People were saying, we don't fancy a future with sky-high pump prices either," Mr Rozès said. "They identified with the professionals taking the protest action, made a clear connection with them through the price of fuel. They expect the government to do something to help."

A Socialist party analyst, Henri Weber, agreed. "At a time when the French are expecting to benefit from the fruits of three years of solid economic growth, they find themselves facing the third global oil crisis," he said.

"It's understandable. The massive hike in the price of petrol seems to them to have wiped out all that they've gained over the past couple of years in terms of tax cuts, shorter working hours, falling unemployment and higher income levels."

Popular discontent with the French prime minister can also be laid at the door of a variety of domestic problems, in particular the controversy over Mr Jospin's plan to offer the turbulent island of Corsica limited powers to run its own affairs, an issue so divisive that it triggered the resignation of the popular interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, last month.

But the high pump prices seem simply to have acted as a lightning rod for a widespread feeling of discontent that the proceeds of France's economic boom have not so far reached the average French person's pocket.

Mr Jospin is now urgently consulting his advisers about ways to calm the anger and allow the French as a whole to feel they are benefiting from the economic upturn, either by announcing lower fuel prices through a cut in state fuel taxes of by some other compensatory tax mechanism. Judging by the French opinion polls, Mr Blair may want to do the same.

fields.headline: Copycat chaos still spreading
fields.standfirst:
Europe: Anger flares as leaders stand firm against tax cuts

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Continental Europe's fuel crisis worsened yesterday, with countrywide protests in Germany and calls for demonstrations from Spain to Hungary as governments stood firm in rejecting tax cuts.
fields.body:
Continental Europe's fuel crisis worsened yesterday, with countrywide protests in Germany and calls for demonstrations from Spain to Hungary as governments stood firm in rejecting tax cuts.

But last night in Belgium truck drivers struck an agreement with the government to release their stranglehold on fuel depots and streets across the country.

German oil refineries were hit for the first time and up to 1,000 truckers and farmers jammed traffic in the northern city of Hanover.

But Chancellor Gerhard Schröder said he would not surrender to demands to reduce fuel taxes, as the French government did last week to the dismay of its EU partners.

Protests also flared in Sweden, Greece and Netherlands, as commentators noted a "harmonisation" of protests across the EU. Trouble is expected in Ireland today.

Yesterday, Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, warned striking drivers to end their protests after five days which have seen the centre of Brussels reduced to a ghost town.

"The government will not tolerate that a minority of truckers exposes our country, our people, our economy and our industry to further damage," he warned.

Last night the tough stance appeared to have paid off when the protests were suddenly called off.

One factor may have been the way Belgian police blamed two deaths on the demonstrations as motorists tried to drive on the wrong side of road to get around roadblocks. Emergency services had reported mounting difficulties.

Truckers also cut road links into Germany, the Netherlands and France. Action at the North sea port of Zeebrugge prevented British drivers from taking their vehicles off ferries.

Further afield, in Budapest, lorry drivers announced protests after the Hungarian oil and gas company, MOL, said it was raising petrol and diesel prices.

In Madrid, the Association of Spanish Farmers and Ranchers called for demonstrations next week.

Irish motorists, meanwhile, rushed to fill their tanks as truckers prepared to stage a 24-hour stoppage and protests over fuel prices from midnight.

The Irish Road Haulage Association said drivers would push ahead with go-slow convoys on key national and urban routes after the government rejected their demand to cut the diesel fuel tax by a third.

What the foreign papers say:

Libération, France
Will Tony Blair win his bet? On Tuesday, the British prime minister promised to tame the fuel revolt within 24 hours with the help of the police. But Britain continues to sink into paralysis. Since the beginning of this crisis, the prime minister has played for high stakes at the risk of alienating public opinion which is massively behind the protesters - a BBC poll showed 78% of the British support the demonstrators. Tony Blair has seriously underestimated the strength of the movement.

Berliner Zeitung
While the protests may not be over, Tony Blair has already won a "first-stage victory" in the crisis over fuel prices. Most Britons do not want a repetition of the winter of 1978-79. Additionally, though, doubts have spread over the motivations of the leaders of the blockade. As much as people dislike the high tax on fuel, they realise that the farmers, fishermen and lorry drivers are not really protesting because of fuel. The fishermen and the farmers scarcely pay any fuel tax. The long distance lorry drivers would like continental fuel prices, but do not want to do without the low income and corporation tax in Britain.

La Repubblica, Italy
Tony Blair has sensed the smell of war and has assumed emergency powers. An English prime minister can never resist the temptation of testing his courage in the fire of social conflict. In general, it is an infallible way of seducing the country. Fifteen years ago Thatcher emerged victorious from the smoking ruins of the glorious miners. Blair does not intend to show any greater clemency to a handful of demonstrators.

Washington Post
Although the prime minister has tried to demonise the demonstrators, most Britons clearly sympathise with them and agree with their basic point that gasoline prices are too high. The demonstrators may be shutting down one of the world's greatest industrial powers, but they are a laid-back group of revolutionaries.

Irish motorists, meanwhile, rushed to fill their tanks as truckers prepared to stage a 24-hour stoppage and protests over fuel prices from midnight. The Irish Road Haulage Association said drivers would push ahead with go-slow convoys on key national and urban routes after the government rejected their demand to cut the diesel fuel tax by a third. What the foreign papers say: Libération, France Will Tony Blair win his bet? On Tuesday, the British prime minister promised to tame the fuel revolt within 24 hours with the help of the police. But Britain continues to sink into paralysis. Since the beginning of this crisis, the prime minister has played for high stakes at the risk of alienating public opinion which is massively behind the protesters - a BBC poll showed 78% of the British support the demonstrators. Tony Blair has seriously underestimated the strength of the movement. Berliner Zeitung While the protests may not be over, Tony Blair has already won a "first-stage victory" in the crisis over fuel prices. Most Britons do not want a repetition of the winter of 1978-79. Additionally, though, doubts have spread over the motivations of the leaders of the blockade. As much as people dislike the high tax on fuel, they realise that the farmers, fishermen and lorry drivers are not really protesting because of fuel. The fishermen and the farmers scarcely pay any fuel tax. The long distance lorry drivers would like continental fuel prices, but do not want to do without the low income and corporation tax in Britain. La Repubblica, Italy Tony Blair has sensed the smell of war and has assumed emergency powers. An English prime minister can never resist the temptation of testing his courage in the fire of social conflict. In general, it is an infallible way of seducing the country. Fifteen years ago Thatcher emerged victorious from the smoking ruins of the glorious miners. Blair does not intend to show any greater clemency to a handful of demonstrators. Washington Post Although the prime minister has tried to demonise the demonstrators, most Britons clearly sympathise with them and agree with their basic point that gasoline prices are too high. The demonstrators may be shutting down one of the world's greatest industrial powers, but they are a laid-back group of revolutionaries.

fields.headline: Out of tune?
fields.standfirst:
Blair's not even speaking the same language

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: It was the prime minister's third press conference in as many days. He was nearly 40 minutes late, possibly because he had just heard that some petrol companies had decided that yesterday was the perfect time to stick another 2p on a litre - timing which even Mr Peter "Dome" Mandelson, a man who appears to have all the public relations skills of Pot Noodle, would have eschewed.
fields.body:
It was the prime minister's third press conference in as many days. He was nearly 40 minutes late, possibly because he had just heard that some petrol companies had decided that yesterday was the perfect time to stick another 2p on a litre - timing which even Mr Peter "Dome" Mandelson, a man who appears to have all the public relations skills of Pot Noodle, would have eschewed.

The prime minister arrived so quickly and silently in the State Dining Room that we hardly noticed he was there before he began to speak. He was in front of a portrait of George II, the last English king to lead his troops into battle, an example which Mr Blair appears not to have decided to follow this week.

But there is a link; King George was famously out of tune with the mood of the people. However, he had an excuse in that his first language was German. The prime minister himself speaks Blairish.

Actually, Blairish is not so much a language as a cast of mind. Blairish is inclusive. It seeks consensus. Nothing is asserted; instead the Blairish speaker precedes his wisdom with remarks such as "I think everyone will agree..." or, "you know, I hope people will reflect carefully on events..." Someone asked if he saw the apparent ending of the crisis as a defeat of the "forces of conservatism", which play the same role for the present government as the Daleks did in Dr Who.

But there was no gloating. "I don't think it's a question of defeating anyone," he said vaguely, in an emollient phrase lifted straight from the Blairish lexicon. His eyes constantly roamed round the room looking for agreement. Thatcherish was the language of confrontation, or as your Latin teacher might have put it, "question expecting the answer 'sod off'." A sentence in Blairish, in contrast, is supposed to invite a low mumble of agreement.

He did look very tired and under terrific strain, though people who had attended Wednesday's performance said he looked a lot better than yesterday. The temptation to shout "Yes! Result!" at the top of his voice must have been great, but he resisted it manfully. He refused to gloat. He realised that hauliers had faced a very difficult time with their increased costs (was there a hint here that his life would be a lot easier without having a cackling Silas Marner figure next door, grabbing every bawbee he can from the lorry drivers, farmers, manufacturers, widows and orphans of Britain?) but he was sure we'd agree that everyone always wanted to cut taxes and raise public spending at the same time.

He even refused to plead that he was protecting the environment, always a temptation for politicians. "In a rural area, the price of petrol is an issue, and it's no good us not saying that it isn't an issue." I was reminded of a man rediscovering the joys of not banging his head against a brick wall.

Then a French reporter asked: "You say that 'no government worthy of the name could give in to such a protest'. How is the French government supposed to take that?"

A look of mild panic crossed the prime minister's face, and for a fleeting second the eyes seemed to wander off in two different directions. The Blairish language simply can't cope with criticism; it doesn't have the vocabulary. "I am speaking only for us," he rambled, "some of the measures taken there have been rather different from the ones which have appeared in the newspapers there, I am not criticising the French government..."

Of course, of course. Then he was gone and we filed out as George II gazed majestically down on us. It was, by the way, the French against whom he led his lads into battle.

fields.headline: OK, keep on trucking
fields.standfirst:
The government is refusing to say a green word for fear of further enraging Mondeo man

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Outside Downing Street after the prime minister's press conference, a lone figure in shorts was waving a remarkably polite placard: "Sustainable fuel. Please help us breathe!" But he was all alone. Where are Reclaim the Streets when you need them? (The Socialist Workers turned up outside oil refineries to join the pickets, but the forces of conservatism told them to push off.) Where was this great green movement that trashes GM crops and burrows under motorways? Where were those who blockaded ports over veal calves? With the government refusing to say a green word for fear of further enraging Mondeo man, there was never a better time for putting the green case. But the Green party were busy passing an emergency motion at their conference calling for no cut in fuel prices, instead of supporting the government's green fuel policies in public demonstrations.
fields.body:
Outside Downing Street after the prime minister's press conference, a lone figure in shorts was waving a remarkably polite placard: "Sustainable fuel. Please help us breathe!" But he was all alone. Where are Reclaim the Streets when you need them? (The Socialist Workers turned up outside oil refineries to join the pickets, but the forces of conservatism told them to push off.) Where was this great green movement that trashes GM crops and burrows under motorways? Where were those who blockaded ports over veal calves? With the government refusing to say a green word for fear of further enraging Mondeo man, there was never a better time for putting the green case. But the Green party were busy passing an emergency motion at their conference calling for no cut in fuel prices, instead of supporting the government's green fuel policies in public demonstrations.

It took remarkably few of the forces of conservatism to bring the country to a halt - Channel 4 is estimating a maximum of 2,500 pickets, Downing Street think 2000 is generous. Most of these "intimidators" were groups of about six middle-aged men in deck chairs. Never in the field of political conflict was so much harm done to so many by so few. They could have been swamped by Swampies, but none came down from the trees. The farmers and hauliers went unchallenged by the other, greener Britain. Indeed the government has been remarkably friendless in this crisis. The TUC and especially the T and G have been staunch, trying to get its drivers out on the road. The CBI, to its eternal shame, was pretty much endorsing the picketters. Even the Mirror ratted and joined the Sun's white van man, along with all the rightwing press. What was Radio 5 Live doing calling all listeners to phone in if they spotted a tanker on the move anywhere? Compare Tony Blair's stand with Mrs Thatcher's "bravery" over the miners, when she had virtually the whole press and over-whelming public support behind her.

Now the spotlight shines straight into the faces of the oil companies and the disgraceful part they played in all this. Imagine if it had been T and G pickets outside their refineries. They'd have had court orders, emergency drivers and all legal weapons that prevent wild-cat and secondary action. Remember the speed and strength with which Rupert Murdoch drove his drivers across genuinely terrifying pickets at Wapping? Instead the oil men sat on their fatcat backsides purring quietly for two days while the crisis deepened. Uniquely gentle employers, they said they wouldn't dream of putting pressure on their drivers to do anything they didn't want to do. How unlike the oil companies who have worked so hard to undermine Kyoto and the forthcoming global warming conference in the Hague.

Since the Opec price rises over the past 18 months, oil company profits have doubled. They have already made around £35bn globally. The protesters focus on getting their hands on Gordon Brown's possible windfall tax revenues that might or might not amount to £1bn this year. This will never be clear-cut, as people and companies spending more on petrol spend less elsewhere so the treasury's tax take may fall in other areas. But what of the mighty oil company revenues? What loud cheers would go up at the next budget if Mr Brown announced a heavy windfall tax on their extra profits, as he did with the privatised industries on coming to power. Why not take all their extra price-rise profits and use it on transport, with immediate bus and train fare subsidies?

The chancellor already has the power to fix the petroleum revenue tax on North sea oil at whatever rate he wishes, so he certainly could claw back all the extra price-gains from there. It was only a joke, but when the Downing Street spokesman was asked yesterday what powers the government could acquire to force the oil companies to send out their tankers, he said they could get the emergency power to nationalise them. Everyone laughed heartily.

But the mood in Downing Street is fuming with anger at the oil men, questioning the way they acted again as a seamless cartel. When the prime minister called them to Downing Street again yesterday afternoon he asked steely questions about their inexplicably soft management style and they floundered. Esso's shameless attempt at a price rise was a gift he could not have dreamed they would hand him. The oil companies stand to make a handsome profit out of the crisis over the next few days, with professional estimates suggesting greatly increased overall consumption as people nervously keep their tanks topped up until the panic wears off. Cui bono?

Cheering on their shock troops at the refinery gates, Conservatives imagine that suddenly the political game has changed. William Hague detects a new taxpayers rebellion, "an earthquake in the political argument about tax". Wrong. His popular seismology has never been good, however out of touch he claims the government is. Just wait until he and Michael Portillo finally produce their tax-and-spend plans and then the real debate begins. All the government's private polling, the long-running British Social Attitudes Survey and other polls show what people want most is better health, education and transport: they are willing to pay for it (up to quite what point is less easy to gauge). Watch out this weekend for daft opinion polls of the kind the BBC shamelessly used last night asking if people wanted less tax on petrol. Of course they do. No one ever wants to pay more tax without any other proposition put to them. But ask subtler questions and you get better answers.

The forthcoming head-on ideological tax clash with the Tories will be a healthy airing of too many things Mr Brown has tried to do by stealth. This crisis has made him publicly expound the virtue and necessity of tax more openly than before. Now he will have to explain to voters that they get what they pay for, no more magic tricks that suggest free lunches for all. A cut in fuel tax at the budget would look weak - in which case the government must talk green loudly leading up to the Hague climate change conference.

Now this rightwing rebellion is over, it is time to consider whether the real Mondeo man would prefer fairer income taxes than stealthy purchase taxes that hit those on middle incomes and the poorest hardest. An appeal for the rich to carry a fairer share of the burden at the next budget would be popular. As for the government's ratings, Jospin's fell 16-20% after he caved in, despite apparent popular support for tax cuts at the time.

Labour may take a temporary knock, but competence and strength are the values that count - ask John Major. This week also hit the lowest unemployment in 20 years and the lowest inflation for 27. All this will be blip not slip.

webTitle: Leader: The revolt has reached the end of the road

fields.headline: Common sense creeps in
fields.standfirst:
The revolt has reached the end of the road

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: It feels a bit more normal. Not business as usual, we are a long way from that. But the abyss into which the country seemed to be staring on Wednesday has suddenly retreated.
fields.body:
It feels a bit more normal. Not business as usual, we are a long way from that. But the abyss into which the country seemed to be staring on Wednesday has suddenly retreated. Common sense - or was it political nous? - asserted itself on the picket lines; tried and trusted forms of behaviour, such as meetings and negotiation, came back into fashion.

It is far from over. At the rate tankers were moving yesterday, private motorists may have to wait till well into next week before they can guarantee finding a local garage with working pumps. The casualty count may rise before it falls, literally as well as figuratively. Alan Milburn was accused of exaggeration yesterday over the state of the health service; but he knows the critics would turn on him if he seemed complacent. Meanwhile, a note of panic is audible among business leaders, including the big hauliers. Interest groups that have lately winked at breach of contract and the obstruction of market forces suddenly woke up. Their anxiety has not made them any more intellectually coherent - witness the economic illiteracy that passes for policy at the Institute of Directors. But the government may take comfort from the acid remarks of the chambers of commerce about Big Oil's responsibility.

Except it is way too soon to try to settle that account, the oil companies still holding trump cards. Do puny national governments even hold sway any longer over these global energy corporations? The arrogance with which Esso and TotalFinaElf sought to increase pump prices when they were not even delivering fuel was indicative even if it proved counterproductive. Revisionism beckons for Third Way enthusiasts for globalisation. And not them alone. The past few days posed questions high and wide. The environmental project that flowered in Rio and Kyoto is parched. Friends of the Earth may say the high politics of this dispute is about climate change, but getting ordinary people to change their daily behaviour for the sake of the planet now looks more difficult than ever. The constitution has been holed. The state suddenly looks unreliable, its fiscal authority challenged. Smugglers (and collusive suppliers) have long since imposed their limits on tax on tobacco. Perhaps we are now there on fuel.

In the televised press conference that this week became a daily event, the prime minister tried to reserve for the state the unique job of balancing interests while taking the longer view. Mr Blair offered an elegant statement of the case but, his focus on the short-run restoration of gas-guzzling normality, there are concessions in the air, despite Jack Straw's bid to close the stable door by examining how oil supplies might be secured in future. The blockaders' sense of timing was acute: if there is no single political intelligence behind this, the mobile telephone certainly seems to secure remarkable agreement and - the stragglers notwithstanding - discipline. Mr Blair now talks of listening as well as standing firm. Delegations are to be received; representations taken into account. Should he, in the spirit of dialogue, summon parliament? Tony Blair's response yesterday, that the nation's preoccupation is fuel supply, is probably right - he might have added that fully fledged representative institutions are open for business in Cardiff and Edinburgh. But banners on the picket lines alleging representation is wrecked are more than reactionary banter. The protesters have had their say. MPs should speak up for those who have gone unheard during this dispute - the carless, the poor, the urban majority.

fields.headline: Poujadisme 2000
fields.standfirst: The hauliers and farmers noisily trying to uphold their rights this week owe much, in spirit, to a certain 50s Frenchman, says Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The hauliers and farmers noisily trying to uphold their rights this week owe much, in spirit, to a certain 50s Frenchman, says Julian Glover.
fields.body:
What has an obscure French bookseller from the 1950s called Pierre Poujade got to do with the petrol crisis in Britain? Quite a lot, actually, if you believe what journalists have been writing over the past few days.

The Guardian's own Polly Toynbee described the protestors as "a popular front of poujadist small businessmen", the newspaper then talked of "a rising of the poujadist self-employed" in a leader and the Daily Telegraph countered by attacking the Guardian for using the word at all. But why has Poujade caused such a fuss?

It's certainly not because Poujade has been here in person spreading books and rebellion. He faded from even the French political front line quite some time ago. Instead, his name is summoned up because (to a debatable extent) he personifies the political philosophy which lies behind this week's revolt.

How? Well, like this week's protestors, Poujade was a conservative who saw the need to take radical action. In 1953 he was behind a shopkeepers' strike in a small French town against high taxation and, inspired by the success of this, he established a national union of small traders: Poujadisme.

He found backing from all sorts of reactionary groups who found their place in society under threat from economic modernisation. His triumph came in the 1956 national French elections, when Poujadist candidates won 52 of the 595 assembly seats. The success didn't last though - the party lost them all in 1958.

Even this brief spell under the spotlight alarmed the country's elite by showing that middle France - just like middle England this week - cannot be taken for granted. Though Poujadisme has faded (many supporters joined more overtly right wing parties) his name has come to be associated with any revolt by the underlings of a capitalist economy.

So though they might not have known it, the truck drivers who blocked the way out of oil refineries were, without a doubt, true poujadists.

Even this brief spell under the spotlight alarmed the country's elite by showing that middle France - just like middle England this week - cannot be taken for granted. Though Poujadisme has faded (many supporters joined more overtly right wing parties) his name has come to be associated with any revolt by the underlings of a capitalist economy. So though they might not have known it, the truck drivers who blocked the way out of oil refineries were, without a doubt, true poujadists.

fields.headline: Charm lessons for Eurocrats
fields.standfirst: EC vice-president Neil Kinnock's got a fresh target in his sights, says Andrew Osborn in Brussels. The days of the surly European civil servant are numbered
fields.trailText: EC vice-president Neil Kinnock's got a fresh target in his sights, says Andrew Osborn in Brussels. The days of the surly European civil servant are numbered.
fields.body:
Haughty French Eurocrats beware: bluff Welshman Neil Kinnock this week unveiled tough new rules to put the civil back into the European civil service and he's not taking any prisoners.

In future officials from the 18,000 strong European Commission (EC) will have to mind their manners when they speak to the public or, in extreme circumstances, they could find themselves in court.

They have been instructed to be "courteous, objective and impartial" when dealing with the public and ordered to reply to any letters of enquiry within 15 days and in the appropriate official EU language (there are 11). Die-hard Eurocrats who are unwilling to change are unimpressed and feel patronised.

The courtesy drive is a mainstay of Mr Kinnock's one-man mission to reform the EC and is an attempt to consign the popular image of remote free-loading Eurocrats to the past. Mr Kinnock is EC vice-president and charged with overhauling its outmoded working practices, which were modelled on the French civil service of the 1950s.

Part of the problem, aides explain, is that the 15-nation club employs so many different nationalities, who all have different ideas of how they should behave.

"There are member states whose culture doesn't include answering the phone and where the civil service is not viewed as a public service. There is no single culture and that's the problem," says one reform-minded official.

"You might think of Greece, Spain, France and Italy," he whispers conspiratorially before clamming up, "and this is a very effective way of weeding people out."

Mr Kinnock's drive to spruce up the image of the frequently derided institution will also target telephone manner. Officials will be forced to give their name and department when they answer the phone and told to return calls promptly.

The new rules, which are legally binding, will come into force in November and will be buttressed by staff training though, according to Mr Kinnock, this will not include American-style "how to smile" courses.

The general public will be able to see what is expected of officials by consulting a glossy brochure and a complaints officer will be appointed in each of the commission's 20 departments.

If a member of the public feels they have been seriously mistreated they have the option, for the first time, to take the EC or an individual official to the Luxembourg-based European court of justice.

The only alternative up to now was to draft a letter of complaint to one central EU ombudsman who could pursue the matter and "a code of good behaviour" simply did not exist.

The EC receives thousands of telephone calls and enquiries each week and Brussels is heaving with lobbyists and interest groups whose stock in trade is to extract information from officials and influence decision-making. Information on eligibility for the EU's array of subsidies and grants and future policy initiatives means the switchboard in Brussels is always busy. But in the future officials will have to tread more carefully.

"If you phone someone up and get a hysterical official who tells you that you're bonkers and gives you short shrift then, in an extreme case, that official could be taken to court," says one EU official.

Mr Kinnock, who has had plenty of practice in knocking heads together as leader of the Labour party when he clamped down on the "loony left", is now engaged upon the biggest modernisation programme in the EC's 43-year history.

He strongly denied this week, however, that the new rules were prompted by a flood of complaints from the public and was at pains to stress that the vast majority of Eurocrats are competent and polite.

"We are far from being inundated by complaints. We believe that the introduction of the code is evidence of our desire to follow best practice," he explained.

The powerful trade unions which protect Eurocrats' rights have dismissed the code as "a publicity stunt" and argue that their members are already following its rules.

But Mr Kinnock, whose own credibility depends on the success of the reforms, is unlikely to leave it at that. New measures to tighten up staff training and discipline are expected before the end of the year and a "whistleblowers' charter" - which will allow the likes of Paul van Buitenen who triggered last year's fraud scandal to have his say - is in the pipeline.

webTitle: Rights challenge on prison phone calls

fields.headline: Rights challenge on prison phone calls
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Four prisoners have begun a high court challenge under the Human Rights Act to a system for controlling their phone calls, which the prison service plans to extend to all English and Welsh jails.
fields.body:
Four prisoners have begun a high court challenge under the Human Rights Act to a system for controlling their phone calls, which the prison service plans to extend to all English and Welsh jails.

The four, long-stay prisoners at Full Sutton maximum security prison in York, claim the system breaches their right to privacy under article 8 of the European convention on human rights. The system replaces phonecards, which the service says are targets for bullies; it also wants to be able to stop prisoners intimidating witnesses or phoning people unhappy at receiving their calls.

The system, which has been piloted at Full Sutton and at Frankland prison in Durham, works by giving inmates an account number to call up to 20 pre-approved numbers, but prisoners say they dislike it because when their call is answered a computer announcement states that it is coming from the prison.

Lucy Gampell, of the Federation of Prisoners' Families Support Groups, said: "One-third of children with a parent in prison don't know where the parent is. If a young child is confused and hangs up, the prisoner is told that the call was refused. There are also young people who haven't told their housemates they have a parent in prison."

The announcement objected to has been suspended for several months for business reasons, but British Telecom will install a new system next month or in November, which the service proposes to extend.

The prisoners' high court challenge has been adjourned until this system is operational.

fields.headline: Hostage crisis: major at fault
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The British officer at the heart of the Sierra Leone hostage crisis faces disciplinary action for making "a grave mistake" in allowing his patrol to be captured by the West Side Boys.
fields.body:
The British officer at the heart of the Sierra Leone hostage crisis faces disciplinary action for making "a grave mistake" in allowing his patrol to be captured by the West Side Boys.

An internal army report given yesterday to Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, went some way towards explaining how 11 well-trained and armed British soldiers could be overwhelmed by the indisciplined militia.

The officer had been expecting the village of Magbeni to be free of West Side Boys but within five minutes they had been surrounded by 25 volatile and excitable members of the renegade militia. A truck, on which twin machine guns were mounted, was then positioned behind the Royal Irish regiment patrol.

Their officer, Major Alan Marshall, who was wounded in the incident, judged the position to be untenable. The MoD has not revealed why he went to Magbeni in the first place, but said last night it was still talking to him and would be able to further clarify the sequence of events tomorrow.

The MoD said Maj Marshall would be dealt with by the commander of UK land forces, General Sir Michael Jackson. A court martial has been ruled out because military law was not broken, but there are other avenues for disciplinary action. Some form of reprimand, which would go on his record, is expected.

In a statement issued last night the MoD said Maj Marshall "made an error of professional judgment in diverting from a planned and authorised journey so as to make an unauthorised visit to the village of Magbeni on the banks of the Rokel creek".

The troops' capture was a humiliation for the army and cost the life of an SAS soldier in the rescue mission last weekend.

The Royal Irish regiment was in Sierra Leone to train its army to fight the rebel Revolutionary United Front. As part of the regiment's defence responsibility, Maj Marshall had been authorised to visit a Jordanian contingent of the UN peacekeeping force on August 25. On the way back, he diverted to Magbeni, known to be a West Side Boys base.

"On arrival, they encountered West Side Boys who became excited and aggressive. They moved a truck with twin machine guns behind the patrol vehicle.

"In all, about 25 West Side Boys were present. Very quickly the patrol was enveloped and the soldiers disarmed. The major was struck. The whole incident lasted five minutes," said the MoD's report.

They lost their assault rifles and three Land Rovers, one of which was equipped with a powerful machine gun.

Five soldiers were released before the army decided to go in on Sunday, fearing for the lives of the remaining six after the West Side Boys began carrying out mock executions.

The MoD accepted that liaison with the Jordanians was a necessary and normal part of preparing defences by obtaining intelligence. Orders will now be changed to make it clear that diversions are not acceptable in such a volatile situation.

webTitle: How Spanish boy, 12, died at Omagh

fields.headline: How Spanish boy, 12, died at Omagh
fields.standfirst:
Three local children killed alongside youngster on exchange trip

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: He was born on November 12 1985, a sturdy, brown-haired Spanish boy whose life was snuffed out less than 13 years later hundreds of miles from his home in a crazy, murderous dispute about which he knew nothing.
fields.body:
He was born on November 12 1985, a sturdy, brown-haired Spanish boy whose life was snuffed out less than 13 years later hundreds of miles from his home in a crazy, murderous dispute about which he knew nothing.

He was Fernando Blasco Baselga. But at Lisnagelly army barracks in Omagh, Co Tyrone, he was body number 13 when his mother, Lucretia, arrived from Madrid to identified him formally.

His luck, the deputy state coroner, Derek Carson, said, had deserted him. Had a small piece of shrapnel ripped through another part of his body, so superficial were his other injuries, he would have survived. But it sliced into his spinal cord, below his left ear. Death was inevitable.

He was one of 29 people to die in Northern Ireland's worst ever atrocity, terrible happenstance bringing them together soon after 3pm in Omagh on August 15 1998, close to a stolen maroon Vauxhall Cavalier containing 500lb of home-made explosives. Another 300 were injured in the Real IRA's so-called mission.

Somehow the prosaic details of such a short life were overwhelming yesterday as the coroner, John Leckey, began to deal with the individual circumstances of each victim's death. So recent a birthdate was shocking.

Bureaucracy dealt with the death efficiently yesterday. There were heartfelt expression of sympathy, but the legal niceties were over in around a dozen minutes, one for each year of his life.

His family stayed away. But their legal representative wanted to know from Dr Carson whether he would have suffered. No, he replied, he would have been immediately unconscious. The vital functions, as he called them, would have quickly shut down.

Paula Mahon, a youth leader from Buncrana, Co Donegal, had known Fernando all his life. She was a friend of his family. She had organised the annual visit of 30 Spanish children to Buncrana, where they stayed with host families while learning English over the summer. They had been on an outing to a museum when they were caught up in the murderous conflict.

Ms Mahon, spared the ordeal of having to give oral evidence, had initially identified the boy, and his youth leader, Rocio Abad Ramos, 23, body number 11 at the barracks. Miss Ramos's neck had snapped as she was thrown forward in the blast.

As well as 30 Spanish children, three leaders and 10 children from Buncrana had gone to Omagh that day. Three local children died.

The families with whom the Spaniards stayed across the border in Co Donegal rushed to Omagh leisure centre yesterday. But their inquests were unexpectedly taken before lunch and so their wishes to show their last respects in such a small yet important way were denied them.

It was a day when even the lawyers forgot their lamentable suggestions that the police were in some way to blame, for failing to clear the area around the bomb.

Families were spared the indignity of the most terrible details of victims' injuries being made public. The pathologists instead offered only brief statements, which still made appalling listening.

But it was the tiny details, the make of jeans, or the thong necklace, or blue T-shirt, which were unbearable.

One witness, Sandra Blackwell, giving evidence into the death of student Julia Hughes, 21, was weeping even as she tried to take the oath. Many shed a tear for Miss Blackwell too, as she told how she was talking to the dead woman when the bomb exploded. She had married since the tragedy, but her hand was badly bent as she held the bible. She told Mr Leckey between her sobs that she was still receiving treatment. He thanked her and sympathised.

A consultant surgeon, Dominic Pinto, recalled how he had raced to the Tyrone county hospital after hearing the bomb explode. So choc-a-bloc had been the traffic that he was forced to drive on the wrong side of the road with his headlights on.

webTitle: Complaint to GMC on overdose death

fields.headline: Complaint to GMC on overdose death
fields.trailText: A complaint is to be made to the General Medical Council about a GP who prescribed the sleeping drug that killed Emma Humphreys, whose fight against her murder conviction changed how courts regard the defence of provocation for battered partners.
fields.body:
A complaint is to be made to the General Medical Council about a GP who prescribed the sleeping drug that killed Emma Humphreys, whose fight against her murder conviction changed how courts regard the defence of provocation for battered partners.

Ms Humphreys, who had anorexia and was addicted to drugs originally prescribed to her in prison, was found dead at her London home in July 1998.

An inquest, reopened at St Pancras coroner's court in London yesterday, heard she weighed just five stone and had 20 times the recommended dose of chloral hydrate in her blood at her death.

The jury unanimously found Ms Humphreys, 30, from Upper Holloway, north London, died of trichloroethanol poisoning and returned a verdict of death by misadventure.

But after the verdict the campaign group Justice for Women revealed it would be filing a complaint about one of her doctors to the GMC.

Spokeswoman Julie Bindel said: "Because information was censored by the coroner in the inquest, we have been forced to put a complaint about Dr Mayur Gor to the GMC. We were allowed to hold the inquest in front of a jury because the circumstances surrounding Emma's death are of public interest."

Dr Gor, who was Ms Humphreys's GP after her release from prison in 1995 until her death, told the inquest he had tried to prescribe alternative medication.

The inquest heard there were times when the weekly therapeutic dose of 200mls was issued twice within seven days. But the GP said he had given his patient two weeks' worth of the drug in one prescription because he was led to believe that she was going to be away on holiday for that period. Ms Humphreys had also been prescribed chloral hydrate by other GPs in the same north London practice as Dr Gor in the period before her death, the inquest heard.

Ms Humphreys was jailed for life for murder in February 1985 at Nottingham crown court after stabbing her boyfriend, Trevor Armitage, to death when she was 17.

She claimed Mr Armitage, whom she met when she worked as a prostitute, beat her, forced her to have sex with him and was verbally abusive.

She was freed from Holloway prison after 10 years in jail when her conviction was reduced by the appeal court to manslaughter on the grounds of long-term provocation.

The decision was hailed as a landmark and set a precedent for women who had killed abusive partners.

webTitle: Business: Baltimore steps up security with Content buy

fields.headline: Baltimore steps up security with Content buy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Baltimore Technologies, the Irish e-security specialist, yesterday announced its largest acquisition to date by paying £702.5m in shares for the Berkshire-based firm behind the popular MIMEsweeper email security product.
fields.body:
Baltimore Technologies, the Irish e-security specialist, yesterday announced its largest acquisition to date by paying £702.5m in shares for the Berkshire-based firm behind the popular MIMEsweeper email security product.

Content Technologies Holdings was founded five years ago by David Guyatt and Andy Harris who make a combined £180m from the takeover.

Baltimore said the deal would increase its presence in the US, where Content does much of its business, and present numerous opportunities for the cross-selling of products between the two companies' customer bases.

The acquisition dwarfs Baltimore's previous largest - the £100m takeover of CyberTrust - and to complete a momentous day the Dublin-based firm said it had appointed a new finance director whose first job would be to raise a further $100m through a share placement to provide working capital.

Analysts' eyes were however on the Content deal. MIMEsweeper has 40% of the content security market, the technical term for email applications that prevent breaches of security and the circulation of illicit material at large companies.

Baltimore's executive vice president of marketing, Paddy Holahan, said the market is growing at 71% per year and can prevent corporate secrets and malicious information from escaping from companies via email and stop pornography and viruses from being circulated within them.

"Every internet company needs MIMEsweeper," he said. "Whichever way we slice this deal we see huge potential for selling new products both to our customers and Content's." Baltimore has a large number of financial institutions as customers, while Content sells to numerous medium-sized businesses.

Content's 200 staff serves around 6,000 customers and 6m email users worldwide through four offices in the US and centres in Europe, Australasia and Japan. "This acquisition is about taking a leadership position in the e-security field and should distance us from any competitor," Mr Holahan added.

A total of 91m new Baltimore shares will be issued at 772p per share to fund the £702.5m deal. Analysts said that while the price of the deal appeared high, with Content being valued at almost 40 times its annual sales, Baltimore shares trade on an even higher multiple and it could afford to issue the new shares at this level. Shares in Baltimore fell 12p to 760p.

Mr Guyatt, chief executive of Content, said joining forces with Baltimore would enable it to roll out new products faster and give it access to a wider customer base.

Paul Sanders, group finance director at SSL International, will become chief financial officer in November. The 36-year-old's experience in making strategic acquisitions suggests that Baltimore will pursue further deals.

His appointment follows Tuesday's resignation of the chairman, Henry Becker, who has left to devote more time to a project to give every school child in Britain a laptop computer.

Deputy chairman Peter Morgan has been promoted to take his place.

webTitle: Jakarta protesters rage at sluggish trial of Suharto

fields.headline: Jakarta protesters rage at sluggish trial of Suharto
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Protesters inflamed by the repeated refusal of Indonesia's former dictator Suharto to appear at his corruption trial clashed in Jakarta yesterday with police and supporters of the accused.
fields.body:
Protesters inflamed by the repeated refusal of Indonesia's former dictator Suharto to appear at his corruption trial clashed in Jakarta yesterday with police and supporters of the accused.

The frustration of the protesters - who were armed with petrol bombs and sharpened bamboo spears - was compounded by another delay in the proceedings: judges inside the heavily guarded agriculture ministry complex being used for the trial ordered an independent medical examination of the ailing defendant and set the next session for September 28.

After several hours of medical evidence by Mr Suharto's doctors and prosecution experts, the judges said they had yet to be convinced by defence lawyers' claims that their client was too ill to attend.

"In order to get a conclusive answer as to the state of his health, the defendant should undergo a comprehensive medical examination by an independent team," the chief judge, Lalu Mariyun, ordered.

This team is to comprise doctors from three universities, the department of health and the Indonesian Doctors' Association. Its members will examine Mr Suharto, 79, and report back to the judges within two weeks.

"If he is considered healthy enough, then he must appear," Judge Mariyun said.

The Suharto family and its friends are suspected of looting the country's wealth on a grand scale, but the present case is focusing on Mr Suharto and seven charitable foundations he controlled.

The retired general - who ruled with an iron fist for 32 years until anti-regime riots forced him to step down in May 1998 - is charged with embezzling about £400m through the foundations, and taking the proceeds of special taxes he imposed on the profits of state firms.

Yesterday was the second session of the slow-moving trial process. At it, Mr Suharto's doctors used slides of brain scans to argue that the stress of court appearances could kill him. "He has had three strokes in the last two years and there is a large threat of another stroke," which would be fatal, Dr Teguh Ranahkusuma said.

He added that Mr Suharto had heart problems, high blood pressure, diabetes, sufferred memory loss and could not communicate well. In a cognitive test last month Mr Suharto could complete only the first 12 out of 36 tasks, he said, and his IQ was 84 (the rough average is 110-120).

Doctors appointed by the prosecution said they thought Mr Suharto was sufficiently healthy to be investigated and stand trial. Even if he is found to be too sick to be in court there is a possibility that he could be tried in absentia.

While glad that the trial had not been halted, many of those in the public gallery, were dissatisfied with the pace."Why do they [the judges] have to wait for two weeks between each session?" said Bintang Pamungkas, an opposition politician who was jailed several times during Suharto's reign.

"As for the stress argument", he said, "no ordinary citizen would get such favourable treatment."

About 100 demonstrators outside the agriculture complex were even more angry. After the hearing was adjourned they headed for Mr Suahrto's home in central Jakarta. There they were joined by about 400 protesters carrying wooden stakes, petrol bombs and spears.

After a stand-off with about 200 police and dozens of pro-Suharto youths, they attacked the police, who answered with tear gas and a charge. The skirmishes continued for about an hour. Police arrested several demonstrators and beat up a number of others. Photographers and cameramen were forced away from the scene.

Jakarta was tense yesterday, with the trial and clashes coming after a bomb exploded on Wednesday in the car park below the Jakarta stock exchange, killing at least 15 people and injuring more than 30. People stayed at home, fearing further blasts to coincide with the trial. Many buildings received bomb threats, but no devices were found.

fields.headline: BT heats up Ignite debate
fields.trailText: Debt-laden British Telecom yesterday moved to raise the profile of its new chain of "internet hotels" amid speculation that it could spin off the unit in an effort to boost its flagging share price.
fields.body:
Debt-laden British Telecom yesterday moved to raise the profile of its new chain of "internet hotels" amid speculation that it could spin off the unit in an effort to boost its flagging share price.

Ignite Content Hosting, the corporate internet arm set up after BT's strategic reshuffle in April, now has 20 web hosting and data centres open for business across nine European countries, BT announced.

The network has been funded to the tune of £1.25bn by BT, US carrier AT&T and Concert, the joint venture between the two. They aim to build 44 centres to give their large multinational customers worldwide access to integrated web hosting and application service provision (ASP).

Internet hosting is one of the telecoms sector's fastest growing markets as businesses' internet demands become more sophisticated and they increasingly look to rent software over the net rather than install it in their computers.

Analysts say web hosting has become a vogue area among investors, so many believe BT will look to crystallise the value of the venture and reduce debt by eventually floating off Ignite.

"It's being looked at now but nothing has been ruled in and nothing has been ruled out," admitted Ignite's Keith Langridge.

BT refuses to give details of how much of Ignite's £1.25bn funding it is providing or what its shareholding in the venture is. Mr Langridge said BT's commitment was to develop the European centres, while AT&T looked after the American build and Concert oversaw Asia-Pacific development.

Internet hotels in Amsterdam, Manchester, Frankfurt and Dublin have recently gone live as Ignite vies for leadership in a market forecast to grow from $4bn in 2000 to more than $16bn in 2004.

Telecity is the largest data centre specialist listed on the London Stock Exchange and has seen its shares soar since its July flotation. The firm operates nine centres across Europe and is now worth more than £1.4bn.

BT, by contrast, has seen the value of its shares fall by 45% in the past six months and significantly underperform the wider telecoms sector. Investors have become alarmed by the debt it has accrued.

webTitle: Zamorano signs in with a hat-trick

fields.headline: Zamorano signs in with a hat-trick
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Ivan Zamorano of Internazionale made an immediate impact on the games with a 21-minute hat-trick in Chile's 4-1 win over Morocco at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
fields.body:
Ivan Zamorano of Internazionale made an immediate impact on the games with a 21-minute hat-trick in Chile's 4-1 win over Morocco at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

Morocco played most of the Group B match with 10 men after the defender Adel Chbouki was sent off after six minutes and Zamorano put the South Americans ahead with a header after 37. He added a second from the penalty spot at the end of the first half and completed his hat-trick from close range 10 minutes after the interval.

He also earned the penalty that Reinaldo Navia converted 18 minutes from time to make it 4-0. Housainne El Ouchla scored a late consolation goal for the Moroccans.

The gold medal favourites Brazil began with a stuttering 3-1 win over Slovakia in Brisbane. They got off to a poor start when Andrej Porazik took advantage of some slack defending to put the Slovaks ahead after 26 minutes.

Brazil roused themselves and equalised four minutes later when Ronaldinho won the ball and fed Alex on the left. He crossed sweetly for Edu, who chested the ball down before slotting it in.

Brazil eventually took the lead midway through the second half when an angled cross from Fabio Aurelio found its way into the net via the boot of the Slovakian defender Marian Cisovsky. Alex, celebrating his 23rd birthday, scored the third just before the end.

Japan came from behind to beat South Africa 2-1 in Canberra, and Spain, another of the medal favourites, over came South Korea 3-0 in Adelaide. In Melbourne in the women's tournament, Mia Hamm and Tiffeny Milbrett scored to give the United States a 2-0 win over Norway.

Yesterday's results:

Men: Group B: South Korea 0 Spain 3 / Morocco 1 Chile 4 / Group D: Brazil 3 Slovakia 1 / South Africa 1 Japan 2.

Women: Group B: China 3 Nigeria 1 / US 2 Norway 0.

webTitle: Partners pay price for John Lewis profits fall

fields.headline: Partners pay price for John Lewis profits fall
fields.trailText: John Lewis Partnership yesterday warned its 50,000 employee partners that their bonuses would be lower this year because of a "sharp" decline in profits.
fields.body:
John Lewis Partnership yesterday warned its 50,000 employee partners that their bonuses would be lower this year because of a "sharp" decline in profits.

However the retailer, which last year fended off rebel partners who wanted to shake up its ownership structure, revealed that some of the partners are in line to share in a £6m windfall under an accrued holiday pay scheme.

Its profits slumped by 43% in the first half of the year - in part because of the four-year, £80m refurbishment of its flagship Peter Jones store in Sloane Square, London.

The interim profits were also knocked to £38.5m because of the costs associated with incorporating 11 Somerfield stores into its Waitrose food chain as well as the £6m cost of accrued holiday pay.

Now they will be able to choose to take the payment before reaching retirement.

webTitle: Tokyo defiant after US threat on whales

fields.headline: Tokyo defiant after US threat on whales
fields.standfirst: Special report: Fish
fields.trailText: Japan vented its anger yesterday at a US threat to impose sanctions on it for hunting two endangered whale species.
fields.body:
Japan vented its anger yesterday at a US threat to impose sanctions on it for hunting two endangered whale species.

Washington says the expanded hunt is a move towards resuming commercial whaling. The issue is fast becoming the angriest between the two countries in years. Japanese fishermen have been barred from US territorial waters.

Japanese ministers called the sanctions threat "deplorable" yesterday and said it contravened the international treaty on whaling. President Bill Clinton has started a process that could lead to economic sanctions in 60 days.

Yoshiro Mori, the prime minister, refused to recall the four ships at the centre of the bilateral storm. They are in the north-west Pacific to harpoon 10 sperm whales and 50 Bryde's whales for the first time since an international moratorium on commercial whaling began in 1986. Japan says the kill from the two species - both protected under US law - is important for research purposes. This is in addition to its usual cull of more than 100 minke whales. The meat from such hunts will end up as gourmet dishes in restaurants for Japan's elite.

The government spokesman, Hidenao Nakagawa, hinted that Tokyo was ready to complain to the World Trade Organisation: "If import restrictions are put in place, we will respond in line with the rules."

In private, Japanese officials say the Clinton administration is trying to woo environmentalists for Al Gore, the Democrats' presidential candidate.

Few Japanese eat whale meat, which is very expensive, and most seem indifferent as to whether it is available. But the government is determined to keep whaling alive in the face of perceived western cultural imperialism. It says a limited hunt does no damage.

fields.headline: Head defends £90,000 salary
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A London headteacher who will next year become the most highly paid head in the state sector when he takes over a failing school defended his new salary of £90,000 a year yesterday.
fields.body:
A London headteacher who will next year become the most highly paid head in the state sector when he takes over a failing school defended his new salary of £90,000 a year yesterday.

The details emerged as the government prepared for the launch today of the first of its network of city academy schools, a type of urban secondary to replace schools that are failing or under-achieving. They will be outside the control of local authorities, offering a major role for the private sector and "new approaches to staffing" which could include higher salaries and bonuses to retain the best staff.

Headteachers' leaders yesterday welcomed Michael Murphy's appointment to Crown Woods comprehensive in Eltham, south-east London, and said salaries of £90,000 were still "light years" away from the extortionate amounts paid to football managers and "fat cat" businessmen.

Recruitment specialists said the top advertised salary to date for a head was £78,000. The government has agreed to pay £70,000 to "superheads" who have taken over fresh-start schools.

Mr Murphy was offered the Crown Woods job by Greenwich borough council on a salary of just over £71,000, when he was already being paid £85,000 as head of Hurlingham and Chelsea school.

"I said that if they wanted me to the do the job it was not unreasonable to pay me a higher salary than I was already getting," he said yesterday.

Over the past six years as head of the once highly unpopular Hurlingham and Chelsea school - which had the worst results of any London secondary - he increased the proportion of pupils getting five good grades at GCSE from 6% to 27% and nearly trebled the roll from 400 to 1,100 pupils.

The school featured in a government video on performance-related pay on the strength of its performance management system for teachers.

Crown Woods school had been put on "special measures" by inspectors. But Mr Murphy said that although the new job would be challenging he felt the school's problems could be tackled with "simple solutions which do not require rocket science".

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "This is a sign of the times and a shape of things to come. It proves the rather obvious point that if you want to get the best then you are going to have to pay for the best. This is market forces at work, just like in the private sector."

Today the government gives details of the first city academies in its Excellence in Cities programme, likely to include schools in London and the north-west. David Blunkett, the education secretary, aims to have six academies established in the scheme's first year.

fields.headline: Big payout over Guevara photo
fields.trailText: The photographer responsible for an iconic image of the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara has won his battle to assert copyright over the work.
fields.body:
The photographer responsible for an iconic image of the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara has won his battle to assert copyright over the work.

Alberto Diaz Gutierrez has accepted a "substantial" payment from the picture agency Rex Features and the advertising agency Lowe Lintas, which had used the image of Guevara in an advertisement for spicy vodka.

Declaring himself delighted with the settlement last night, Mr Gutierrez, better known as Korda, said he would donate any profits from the case to fund medical care of children in Cuba.

"This settlement ensures that my photograph of our national hero will never again be used in a way that slurs his memory, and this is most important to me."

Rex, Lowe Lintas and Korda issued a joint statement yesterday saying the case had been settled amicably, before a full hearing was due to start at the high court in London. "All parties are pleased to confirm that they have now settled their differences and Korda's claim has now been sensibly and amicably resolved." The settlement was ratified at the high court, which declared Korda to be the copyright owner.

The picture was taken on March 5 1960, at a memorial service for more than 100 crew members of a Belgian arms cargo ship, killed in an attack for which Cuba blamed counter-revolutionary forces aided by the US. Korda was assigned by a Havana newspaper to cover the ceremony.

The image left his possession when he unwittingly gave a copy to an Italian publisher.

It has been used countless times, but Korda appeared content to let the copyright breaches pass. His patience snapped with the vodka advert. In his claim to the high court, Korda accused the advertising firm of trivialising the historical significance of the photograph by overprinting it with a hammer and sickle motif, in which the sickle was represented by a chilli pepper.

Korda, who celebrated his 72nd birthday yesterday at an exhibition of his work at the National Gallery in London, said: "I have always considered it a mark of disrespect for the picture to be used without my permission and without me being credited as the author.

"This case was fought to defend the principle that all creators have a moral and property right to their own work."

The photographer, who still lives in Cuba, could now launch a series of claims against anyone else who has used the image without permission.
