Big Brother has given us, briefly, a small group of national neighbours and we have all enjoyed comparing notes about them the following day. That's all it is, a bit of gossipy fun, and good luck to it. Having said that, I fear we may not see another Big Brother series, because it is reported that the outraged owner of the copyright to George Orwell's works, including Big Brother, is about to sue Bazal Productions, makers of the C4 show, and its foreign counterparts for every penny they've got, because they have stolen the Orwellian concept from him. Since I would enjoy another helping of Big Brother, I can offer Bazal and co the following thought. Despite its title, their series has little to do with Orwell. His Big Brother was primarily a propaganda dispenser. Theirs is not. If anything, it is the estate of Sartre who should be worried, because the televised Big Brother is much closer to his 1944 concept of Huis Clos (Behind Closed Doors). A final word about the contestants. They may not have debated Wittgenstein, or contemplated the nature of infinity, as some lofty critics seemed to have expected, and they may have been childlike and occasionally vulgar, but considering the deprived environment in which they have found themselves day after day, they have, it seems to me, revealed a resilience and good-humoured tolerance that bodes well for our culture. But now I am beginning to sound pompous, too, so I must stop. What is it about BB that does that to us? There's the real mystery.

webTitle: Letter: Searcher for the truth about HIV

fields.headline: Searcher for the truth about HIV
fields.trailText: I was the companion of Bill Hamilton, the biologist who wrote the foreword to Edward Hooper's book on the origin of Aids (G2, September 12), for his last six years. He felt strongly that the oral polio vaccine hypothesis of the origin of Aids should be tested. To test, as is well known to every scientist, doesn't mean to prove by preconception.
fields.body:
I was the companion of Bill Hamilton, the biologist who wrote the foreword to Edward Hooper's book on the origin of Aids (G2, September 12), for his last six years. He felt strongly that the oral polio vaccine hypothesis of the origin of Aids should be tested. To test, as is well known to every scientist, doesn't mean to prove by preconception.

This is the reason Bill made his second, fatal, expedition to the Congo last January. He was aware of the danger of this mission in a country in a civil war and where it was easy to get sick. He had already experienced this in his first expedition in June 1999, when he was threatened by soldiers and came back ill.

But he was concerned that the chimpanzees of the eastern Congo forest close to the Lindi camp where, during the 50s, experiments with the oral polio vaccine were carried out, might be exterminated by people starving because of the war. He wanted to study these animals before it was too late, to see if they harboured SIV, the chimpanzee virus that is the ancestor of the Aids virus.

Even though this was not his field, Bill thought it was his duty to try to establish facts. He thought that an evolutionary biologist, better than any other person, could help the scientific community understand the biological factors implicated in the possible transfer of viruses to humans. He was convinced that transmission of a virus from another species to humans via a vaccine was possible; that it might have happened in this case; and that it could happen in the future if we were not aware of the possibility.

As he wrote in his foreword to Hooper's book: "Some aspects of genetic engineering may indeed be dangerous, but a situation in which the general public has greater concern about mystical subversion of the chemicals in soy sauce than about the risk of viruses in live animal products that are already administrated, almost compulsorily, to our bodies, is near to absurd. In parallel to this, our doctors' Hippocratic oath warns them of various temptations and dangers, but it says nothing of how they need to guard themselves, and their profession, against the effects of millions of profit that dangle before the nascent industry proposing to transplant organs into humans form other species."
Dr Maria Luisa Bozzi
Turin

webTitle: Letters: Causes of the fuel crisis

fields.headline: ... and its causes
fields.trailText: The prime minister claims the fuel crisis has been brought about by a small group of politically motivated people in defiance of the democratically elected government (Britain grinds to a halt, September 13). That is breathtaking hypocrisy from a man who, since coming to power, has done so much to undermine the democratic process. Tony Blair will not listen to anyone, except the coterie of unelected yes-men and spin doctors who feed his vanity.
fields.body:
The prime minister claims the fuel crisis has been brought about by a small group of politically motivated people in defiance of the democratically elected government (Britain grinds to a halt, September 13). That is breathtaking hypocrisy from a man who, since coming to power, has done so much to undermine the democratic process. Tony Blair will not listen to anyone, except the coterie of unelected yes-men and spin doctors who feed his vanity.

This crisis is unique in as much as the action that provoked it has been supported by almost everyone in the country - despite the inconvenience it has caused. A salutary reminder to the arrogant bunch in government that they were elected to apply the will of the people - not their own self-serving agenda.
Robert Readman
Boscombe, Dorset

 The prime minister must bear much of the responsibility for the mishandling of the crisis. His deep-seated arrogance has led him to misunderstand the level of public support for the protesters. His belief that he had only to snap his fingers and oil companies and tanker drivers would rapidly begin to deliver fuel reinforces the view that he is dangerously overconfident about his own abilities. At some point New Labour has to compromise on fuel tax. Alas the notion of compromise is for the prime minister one that he can see only as weakness.
Trevor Fisher
Stafford

 Farmers and fishermen (fat and thin) do dangerous, dirty work to provide basic necessities (food) for us. They have seen their incomes falling while at the same time dot.com companies make millions providing frivolous "services" that no one really needs. People recognise that this society has its priorities wrong, that hard work and essential services are neither valued nor rewarded, which is why there is so much public support for Steve Bell's "fat blokes".
Caroline Walker
Hartland, Devon

 There is a national crisis, but where is the national debate? Certainly not in our democratically elected House of Commons, unrecalled and empty. Instead we hear of a meeting at Balmoral of the Privy Council (unelected), headed by the Queen (unelected), approving an Order in Council to enable "exceptional powers" under the Emergency Powers Acts. It is little wonder that direct action by citizens is seen to be the only way to bring matters to the attention of an over-powerful executive that doesn't seem to listen.
Jon Temple
Republic

fields.headline: Picket-line stories
fields.trailText: The admirable Catherine Bennett (Middle of the road protest, G2, September 14) mistakenly suggests I support extra-parliamentary action. I gave that up long ago, when I stopped being a Trotskyist. In the article she quotes, I wrote: "We might pause to wonder if we really want to live in a society where the loudest bully rules and the picket line replaces parliament." If people don't like high taxes, they should vote to remove this government at the next election.

In the article she quotes, I wrote: "We might pause to wonder if we really want to live in a society where the loudest bully rules and the picket line replaces parliament." If people don't like high taxes, they should vote to remove this government at the next election.
Peter Hitchens
Daily Express

 "Too bad all the people who know how to run the country are busy driving cabs," quipped the late George Burns. He might have added farmers and hauliers.
Peter Denton
Teddington, Middx

 This morning, with enough petrol to last for another 24 hours, we got in the car, drove to the gym, worked out on the stationery bike for 10 minutes then walked on the treadmill for 40. I ask the picketers this: when the tank gets to empty, what's going to happen to our exercise regime?
Linda Grant
London

 The prime minister has pledged "strong support for whatever decisons police have to take" to deal with the blockades. I wonder if his support will be readily forthcoming should Humberside police decide to deploy only the cardboard cut-outs they have been forced to utilise due to the lack of police officers?
Clive Chamberlain
Dorset Police Federation

 If diesel is so expensive perhaps truck drivers should be taking more care not to slop it all over our roads killing, as they do, hundreds of motorcyclists every year.
Andy Kershaw
London

 A very British queue?
Dr Peter Laugharne
Ilford, Essex

fields.headline: Fuel: the political fall-out
fields.trailText: I wonder if the country's fuel supplies wouldn't be safer in the hands of Rupert Murdoch (Drivers told 'not to go out', September 14). During the months of the Wapping dispute of 1986, not a single edition of the Sun, News of the World, Times or Sunday Times was prevented leaving his plant by the presence of pickets. There were often thousands of them; they were angry; and most were in direct dispute with Murdoch, who had stopped their wages. And yet every night the lorries rolled out, some of them possibly driven by the same gents now sunning themselves in small groups outside oil depots.
fields.body:
I wonder if the country's fuel supplies wouldn't be safer in the hands of Rupert Murdoch (Drivers told 'not to go out', September 14). During the months of the Wapping dispute of 1986, not a single edition of the Sun, News of the World, Times or Sunday Times was prevented leaving his plant by the presence of pickets. There were often thousands of them; they were angry; and most were in direct dispute with Murdoch, who had stopped their wages. And yet every night the lorries rolled out, some of them possibly driven by the same gents now sunning themselves in small groups outside oil depots.

How was this possible? Because Rupert and his management willed it and because a sympathetic government made sure the police kept the exit open. This was a large and expensive operation. Sometimes mounted police were drafted in. There was at least one pitched battle. Newspapers may not be as inflammable as petrol, but nobody should doubt that the safety of many drivers was put at risk many times, as well as, occasionally, the lives of police and pickets. In a way, the police permitted the fundamental reshaping of the newspaper industry, just as, a few months earlier, they helped the restructuring (or destruction) of the coal industry.

These results may have been good or bad or just plain inevitable. The questions now are: where is the impartial application of the law? Where is the will of the oil companies? And who are we to think of as "the enemy within"?
Ian Jack
Editor, Granta ianjack@grantamag.co.uk

 The task for the government is to tackle the justifiable concerns of farmers, some hauliers and small businesses over the sudden rise in fuel costs, while maintaining its already slow course towards the Kyoto targets. This is a real test of political leadership and will demonstrate if the cabinet has more intellect than a mere collection of focus group results.

The government can start by talking to the protesters and looking at its short-term increase in VAT receipts and committing them to rural transport users. In the long term, we must move from the crude penalisation of motor car use to a more sophisticated taxation of unnecessary use, for example by taxing car parking in city centres. In the meantime, all of us must remember the way the oil companies have behaved during this crisis next time they plead environmental concerns.
Simon Thomas MP

 Although I agree in substance with the director of Friends of the Earth (Letters, September 14), he and his counterparts in Greenpeace, Reclaim the Streets and other environmentalist and anti-capitalist movements that are happy themselves to employ direct action need to reflect on the extent to which their activities have legitimated the reactionary politics of the fuel-price protesters. Using "our power as citizens to bring the corporations and politicians to account" sounds suspiciously like what the fuel protesters think they are doing.

Would it not be more appropriate to insist that policy should be made at Westminster and in Whitehall and not by "citizens" on the streets? But in that case, it has to be acknowledged that this principle applies to opposition to GM foods, motorway construction and so on, as well as to the present circumstances. Max Weber remarked harshly of the death in an insurrection of Rosa Luxemburg that "she called on the street and the street answered" - FoE and Greenpeace have called on the streets many times in the past and I am afraid the streets may now be answering them.
Prof Chris Brown
London School of Economics C.J.Brown@lse.ac.uk

fields.headline: Whale à la japonaise
fields.standfirst: Those who oppose are imperialists
fields.trailText: "Americans are a bunch of culinary imperialists. Telling the Japanese not to hunt whales is like telling the British to stop having their afternoon tea or denying French people their paté. This is how you start a war."
fields.body:
"Americans are a bunch of culinary imperialists. Telling the Japanese not to hunt whales is like telling the British to stop having their afternoon tea or denying French people their paté. This is how you start a war." So says Takashi Sato, owner of a Tokyo whalemeat restaurant, whose specialities include fried whale, raw whale, whale bacon, whale heart, whale testicle, whale kidney, and whale fat ice cream. Nor are Mr Sato's overcooked comments, made recently to the New York Times, untypical of the passions aroused in Japan by foreign attempts to end its killing of sperm, Bryde's and other protected giants of the deep.

As well as being kitchen-hob hegemonists, anti-whalers are denounced as sentimental. "Why are only whales so cute that Japan must be denied this sustainable resource?" asked one furious official. There is the "enemy whales" defence: Japan suspects marauding Mobys may be gobbling up its seafood supplies, hence the need for "scientific research". There is the "cultural" defence (also favoured by Norwegian minke-mashers and Faroese pilot-pulverisers): that is to say, "you" do not understand "our" ancient ways - although forking out £285 a pound for best leg of whale is a bit hard to understand for many younger Japanese, too. In defending the indefensible, Japan, allegedly, is not above getting down and dirty by covertly linking its development aid to support for its war on whales by poorer countries. But nor is it slow to seek the political high ground. After the US moved to impose trade sanctions this week in protest at Japan's expanded whale hunt, agriculture minister Yoichi Tani, sounding more like a rogue North Korean, angrily asked: "Does the US think it should decide everything?"

Well, perhaps it does. And perhaps this is all part of a selfish US global economic agenda. But when it comes to protecting endangered species, the US is right to act, Britain should follow suit, and the Japanese should try eating humble pie.

webTitle: Connex will quit if £1bn rail bid fails

fields.headline: Connex will quit if £1bn rail bid fails
fields.trailText: Connex, one of the worst performing rail companies, last night threatened to pull out from running the congested south central London line if it loses the franchise.
fields.body:
Connex, one of the worst performing rail companies, last night threatened to pull out from running the congested south central London line if it loses the franchise.

A decision is due this autumn but Connex faces the sack because of its poor record. Under the terms of the original franchise, Connex should run the line until 2003.

If the axe does fall, it will make a quick exit. But it promised not to "slash and burn" should the shadow Strategic Rail Authority issue it with marching orders.

The French-owned company, widely criticised for dirty and late running trains, said that it would get out after making the best possible deal.

Connex stressed that it was a strong contender for the new 20 year franchise for which it had bid more than £1 bn. It also appears among a list of nine bidders for the Thameslink franchise published yesterday.

The link is to expand in an £800m project, supervised by Railtrack, to enable passengers to travel from Cambridgeshire to the south coast without changing.

Mike Grant, the SSRA's chief executive, said this will provide extra capacity for "hard pressed commuters," but will not be ready for six years.

The SSRA has also listed eight bidders, including Connex, FirstGroup and security company Group 4, to run the majority of services in Wales.

fields.headline: BNFL losses at all-time high
fields.standfirst: Switch to clean-up contracts planned
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels plunged to a £337m loss last year - the worst in the company's history - after a series of controversies including charges of falsifying quality control data.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels plunged to a £337m loss last year - the worst in the company's history - after a series of controversies including charges of falsifying quality control data.

The company reported a profit of £218m the previous year. Since then it has faced a damaging safety review by the government regulator, the loss of Japanese business because of falsification of data and found it had disastrously underpriced contracts in the US.

Hugh Collum, brought in as chairman as part of a management shake-up, described the results as "poor" and the future as "challenging".

BNFL's total undiscounted nuclear liabilities increased by some 26% to £34.2bn.

The planned part-privatisation of the group, postponed last autumn when the Japanese scandal broke, is now scheduled to take place in two years' time.

But first the company needs to re-establish good relations with its customers. Without new spent fuel reprocessing contracts and a guaranteed market for the recovered plutonium, the outlook for the core business of Sellafield would appear bleak.

The company admitted for the first time yesterday that it would not be able to fullfil contracts to process 7,000 tonnes of spent fuel in the first 10 years of opening the£1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant at the Cumbrian site.

This was the timetable on which the original £500m profit figure used to justify opening the plant was based.

A purpose-built plant for producing mixed oxide fuel, at present lying idle at Sellafield, is listed as an asset worth £462m in the company books.

But the plant can only be opened with the permission of the Department of Environment, and this has been withheld until the company can prove it has enough orders to cover the operating and clean-up costs of contaminating the building with plutonium.

Although the company had some orders from Switzerland, it had none from Japan. "Without Japanese orders we cannot justify opening the mox plant," said the chief executive, Norman Askew. "We have no time to finesse this: we have until about next January or February to convince the Japanese, otherwise we shall have to abandon the project."

Many of the company's critics believe that its future lies not in reprocessing but in clean-up work.

BNFL had to write off £139m for underpricing the cost of an American military clean-up contract in Tennesee

The company was optimistic that - given good management - there was a brighter future in prospect with overseas contracts to come.

But the ageing Magnox nuclear stations located in Britain - which proved impossible to privatise - made an operating loss of £37m, compared with a £27m profit last year.

Liabilities increased by another £26m because of the premature closure of the Hinkley Point power station in Somerset, which proved too costly to bring back into service for the remaining five years of its operating licence.

Mark Johnston of Friends of the Earth said: "BNFL is walking a financial tightrope. It has only itself to blame for management incompetence. If BNFL is to survive, the switch to nuclear clean-up work is the only option on the table."

Nuclear afterburn

1999

September 17 BNFL admits data falsification but denies actual fuel went to Japan

November 10 Government shelves plan to open plutonium fuel plant until proved economic

December 17 Japan calls BNFL "untrustworthy"

December 18 Japan demands fuel is returned

2000

February 19 Nuclear watchdog says Sellafield must "clean up or close"

February 23 Germany finds more falsified documents

February 27 BNFL chief John Taylor resigns

March 23 US energy secretary says "business as usual is over with BNFL"

March 30 Part-privatisation put off until after election

April 19 Nine directors sacked, staff to be retrained

The planned part-privatisation of the group, postponed last autumn when the Japanese scandal broke, is now scheduled to take place in two years' time. But first the company needs to re-establish good relations with its customers. Without new spent fuel reprocessing contracts and a guaranteed market for the recovered plutonium, the outlook for the core business of Sellafield would appear bleak. The company admitted for the first time yesterday that it would not be able to fullfil contracts to process 7,000 tonnes of spent fuel in the first 10 years of opening the£1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant at the Cumbrian site. This was the timetable on which the original £500m profit figure used to justify opening the plant was based. A purpose-built plant for producing mixed oxide fuel, at present lying idle at Sellafield, is listed as an asset worth £462m in the company books. But the plant can only be opened with the permission of the Department of Environment, and this has been withheld until the company can prove it has enough orders to cover the operating and clean-up costs of contaminating the building with plutonium. Although the company had some orders from Switzerland, it had none from Japan. "Without Japanese orders we cannot justify opening the mox plant," said the chief executive, Norman Askew. "We have no time to finesse this: we have until about next January or February to convince the Japanese, otherwise we shall have to abandon the project." Many of the company's critics believe that its future lies not in reprocessing but in clean-up work. BNFL had to write off £139m for underpricing the cost of an American military clean-up contract in Tennesee The company was optimistic that - given good management - there was a brighter future in prospect with overseas contracts to come. But the ageing Magnox nuclear stations located in Britain - which proved impossible to privatise - made an operating loss of £37m, compared with a £27m profit last year. Liabilities increased by another £26m because of the premature closure of the Hinkley Point power station in Somerset, which proved too costly to bring back into service for the remaining five years of its operating licence. Mark Johnston of Friends of the Earth said: "BNFL is walking a financial tightrope. It has only itself to blame for management incompetence. If BNFL is to survive, the switch to nuclear clean-up work is the only option on the table." webTitle: South Africans want full control of Lakeside

fields.headline: South Africans want full control of Lakeside
fields.trailText: South African group Liberty International has made a bid to take full control of Capital Shopping Centres, which owns the Lakeside complex in Thurrock, Essex, in the first step towards creating a retail property powerhouse.
fields.body:
South African group Liberty International has made a bid to take full control of Capital Shopping Centres, which owns the Lakeside complex in Thurrock, Essex, in the first step towards creating a retail property powerhouse.

Liberty already owns 75% of Capital and is offering a mixture of cash and shares worth £400m for the rest. The bid fulfils a commitment made by Liberty this year when it was fending off a hostile attack from British Land.

Liberty's managing director, David Fischel, said: "The combined strength of the organisation is likely to be greater. We'd expect it to lead to further expansion in the shopping centres sector."

In addition to Lakeside, Capital owns the newly built Braehead mall in Glasgow and the MetroCentre in Gateshead. However, the government has cracked down on out-of-town developments so future investment is likely to be in expanding existing sites and building town-centre complexes.

Mr Fischel said many property companies were trading on the stock market at a discount to the value of their assets. This was "bound to throw up opportunities".

Capital was originally part of Liberty, spun off six years ago when the parent company was largely involved in financial services. Liberty has since become a pure property company.

Mr Fischel said: "We've changed substantially. We're no longer under majority control from South African and we're now in the property sector. Having two listed companies in the same sector with the same assets was causing confusion."

Capital's shares fell 20.5p to 397p, while Liberty slipped 11p to 510p.

Capital's independent directors, who include the former overseas development minister Baroness Chalker, said they were studying the offer and would write to shareholders shortly. Capital's Lakeside centre is regarded as a prize asset although it has suffered recently due to competition from Bluewater in Kent.

webTitle: BAE goes gunning for Middle East arms sales

fields.headline: BAE goes gunning for Middle East arms sales
fields.trailText: BAE Systems, Britain's biggest defence contractor, is seizing on the soaring price of oil to launch a new arms-sales drive in the Middle East and offset a gap in its order books caused by declining defence budgets in Europe.
fields.body:
BAE Systems, Britain's biggest defence contractor, is seizing on the soaring price of oil to launch a new arms-sales drive in the Middle East and offset a gap in its order books caused by declining defence budgets in Europe.

John Weston, BAE chief executive, said yesterday: "Rising oil prices are good news for us. Previously, the low oil price has been a retardant but the increase gives us hope of doing more business."

The group, which hopes to amass a £3bn warchest for "bolt-on" acquisitions, primarily in the US where military spending is set to rise whoever wins November's presidential elections, has targeted Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Kuwait as lucrative markets.

It already has plans to sell the new Eurofighters, whose British production begins next month, to the Saudis in what would effectively be an Al Yamamah 3 oil-for-arms deal though nobody is talking publicly of an extension to the arrangement begun by Lady Thatcher that brings BAE £2bn a year in sales.

The controversial Hawk fighter/trainer, the Grippen fighters built by Saab in which BAE has a 35% stake, guided weapons and naval systems are the premier products being offered by teams of sales executives in the Middle East.

Mr Weston said: "We believe there is the possibility of a further 200 (global) orders for Hawk over the next eight to ten years and are in advanced stages of negotiating contracts with India."

BAE executives yesterday set out a string of actual and potential orders in an effort to offset market disappointment about its first set of figures since the £7.6bn takeover of the then GEC's Marconi Electronic Systems last year.

Pre-tax profits to June 30 rose 34% from £358m to £480m but BAE promised a stronger performance in the second half. Commercial aerospace turned in a £34m profit in the first half, the bulk of it from Airbus, compared with a £30m loss in 1999. Airbus won 234 orders worth $15.4bn in the first six months and BAE has won a new five-year contract worth £1.244bn to supply Airbus with wing components.

webTitle: Sydney in grip of Olympic security

fields.headline: Sydney in grip of Olympic security
fields.standfirst:
Soldiers permitted to open fire on streets amid fears of terrorist threat and violent protests
Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: The opening ceremony of the 27th Olympic Games, the biggest and most costly event ever to be held in Australia, takes place today amid the biggest security operation in the country's history, for fear of terrorist attack or demonstrations.
fields.body:
The opening ceremony of the 27th Olympic Games, the biggest and most costly event ever to be held in Australia, takes place today amid the biggest security operation in the country's history, for fear of terrorist attack or demonstrations.

In the light of the bomb blast at the Atlanta Olympic Games in 1996, in which two people were killed and 110 injured, draconian measures, known as the Olympic security laws, have been pushed through parliament, bringing criticism from civil rights groups. Around 20,000 police officers, private security guards and army personnel will be on duty during the two weeks of the games, which have cost £1bn to stage.

A shoot on sight law gives the government the right to draft soldiers on to the streets and open fire on people, if they are considered to be a risk to security.

Police fear that anti-capitalist demonstrators, who rioted in Melbourne this week during a meeting of the World Economic Forum, and aboriginal rights activists might target the opening ceremony.

Police have the power to search and photograph people and take them away if they are believed to be creating an "annoyance" or "inconvenience" in Sydney or in and around the Olympic park.

Any activity or demonstration requires permission from the police, while people can be searched without permission, prevented from distributing material of any sort and barred from collecting money.

More than 100 navy divers have been brought in to search Sydney's harbours, where events such as the triathlon and sailing will take place.

Around 500,000 people are expected to visit Sydney during the games. The arrival of the Olympic flame was greeted by around 1m people last night, followed by a spectacular fireworks and laser show.

For those who do not have tickets for events, six huge screens have been erected at various points in Sydney, where they will be able to watch the action and enjoy festivities and concerts.

The police commissioner, Peter Ryan, said: "Australia has always been tolerant of people wanting to express alternative views, politically or otherwise. But we will not tolerate this city being closed down. We will not tolerate any disruption to the Olympic Games. We are not going to have Australia embarrassed."

Civil rights groups, however, have expressed concerns that police may continue to employ special emergency laws once the games are over. Amanda Cornwall, head of a Sydney-based group, said: "These laws will leave Sydney with a bitter Olympic legacy."

Extra security is being provided for certain teams, such as Israel and the US, for fear of attacks from political groups.

Despite threats of disruption from protest groups and corruption scandals that have hit the International Olympic Committee, organisers believe that the Sydney games could be the most successful and lucrative ever held.

According to the IOC, they will attract a global television audience of 3.7bn. They will be broadcast in 220 countries, while organisers claim to have already generated US$626m (£447m) in sponsorship.

The sale of TV rights is expected to bring in around US$1.3bn (£929m), compared with US$895m (£639m) for the Atlanta games.

fields.headline: NatPower hauls in IE customers
fields.trailText: National Power yesterday snapped up the 240,000 clients of bankrupt Independent Energy for a mere £10m - and suggested the deal concluded with receivers KPMG could be self-financing.
fields.body:
National Power yesterday snapped up the 240,000 clients of bankrupt Independent Energy for a mere £10m - and suggested the deal concluded with receivers KPMG could be self-financing.

The group, acting through its UK business arm, Innogy, said it was paying £32 per customer compared with rates of £200 or even £300 in the recent spate of mergers and acquisitions that launched the latest phase of consolidation in the UK's energy supply industry.

But Brian Count, Innogy's chief executive, said the deal could cost nothing as the group had agreed to collect, on behalf of KPMG, unpaid accounts for all Independent's customers up to the date of receivership on September 9. It is understood that Innogy will be paid a 10% fee for the first £75m of outstanding bills and a higher rate for the rest. Mr Count indicated that the uncollected debts stood in excess of £150m compared with the £119m officially disclosed by Independent earlier this year.

Innogy, which retails as Npower, paid a similar sum last March for the 600,000 gas customers of Calortex, and will now have just above 3m energy customers. Independent's domestic customers and small business users will be taken on by Innogy under the same terms and conditions, according to industry regulator Ofgem, but Mr Count said larger users had not been paying market rates and would be asked to renegotiate contracts.

He said Innogy would not be responsible for any liabilities or debts and had nothing to do with the recent suit launched by some US investors against former Independent directors who sold a large parcel of shares before issuing a profits warning this summer. KPMG also denied responsibility for the suit.

Yesterday's sale brings to an end the once-stellar saga of Solihull-based Independent, which launched in 1996 and last year was share of the year on the AIM market. Its shares peaked at £37.50 in March but had fallen to 500p by last Friday.

fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.standfirst: Just out: Provamel Soya Fruity
fields.trailText: Just out: Provamel Soya Fruity
fields.body:
www.prestat.co.uk

Yum! Prestat - the "Royal Chocolatiers" - has launched a website where you can order the confections famously enjoyed by politicians, royals and stars of stage and screen.

Pros: No nasty ones left at the end. The bespoke service provided by the shop in London's Piccadilly is available online, so you choose exactly what goes into the box. Simply enter details of your special requirements in "other preferences" and your box will be hand-packed accordingly.

Cons: Not a lot for you here if you don't like chocolate and far too much temptation if you do.

Delivery: Orders are processed within 48 hours of receipt and will be delivered by express (one day) or standard (one to three days) post.

Charges: £5.50 for express, £3.50 for standard.

Form: Liquid; made from filtered water, hulled organic soya beans and concentrated fruit juice.

Flavour: Vaguely like the flavouring fruits (apple and pear, orange and pineapple in these tests); not sweet; not natural either; background of soya milk.

Verdict: Why should you drink them? Well, they're free of lactose, gluten, cholesterol, animal products and genetically modified soya. But they're far from calorie-free - 243 per 100ml. I can't help thinking that pure, fresh fruit juice would be nicer, healthier and cheaper.

Price: 69p per 330ml pack.

There is an endless debate as to the niceties of roasting, grinding, freshness, acidity, water, aroma, colour, the right proportion of arabica to robusta ... Good coffee is an art form at which the British, traditionally, have not sparkled. Perhaps things are changing.

fields.headline: Bad heirs day
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Battle of Wills/Taggart/Secret Agent
fields.body:
Wills, like wakes, seem to take on a much livelier aspect in Ireland. This week's Battle of Wills (Channel 4) was about disputes over inheriting a house, usually the major part of an estate. The British were pretty darn decent about it, wounded yet restrained. Not so in Ireland. For nearly 10 years Dublin has been entertained by its own soap opera, The Battling Blackwalls of Blackrock.

Rose, Eileen and Gerard Blackwall were left Marino Park in the will of their mother. It is a charming little estate in a rapidly appreciating area. Rose and Eileen want to spend the rest of their lives there. Gerard's widow wants the money. Rose is 82, frail, funny and full of fighting spirit. The Queen Mother could take her correspondence course on how to arrive at court in a wheelchair, waving. She says she was born a fighter, being related to Brian Boru. I am not acquainted with Brian myself but obviously he's a man you can hear coming before he turns the corner by the sound of breaking glass and vainglorious shouting.

Gerard was not, like his sisters, a home bird. In old age, he married the pneumatic Iris ("She used to pose in skimpy undies" according to scandalised Irish tabloids) and left her everything. Gerard's only son, William, reacted like a true descendant of Brian Boru ("I went into a field and called him a bastard at the top of my voice.") Iris dug her hooves in ("I'm not going to give him anything. There's no way he's getting anything from his father's estate.") Rose, radiating charm, sued the socks off the lot of them ("I want what is mine and I refuse to see why someone else should have what is mine. It's very annoying.")

If this story doesn't have everything, then tell me what's missing? Well, apart from seven dwarfs.

Rose, William and Iris are friendly and fluent to a delightful degree, though "stiff," "upper" and "lip" do not seem to feature in their vocabulary. I often feel that journalism must be an easy job anywhere that isn't England. Meanwhile Marino Park is decaying like a bunch of grapes with noble rot. It now looks like a wedding cake left out in the rain. Wisely waiting till Rose was in court, bailiffs evicted Eileen. Iris, installed by the court as a caretaker, perches upstairs among the rafters like a pigeon. The site value has escalated into millions.

Rose has fought every millimetre of the way. She says she doesn't want to be a millionaire, though, with a twinkle, she wouldn't mind. She is just determined to die in her own house if it kills her. Personally, I think it's what's keeping her alive.

As Dylan, the lethargic rabbit said, yawning, in The Magic Roundabout, "We're trying to change the image." A wholly unfamiliar image of Glasgow emerges from a new series of Taggart (ITV). The new producer says "Glasgow has changed. The city is incredibly vibrant and packed with great restaurants." If I want somewhere incredibly vibrant and packed with great restaurants, I'll go and lie down till the sensation passes. Glasgow, thank God, is naturally intimidating. As Billy Connolly's children, fresh from California, asked nervously, "Daddy, why is the sky so low?"

Skin Deep, the first of three Taggarts, was set in a health club. The plot was about slimming pills, DCI Jardine was observed trying blackcurrant tea. What's far worse, NO ONE WAS MURDERED. Unless you count Fish, the heavy metal lead singer, who was accidentally impaled on a pair of horns or, possibly, a Viking helmet. This was definitely the high point of the proceedings. Fish, bless him, encapsulated all we think we know and know we love about Glasgow. Aggressive, oppressive, rowdy and healthily contemptuous of health clubs ("A bunch of Jessies prancing aboot.") He has one of those faces which might look quite friendly if it was on the other way up. As an actor, he was excellent, and I'm not just saying that because I'm terrified.

It is ironic that the head of the obsessively secret SOE was Hugh Dalton. He later resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer because, while he was on his way to make a budget speech, a reporter asked what was in it. And he told him . In Secret Agent (BBC 2), Noreen Riols, then the beautiful Miss Moneypenny of the Beaulieau SOE, described how she tested an Danish agent's discretion. They were looking at the moonlight on the summer sea. He held her hand. She asked where he was going and what he was going to do there. And he told her .

The plot was about slimming pills, DCI Jardine was observed trying blackcurrant tea. What's far worse, NO ONE WAS MURDERED. Unless you count Fish, the heavy metal lead singer, who was accidentally impaled on a pair of horns or, possibly, a Viking helmet. This was definitely the high point of the proceedings. Fish, bless him, encapsulated all we think we know and know we love about Glasgow. Aggressive, oppressive, rowdy and healthily contemptuous of health clubs ("A bunch of Jessies prancing aboot.") He has one of those faces which might look quite friendly if it was on the other way up. As an actor, he was excellent, and I'm not just saying that because I'm terrified. It is ironic that the head of the obsessively secret SOE was Hugh Dalton. He later resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer because, while he was on his way to make a budget speech, a reporter asked what was in it. And he told him . In Secret Agent (BBC 2), Noreen Riols, then the beautiful Miss Moneypenny of the Beaulieau SOE, described how she tested an Danish agent's discretion. They were looking at the moonlight on the summer sea. He held her hand. She asked where he was going and what he was going to do there. And he told her .

Which spices? Cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, vanilla.

Anything else? Powdered fruit, apparently.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Marks & Spencer ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Marks & Spencer ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: A well-rounded, distinctly curvy woman is sprinting up a hill, removing her clothing as she goes. Once she reaches the top the camera pulls back to reveal her completely starkers frame, perched on top of a podium. She flings her arms up in the air and cries out triumphantly: "I'm normal!". A voiceover then states that Marks & Spencer has just completed the largest ever survey of women's bodies and found that "...if you're not average, you're normal". The spot ends with the new tagline: "Exclusively for everyone".

The jargon: This woman may appear anything but "normal", judging by her behaviour, but the ad springs from a study which has found that we're all getting taller and, well, fatter really. It's basically normal to be a size 16 now, and the spot is aimed at launching M&S's new sizing for women, now more flatteringly (generously) cut.

Personality: You're any woman, aged from 25 upwards, of any shape and size, from anywhere in the country and of any social standing - a sort of "exuberant everywoman", according to agency Rainey Kelly.

Financial status: You come from both ends of the social/financial spectrum - this ad is trying to talk to All Women, regardless of income (although the skew is slightly towards the upper end).

Telling lifestyle detail: If you're a core M&S shopper, you probably drive a BMW Estate and like to have coffee mornings with your girlfriends (after dropping the children off at their private day school). You also do your weekly food-shop at M&S rather than at any dreary supermarket.

Other relevant data: The commercial was shot at dawn on a hill in Somerset, and stars Amy Davis, a model signed up with Excel model agency (which specialises in Rubenesque figures). Apparently, she used to be a size eight but then decided to stop the diets and surrender to her curves.

fields.headline: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15
fields.standfirst: And: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.trailText: And: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Neon, 71 Atlantic Road, London SW9. Tel: 020-7738 6576.

Once the feared front line, Atlantic Road is now fearlessly fashionable. Neon is up there with the happily hippest - huge red windows and stark interior - serving such dainty delicacies as pizzas, focaccias and home-made ravioli with spinach, ricotta and walnut sauce (£7-10 as a main course, £4 as a first). If that doesn't get your taste buds sitting up and begging, try the meatloaf stuffed with veg at only £7.40. Menu changes constantly. Tasting menu on Sundays; each dish £1. You can keep an eye on the kitchen on a small CCTV at the entrance. The atmosphere is genial and favoured by Brixton's fearsome media and arts mob. But wait a couple of weeks; they're fixing the kitchen.

Lounge, 38 Atlantic Road, London SW9. Tel: 020-7733 5229.

Comrade in culinary revolution, though a tad more laid back on the fashion front. Lounge could hardly be more aptly named, stuffed, as it is, with big, squashy sofas which encourage, well, lounging. Not surprisingly, it appeals more to louche students and self-employed arty types than drug-dealing heavies. Big, fancy sandwiches like goat's cheese with roasted pepper, aubergine and fresh basil for only £2.40; great gooey, sticky cakes; smooth-as-you-like café au lait, and fresh juices for health seekers, both at £2. Chirpy service and, if you like that kind of thing in your lunch break, internet access. Just the place to chill out after a morning battling through Brixton's markets.

fields.headline: No: 1721
fields.standfirst: The Ivy
fields.trailText: The Ivy
fields.body:
Would it be possible to have a table for two this evening? Surely you jest, sir. No tables are available until after Christmas, and only if your surname is Pinter, Beckham or Mandelson. The rest of you plebs will have to wait until late March 2003. This is the Ivy, you know.

Ah, the Ivy, purveyor of posh nosh to the rich and famous, if memory serves. Actually, it is, officially, Britain's favourite restaurant after winning the popularity prize at this week's London Restaurant Survey, compiled by restaurant bible, Zagat.

I guess it's another one of those modern, steel and chrome, rocket-and-fennel-with-pinenuts-in-Californian-honey-dressing type restaurants. Not a bit of it - no trendy Ruthie Rogers decor or Jamie Oliver snazziness here. The Ivy has been around since the first world war and the decor is dark pannelling, green leather and stained windows to keep out the stares of the paparazzi and hungry passersby. The wonderfully monikered actress Alice Delysia suggested the name to founder Abel Giandellini when she breathlessly cooed to him: "We will always come to see you. We will cling together like ivy."

Beautiful. But what's so great about the joint? The dedicated munchers who took part in the survey say, "it's like eating in front of the telly, the celebs just keep on coming," and it's great for "star spotting". Oh, and the food is "brilliant".

A bit of a foodie's Met Bar then, I take it. More stars in here than you find in the Priory. You might sup on Thai-baked Sea Bass (£21.75) while sitting next to George Michael, nibble on pot-roasted Fillet of Red Deer (£17.75) with Leonardo DiCaprio or munch on a hamburger behind Peter Mandelson.

A hamburger? Well, it will set you back £9.

So I take it that the Ivy has entered into national folklore? It recently obtained the highest possible British accolade by allegedly providing the inspiration for Harold Pinter's latest play, Celebration.

What is the play about? It centres around, ahem, irritating people eating in a pretentious restaurant.

Do say: "Pretty damn close to perfection" (Zagat reviewer).

Don't say: "Nine quid for a burger?!"

fields.headline: Czechs face green blockade
fields.standfirst: Protests at Soviet-designed nuclear plant aim to halt border traffic crossings
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of environmental activists plans to block the 26 border crossings between Austria and the Czech Republic today in protest at Czech plans to start up a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant in the next few days.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of environmental activists plans to block the 26 border crossings between Austria and the Czech Republic today in protest at Czech plans to start up a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant in the next few days.

The organisers said they intended to use tractors and cars to prevent traffic crossing the border, and would set off nuclear warning sirens.

The Temelin nuclear power station in southern Bohemia is due to start operating before the end of the month. Situated 90 miles south of Prague, 30 miles north of the border with nuclear-free Austria, and 38 miles east of Germany, it has become the focus of growing anger in the region.

The Czech's western neighbours say it poses a huge safety risk to central Europe. The Czechs, who have spent more than 100bn crowns (£1.7bn) on it - £687m over budget - insist that input by western experts has made it as safe as any in the west. Its safety control system has been upgraded to state-of-the-art by the US company Westinghouse.

But it is is causing diplomatic tension between the Czech Republic and Austria. Earlier this month Austrian MPs called on the government to delay Prague's EU membership talks until the problem was resolved. They insist on EU safety checks being carried out. The EU has demanded an environmental impact study.

An Austrian newspaper survey last week showed that 92% of Austrians believe Czech accession to the EU should depend on it abandoning Temelin. The Czech Republic is one of six countries in the first group of candidates in line for EU membership.

The controversy has become entangled with a long-standing political dispute over the Benes decrees, which enabled the post-war deportation of 2.5m ethnic Germans from Czechoslovakia to Germany and Austria. Many Austrian politicians want the decrees abolished as a condition of Czech membership of the EU.

The Czech foreign minister, Jan Kavan, said this week that independent experts from both sides would visit Temelin before it went on stream to discuss the issues.

The deputy prime minister, Vladimir Spidla, said that Czechs did not want to put themselves or their neighbours at risk. "When putting Temelin into operation, the government will proceed in accordance with national and international habits and regulations, and we see it as our task to spread that message on a diplomatic level," he said.

One of the organisers of today's protest, Rudi Anschober, leader of the Green party in the Austrian upper house, said: "We want an immediate halt to the construction of the station, a six-month break for revision, a thorough environmental impact assessment according to EU standards, publication of all project documentation and neighbouring countries to have access to that information."

Today's blockade follows lower-key protests on the Bavarian and upper Austrian borders. A further blockade of crossings between Bavaria and south Bohemia is planned on Sunday.

The reactor has divided Czech MPs in recent weeks, but as the international pressure has grown, so too has the Prague government's tendency to see the plant as a test of national honour.

Work on it began 16 years ago under communist rule and it was due to open in November 1992, in time for the 75th anniversary celebration of the Russian revolution. But it was interrupted by the fall of communism and shelved as an all-too poignant symbol of Soviet imperialism.

The plant was resurrected by the then prime minister, Vaclav Klaus, on the grounds that additional energy was needed to meet the growing domestic demand. But most of its opponents insist that the republic already has an energy surplus and that Temelin's output will be dumped on the international market at 30% or so below production costs.

"We now export annually 12 terrawatt-hours, or 25% of the electricity we produce, and Temelin would produce a further 11 to 12 terrawatt-hours a year, doubling our overcapacity," said Jan Beranek, a nuclear campaigner for Friends of the Earth in Prague. He and other experts say the plant will never be able to pay for itself.

The Czech energy company, CEZ, defends the safety of the plant, pointing out that 12 missions from the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna have visited it since 1990.

But recently more and more whistle-blowers have been voicing concern about safety issues at Temelin. "Several people, including skilled craftspeople and experts have approached us with information, because they said they couldn't live with a clear conscience about the irregularities they saw taking place," said Jan Haverkamp, an energy expert for Greenpeace.

These allegedly include faulty welding, irregularities in testing and continuing water leaks in valves in the reactor cooling system.

Greenpeace is concerned that at least one whistle-blowers has "disappeared" in the past few days. "We simply can't find him. He might have got scared and gone underground, but we're worried that someone's tried to silence him," Mr Haverkamp said.

Eastern Europe has 60 active nuclear reactors and 13 more under construction. Between 1991 and 1999 the EU invested more than 900m euros in the safety of plants in the region.

webTitle: Power chief cuts off army and railway

fields.headline: Power chief cuts off army and railway
fields.trailText: Elite army units are seizing power plants, new-born babies are at risk and trains on the trans-Siberian railways are grinding to a halt as the Russian electricity monopoly gets tough with debtors.
fields.body:
Elite army units are seizing power plants, new-born babies are at risk and trains on the trans-Siberian railways are grinding to a halt as the Russian electricity monopoly gets tough with debtors.

Unified Energy Systems, which is owed more than £5bn in unpaid bills, is cutting power to a number of prominent customers, plunging military bases, hospitals and companies into the dark.

The "pay up or switch off" policy is due to Anatoly Chubais, the pugnacious Thatcherite who has run UES for the past two years.

"Chubais is quite serious about his campaign to cut off customers and the government also is slowly accepting the fact that social facilities can be cut off, though it is very sensitive about the military," said Hartmut Jakob, a power sector analyst at Renaissance Capital in Moscow.

That "slow acceptance" let a baby die shortly after birth in a hospital in Vladivostok in the far-east last month when the electricity was cut off.

This week armed soldiers from a base of the elite strategic missile forces in Ivanovo, north of Moscow, seized the local power station to reconnect their barracks.

The prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, said the disconnections were inadmissible and ordered UES to keep the military connected. The defence ministry was allocated £32m to pay electricity bills.

Mr Chubais then banned power cuts to the missile forces, but the news did not seem to penetrate Siberia, where a base in Aleix, near the Chinese, border was warned that it would be cut off next week unless it paid £125,000.

A base commander said the troops were removing rocket fuel from the missiles and any power cuts could trigger "an environmental disaster". UES suggested that the army use its back-up diesel generators.

Two nuclear reactors were closed down, one in Sverdlovsk last week and one in Chelyabinsk this week, because of "faults in the regional energy system", though plant managers and the atomic energy ministry denied that Mr Chubais had ordered any power cuts.

"There are two reasons for Chubais's behaviour: he wants to show how important he is and he also badly needs the money because UES has run up enormous debts under his leadership," a Moscow expert on the electricity industry, Moysei Gelman, said.

Gennady Zyuganov, the Communist party leader, said on Wednesday that Mr Chubais should be jailed for his policy.

Throughout the economic collapse of the past 10 years the energy industry has operated on the basis of barter rather than cash. Mr Chubais, who was a chief draughtsman of Russia's flawed privatisation in the early 1990s, before becoming President Boris Yeltsin's chief of staff and election campaign manager, is determined to change that.

Last year UES collected only 30% of its receipts in cash, Mr Jakob said. So far this year cash receipts have risen to 62% of what UES is owed.

The cash-strapped government is the biggest debtor. Central and local government owe 28% of the unpaid £5.6bn. The ministries of defence, interior and justice are the worst offenders.

UES owes at least as much to its creditors, and has posted losses for the past three years, sullying Mr Chubais' reputation as an ardent free marketeer who will deliver profits to UES's shareholders.

"I don't agree with the term cut off," he told the St Petersburg Times last week. "We're not cutting anyone off. We're switching on those who honestly pay for energy, and our policy won't change."

The national railways are said to have made a deal with UES on the backlog of unpaid bills, but yesterday the trans-Siberian route was locked at the key hub of Krasnoyarsk in central Siberia. Power to a 50-mile stretch of the line was cut on Tuesday and Wednesday pending payment of £500,000.

Mr Chubais is keen to publicise military and railway cuts, but less forthcoming about the schools and hospitals.

If the tough tactics continue throughout the winter, the public will suffer.

"Cuts in the social sector are not a large-scale phenomenon, but they're happening now, whereas before the authorities did not allow that to happen," Mr Jakob said. "They're becoming much more widespread."

fields.headline: Police told to 'out' Japan's gangsters
fields.trailText: Japanese police were ordered yesterday to start naming and shaming gangsters in a new attempt to crack down on the crime syndicates that are steadily infiltrating the mainstream business world.
fields.body:
Japanese police were ordered yesterday to start naming and shaming gangsters in a new attempt to crack down on the crime syndicates that are steadily infiltrating the mainstream business world.

Names, addresses and mob affiliations will be made public under the new policy, which was described by one lawyer as an attempt to force the gangsters - the yakuza - to show their tell-tale tattoos to society.

The national police agency said the exposure was necessary because crime syndicates were becoming harder to identify as they shifted their operations into the realm of conventional business.

At first sight, the plan to "out" the gangsters seems absurd: in their habitual garb, the yakuza are the peacocks of Japanese society, impossible to miss. They perm their hair, dress in Hawaiian shirts, and drive huge Mercedes cars through narrow streets.

Their chests and backs are often covered in tattoos of mythical beasts, visible at public bathhouses and when they strip to the waist at Shinto festivals. If that is not enough of a giveaway, many lack a finger or two because the yakuza code requires a mobster to lop off a digit as a sign of contrition if he makes a mistake.

But these ostentatious markings are being shunned by a new generation of gang members who wear Armani suits rather than kimonos and fleece big corporations rather than run brothels, drug rings and protection rackets.

The change is largely a result of a 1994 law that restricted the activities of crime syndicates and made members liable for arrest for wearing syndicate lapel pins or passing out syndicate business cards.

But Japan's continuing economic depression has made financial institutions vulnerable to the schemes of smart young yakuza, many educated at Japan's top universities.

"More and more crime syndicates are stealthily moving into new areas of society and business," said a police agency spokesman. "We have introduced the exposure policy in response to a growing demand for information from groups worried about such activities."

The police have identified 83,100 people in Japan who have close connections with criminal organisations; the 1998 figure was 81,300.

Every police station in Japan has a list of local gangsters. This information, which was supposed to be kept secret to protect the privacy of individuals, has increasingly been leaked to private screening agencies.

Under the new guidelines issued yesterday, police officers will be able to release limited data - excluding photographs and criminal records - on individual mobsters and on the location and activities of crime syndicates.

The national police agency said disclosure would help financial institutions confirm whether potential borrowers have links with gangsters. The information would also go to firms doing debt collection and waste disposal, where syndicates are banned.

"This is what we have wanted for years," Naoguki Fukasawa, who heads an anti-gangsterism committee of the Japan federation of bar associations, said. "The mobsters will no longer be able to hide behind privacy laws. They'll hate this move because it strips away a layer of protection."

But old-fashioned gangsters interviewed yesterday were sanguine. At the Tokyo headquarters of the Inagawa-kai, Japan's third biggest crime syndicate, the burly office chief boasted that it would make no difference.

"I'm proud of being a yakuza. We are not cheap gangsters, so why should we want to hide?" he said. "Tell my neighbours, tell anyone. We have nothing to be ashamed about." He declined to give his name.

fields.headline: Winkles destroy oysters
fields.trailText: Barely recovered from storms and an oil spill which devastated their production, French shellfish farmers face a fearsome new threat: an oyster-eating Japanese winkle which is rapidly taking over the Atlantic seaboard.
fields.body:
Barely recovered from storms and an oil spill which devastated their production, French shellfish farmers face a fearsome new threat: an oyster-eating Japanese winkle which is rapidly taking over the Atlantic seaboard.

"We could be witnessing the beginnings of a commercial and environmental catastrophe," said Michel Séguignes of the marine ecology laboratory at the University of La Rochelle.

The species "breeds incredibly fast, is already supplanting harmless native winkles and can eat its way through a bed of oysters in a matter of weeks".

The inch-long Ocinebrellus inornatus, native to southern Japan, has been found in only six places between La Rochelle and Royan in south-west France.

But the French Academy of Science said in a recent report that on the edges of beds where it had proliferated about half the oyster crop had been destroyed in a band three to four metres wide.

It said that the winkle, which drills a hole in the oyster's shell and sucks out its flesh, was "ideally installed" in the low walls between the beds, one stone housing up to 160 of them.

The French eat 1.8bn oysters a year and the business supports 8,300 farmers, with an annual turnover of £155m.

Storms last December wiped out up to a fifth of the Atlantic coast's 6,880 hectares (17,000 acres) of oyster beds, and the wreck of the tanker Erika spewed out 11.3m litres (3m gallons) of heavy fuel oil soon afterwards.

fields.headline: Mob stones Milosevic rival
fields.standfirst:
Serb challenger driven out of town by organised thugs for trying to make election speech in Kosovo
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Supporters of Slobodan Milosevic broke up a campaign rally in Kosovo yesterday by the Yugoslav leader's main challenger in the presidential race, striking Vojislav Kostunica in the face with a stone and setting upon a convoy of cars protecting him.
fields.byline: Nick Wood  in Mitrovice, northern Kosovo
fields.body:
Supporters of Slobodan Milosevic broke up a campaign rally in Kosovo yesterday by the Yugoslav leader's main challenger in the presidential race, striking Vojislav Kostunica in the face with a stone and setting upon a convoy of cars protecting him.

French troops of the K-For peacekeeping force in Kosovo stood by without intervening.

Pelted by rotten tomatoes, Mr Kostunica, the candidate put up by an alliance comprising most of Yugoslavia's opposition parties, was bundled off the platform by his bodyguards after trying to address Serb inhabitants of the divided city of Mitrovice in northern Kosovo.

Then Mr Milosevic's supporters, some of them bussed in for the purpose, set about attacking Mr Kostunica's convoy. The soft-spoken university professor was hit with a stone below his eye.

Wiping the blood from a small cut under his eye, the challenger said Mr Milosevic must feel threatened if he was resorting to violence. "I am ashamed because I am a Serb, but I am also very satisfied because this means that Milosevic is weaker than ever," he said.

The rally in Mitrovice was intended to be a moment of glory for Mr Kostunica, who was touring Kosovo's Serb enclaves on his first visit to the province as a presidential candidate. The largely male crowd appeared uninterested, however, in being told this was the man who could beat Slobodan Milosevic.

"He [Milosevic] put you up to this - God will forgive you but God will not forgive him," Mr Kostunica shouted at his attackers.

After trying to talk for 10 minutes he and his entourage were forced to withdraw. In front of them the row of cars in which they had arrived came under attack from crowds smashing windows and slashing tyres.

Mr Kostunica blamed plainclothes police planted in the crowd for the violence, and criticised Nato peacekeepers for failing to intervene even though they were standing at the edge of the crowd. French soldiers with riot shields and tear gas canisters, were eventually ordered to disperse the gathering.

The acknowledged leader of Mitrovice's Serb community, Oliver Ivanovic, watched the crowd's behavior uneasily, and blamed Mr Milosevic's forces. "Our dismay is that much greater that we did not prevent Mr Kostunica from being exposed to such an extremely unpleasant situation," he said. "We all know that he was the only Serb politician who really took to heart the plight of our people here."

At a press conference afterwards Mr Kostunica taunted Mr Milosovic by inviting him to visit Kosovo. K-For has vowed to arrest the Yugoslav leader as an indicted war criminal if he sets foot in Kosovo.

Mr Kostunica accused Mr Milosevic of neglecting hundreds of thousands of refugees who have fled the province since Serb forces were driven out by Nato in June 1999.

But the main opposition candidate cast doubt on the fairness of both the local elections being overseen by the UN in Kosovo and the presidential elections: "I was very sceptical about local elections in October so I am sceptical about these elections in September because the situation is not normal in the rest of Kosovo because of Albanian terrorism and here because of Milosevic's terrorism as you have seen here."

Earlier yesterday, Mr Kostunica's convoy was held up at the Serbian border with Kosovo as K-For officials refused to let his party through. Overnight, Serbian Socialist party supporters put up Milosevic posters with the slogan, "Under the flag of freedom". Mr Kostunica's publicity matter was torn down.

Mr Kostunica bitterly attacked international sanctions against Yugoslavia, which helped to produce the resentment behind "some of the stones that we saw today".

"We are his [Mr Milosevic's] hostages and the hostages of the International Community."

The UN says election balloting can take place in Kosovo, but not inside UN buildings. The opposition says this will help Mr Milosevic's party, which is organising the voting expected to take place in private households.

fields.headline: It's an increasingly dirty business
fields.standfirst: Sleaze surveyor calls on Britain to draw up code of conduct for companies working abroad
fields.trailText: When the disgraced Irish prime minister, Charles Haughey, was brought down by a string of scandals, the country's business community caught the backlash. During subsequent investigations more than 100 prominent businessmen featured in allegations that they used offshore accounts to avoid paying Ir£100m (£81m) in tax. Many leading Irish companies have been viewed with suspicion ever since.
fields.body:
When the disgraced Irish prime minister, Charles Haughey, was brought down by a string of scandals, the country's business community caught the backlash. During subsequent investigations more than 100 prominent businessmen featured in allegations that they used offshore accounts to avoid paying Ir£100m (£81m) in tax. Many leading Irish companies have been viewed with suspicion ever since.

In Germany, police are investigating more than 2,000 corruption cases a year, many of them linking politicians and industry leaders. Those whose reputations have been tainted include Gerhard Glogowski, forced to resign as the Social Democrat premier of Lower Saxony. Helmut Kohl, president from 1982 until 1998, has been castigated for flouting the party finance laws he enacted.

Put together, these stories paint a grubby picture. But is this fair?

The answer, according to Transparency International which examines these issues on a daily basis, is an emphatic "yes". Its Corruption Perceptions Index, which defines the problem as "the abuse of public office for private gain", ranks 90 countries in terms of the degree of corruption that is believed to exist among public officials and politicians.

"Corruption in government is rampant in dozens of countries," says this year's report, just published. "Global corruption has impoverished the third world - through cartels, transfer pricing and restraints of all description as well as through more conventional bribery and corruption."

The situation is so bad that corruption has become a "very real threat to the emerging democracies", although much of the blame is levelled at outside investors. It says many international companies are using bribes as an everyday business tool and are only too willing to risk their reputations by making payments to officials responsible for allocating contracts. "The propensity to pay foreign bribes by major international firms, we believe, remains high."

Laurence Cockcroft, chairman of Transparency International UK, wants the British government to establish a code of practice for companies with dealings abroad. Although refusing requests for bribes might mean the loss of one or two contracts, he says, a company's long term reputation will be much more valuable.

"There's increasing recognition that a code of practice needs to be developed and there should be a compliance system."

Mr Cockcroft said around $150bn of outside aid was received by countries which were thought to be the most corrupt in the world. TI rates Nigeria the country perceived to be the most corrupt, followed by Yugoslavia, Ukraine, Azerbaijan, Angola and Indonesia. Nigeria's title, inherited from Cameroon, will be depressing news for its president, Olusegun Obasanjo, who has pursued an anti-corruption agenda.

He now has powers to halt dubious contracts and investigate sleazy politicians but success depends on levels of political and economic stability. He also has the weight of history pressing on him. In July, the Nigerian government formally asked Britain to freeze the bank accounts of the late dictator General Sani Abacha, who is alleged to have stolen $4.3bn during his five years in office from 1993.

Authorities believe that up to $450m was deposited by Abacha, his family and associates in leading London banks. A panel set up by the new government following Abacha's death in 1998 recovered $1bn from accounts he held jointly with an aide and a London-based Nigerian businessman.

Authors of the index admit some countries - Pakistan, Angola and Nicaragua - are not included because there was insufficient data available, even though they are known to have problems.

Last month the Pakistan military government sought the help of British authorities trackdown 14 former officials and businessmen, believed to be living in Britain, as part of a corruption inquiry.

Money laundering in Israel is said to have reached colossal proportions due to the rise of organised crime following the collapse of the Soviet Union.

Closer to home, the worst offenders are named as Ireland, Germany and Italy, which is said to have an "abysmal" record.

"The regional table for western Europe shows that an initiative against corruption in Europe is long overdue," TI says.

The biggest post-war corruption scandal in France centred on the state-owned oil company Elf, which is alleged to have spent around £40m a year in bribes. Andre Tarallo, who used to manage the company's African affairs, has told an inquiry the money was spent on buying influence from foreign and domestic politicians. Most of the money, he claimed, went to Gabon, followed by Angola, Nigeria, Congo and Cameroon.

But there are at least a few places where corruption is barely a problem. The cleanest country in the TI survey was Finland, followed by Denmark, New Zealand, Sweden and Canada. Britain came in 10th, a slight improvement on last year.
Shamed states:

Most corrupt

1. Nigeria

2. Yugoslavia

3. Ukraine/Azerbaijan

5. Angola/Indonesia

Cleanest

1. Finland

2. Denmark

3. New Zealand/Sweden

5. Canada

...

10. United Kingdom
