In his wanderings, Everett assumes a sort of Odyssean status, and the Coens whimsically present their movie as the loosest and most amiable kind of Homeric epic, with - amongst other nudges - our heroes being seduced from their path by Sirens, meeting a sinister Cyclops in the form of the one-eyed Bible-salesman Big Dan Teague (John Goodman) and Everett finally returning to his Penelope in the form of his long-suffering wife Penny (Holly Hunter). And in the Homeric spirit, quite a few of the dramatis personae are blind, or partially blind. But there is a more pressing and relevant form of ancestor worship: screwballmeister Preston Sturges, whose 1942 classic, Sullivan's Travels, was about a director of light comedies, who longs to make a harrowingly earnest "message" picture about social injustice called O Brother, Where Art Thou? One of the distinctive successes of the Coens' O Brother is the way it has managed to channel some of the spirit of Sturges in its zany dialogue and galloping pace, also cloning some of the earlier film's defining moments: the old-time religion, the prison farm, the "church parade" of convicts watching a movie. The anxiety of influence is felt much more strongly from Sturges than the 3,000-year-old Greek poet. This is far from being George Clooney's first comedy role. In his younger, bigger-haired days, he was a veteran of Roseanne and dozens of unsuccessful sitcom pilots. In this film, he produces a novel, raffish charm as the silver-tongued rogue, and a certain old-fashioned masculine mass and substance, which he wears lightly, but in such a way as to signal unmistakablyhis arrival in the big-screen big league. Here, Clooney manages to combine a little of Clark Gable with a whisper of Cary Grant's early incarnation as a vaudevillian stage comic. As for his supporting men: Tim Blake Nelson gets to sing his own blues numbers (Clooney's voice is dubbed by Dan Tyminski). John Turturro's face is stuck in an expression of baffled disapproval, his jaw twisted round to make his face shaped like a J. Clooney is very much the leader of the pack. But all three find their feet in this baroque, distinctive world, which the Coens devise with such intricate charm. Borges has a short story about a writer whose chef d'oeuvre is a multi-volume encyclopaedia about an imaginary universe; the Coens write one of these every time they make a movie. To take just one of the many flecks and touches: when Clooney can't get hold of a can of Dapper Dan, his preferred brand of hair-cream, he is piqued to be offered another, absurdly called Fop. One of many happy inventions. The only reservation I would maintain about O Brother is that the invocation of Preston Sturges reminds us that, somewhere amidst the wackiness, Sullivan's Travels actually had serious things to say about real poverty and what real film-makers can really do about it. For all its accomplishment, there is nothing in the Coens' film which speaks of this concern. But it is made with marvellous clarity and fluency, and Joel and Ethan Coen attain a comic simplicity that other film-makers can only dream of.

fields.headline: Dancer in the dark
fields.standfirst: Lars von Trier's film is silly, shallow and manipulative
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: [It] has to be the most sensationally silly film of the year - as well as the most shallow and crudely manipulative
fields.body:
For its sheer effrontery, for its browbeating melodrama and pseudo-tragedy, Lars von Trier's Dancer in the Dark has to be the most sensationally silly film of the year - as well as the most shallow and crudely manipulative. Everything about it is silly, from the faux naivety and implausibility of its plot to the secret little idiot savant smile on the face of its Victim Heroine played by Björk - a squeaking, chirruping diva turn sufficient to curdle every carton of milk within a 10-kilometre radius.

She plays Selma, the poor Czech immigrant factory worker in small-town America, scrimping every penny to bring up her myopic son by herself and daydreaming ecstatically about the musicals she adores, and the action is regularly interspersed with these fantasy song-and-dance sequences. Björk's role requires her to be almost blind as well, wearing a pair of coke-bottle lenses that make her eyes look even tinier and piggier than usual. As well as conferring the romance and glamour of disability on this bestselling international recording artist, this conceals her inability or unwillingness to inter-relate in any way whatever with the other actors in the film.

Screen acting doesn't get much more dire than this, or at least I really hope not. And there are few films which could aspire, or want to aspire to the extravaganza of unreflective emoting and pain that Lars von Trier cheerfully expects us to endure.

Well, no one's doubting the crude determination with which Dogme's own PT Barnum delivers his bizarre incendiary assault on our emotions. But his story appears to have been plagiarised from a 12-year-old's English composition homework. Poor Selma is going blind! And her poor son Gene is going blind as well! And she's going without and saving up money in a tin box for Gene's "operation" - but this is stolen from her by a wicked policeman. Confronting him and getting her money back leads to violence and tragedy. On death row, Selma learns that a lawyer can get her off, but martyr that she is, she can't accept his help because his fee happens to be equivalent to the money she needs for Gene's surgery. (The state authorities have for some reason allowed Selma to keep this money, although they believe that she has stolen it from the cop, and that theft is the motive for murder!)

So the gruyère plot does not stand up to the most cursory inspection. Furthermore, there is the casual haziness about the nature of this eye problem and the necessary remedial "operation". There is no discussion whatever of the father of Selma's child - can't he put his hand in his pocket? - and no mention of how Selma got over to the US from Czechoslovakia. With the help of family, perhaps? They, too, are a mystery.

But still we haven't reached the peak of this Kilimanjaro of absurdity. For Selma's best friend in the factory is played by Catherine Deneuve, in full Marie Antoinette milkmaid mode, sporting a humble overcoat, a headscarf, and a French accent you could slice a baguette with. What is this haughty patrician exquisite doing here? God only knows. Von Trier appears to have roped them together as if for an art installation. In fact, the opening sequence, in which Björk and Deneuve are attempting to rehearse an am-dram production of The Sound of Music, is an amusingly surreal moment in its laboured way. But it can't justify the price of admission. And there is nothing in Dancer in the Dark to suggest that Von Trier is all that passionate or even knowledgeable about Hollywood musicals: certainly not in his boringly conceived MTV-choreography sequences.

There are obvious points of comparison with Breaking the Waves: the martyr heroine nurturing the flame of her spirit in the midst of reactionary and oppressive forces, the strategic deployment of heart-rending disability. But however chancy Breaking the Waves was, it always had some consistency and believability, due to a luminous performance from Emily Watson, in comparison with which Björk's ridiculous effort pops like a soap bubble. (Some of the cast return for Dancer; the sinister Udo Kier has a cameo as the doctor and Jean-Marc Barr, who played Jan's mate on the oil rig, is cast here as the factory supervisor - and a very charming and human performance it is too.)

In Breaking the Waves, Von Trier displayed not genius, perhaps, but something distinctive and inspired. But in Dancer in the Dark, this talent has degenerated into a kind of cynical showbiz charlatanism. There is something so basically facetious about his film-making: a sense that the whole thing is intended to be nothing more than a grand situationist flourish. Oscar Wilde might have laughed at the death of little Nell; I suspect Von Trier is having a bit of a giggle himself at Selma's fate. It's no more possible to feel sorry for Selma than for any of Damien Hirst's pickled demi-livestock. Maybe Dancer in the Dark would work as a continuous video loop at the Saatchi gallery. In the cinema, there are more exacting standards.
